event_name: A resolution honoring Mississippi's Gestational Age Act.
blurb: On January 22, 2025, the Senate introduced S. RES. 30, honoring Mississippi's Gestational Age Act, which restricts elective abortions after 15 weeks. The resolution, submitted by Senator Hyde-Smith and others, acknowledges Representative Becky Currie's role in its passage and the Supreme Court's decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health. It emphasizes gratitude for states enacting laws to protect unborn children. The resolution is currently with the Committee on the Judiciary.
body:
III 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  S. RES. 30 
Honoring Mississippi’s Gestational Age Act. 
IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES 
JANUARY 22, 2025 
Mrs. H YDE-SMITH (for herself, Mr. W ICKER , Mr. H OEVEN , Mr. M ARSHALL , 
Mr. R ICKETTS , Mr. L EE, and Mr. B ANKS ) submitted the following resolu-
tion; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary 
RESOLUTION 
Honoring Mississippi’s Gestational Age Act. 
Whereas, on January 15, 2018, Mississippi State Representa-
tive Becky Currie of Brookhaven, Mississippi introduced the Gestational Age Act to protect unborn children from elective abortion after 15 weeks gestation; 
Whereas, on March 19, 2018, the Gestational Age Act was 
passed by the Mississippi State Legislature, approved by Mississippi Governor Phil Bryant, and enacted into law; 
Whereas, in May 2021, the United States Supreme Court 
agreed to review Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health, 597 U.S. 215 (2022), a challenge to the constitutionality of the Gestational Age Act, where the question before the Court was whether all pre-viability prohibitions on elec-tive abortion are unconstitutional; and

•SRES 30 IS Whereas, on June 24, 2022, the United States Supreme 
Court issued its historical decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health, holding that ‘‘the Constitution does not confer a right to abortion. Roe and Casey must be over-ruled, and the authority to regulate abortion must be re-turned to the people and their elected representatives.’’: Now, therefore, be it 
Resolved, That the Senate— 1
(1) expresses profound gratitude to Mississippi 2
State Representative Becky Currie for introducing 3
the catalyst that ultimately brought about the his- 4
torical victory of overturning Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. 5
113 (1973) and Planned Parenthood v. Casey, 503 6
U.S. 833 (1992); and 7
(2) honors life-affirming States across the coun- 8
try that have enacted laws aimed to value and pro- 9
tect the inherent dignity of every mother and unborn 10
child. 11

event_name: Born-Alive Abortion Survivors Protection Act
blurb: The Senate voted 52-47 against cloture on the Born-Alive Abortion Survivors Protection Act (S. 6), which mandates healthcare practitioners provide necessary care for infants born alive after an abortion. The bill includes penalties for non-compliance and allows civil actions for damages. This legislative move underscores ongoing debates over abortion rights and infant protections.
body:
II 
Calendar No. 4 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  S. 6 
To amend title 18, United States Code, to prohibit a health care practitioner 
from failing to exercise the proper degree of care in the case of a child who survives an abortion or attempted abortion. 
IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES 
JANUARY 15, 2025 
Mr. L ANKFORD (for himself, Mr. B ANKS , Mr. T HUNE , Mrs. H YDE-SMITH , Mr. 
RISCH, Ms. L UMMIS , Mrs. B RITT, Mr. M CCONNELL , Mr. W ICKER , Mrs. 
BLACKBURN , Mr. C RAPO , Mrs. F ISCHER , Mr. G RASSLEY , Mr. H OEVEN , 
Mr. M ARSHALL , Mr. T ILLIS , Mr. B UDD, Mr. S COTT of South Carolina, 
Mr. J OHNSON , Mr. S HEEHY , Mr. T UBERVILLE , Mr. H AGERTY , Mr. C UR-
TIS, Mr. Y OUNG , Mr. R ICKETTS , Mr. C RAMER , Mr. B ARRASSO , Mr. K EN-
NEDY , Mr. C ORNYN , Mr. C ASSIDY , Mr. R OUNDS , Ms. E RNST , Mr. S COTT  
of Florida, Mr. D AINES , Mr. M ULLIN , Mr. G RAHAM , Mr. C RUZ, Mr.

HAWLEY , Mr. M CCORMICK , and Mr. B OOZMAN ) introduced the following 
bill; which was read the first time 
JANUARY 16, 2025 
Read the second time and placed on the calendar 
A BILL 
To amend title 18, United States Code, to prohibit a health 
care practitioner from failing to exercise the proper de-gree of care in the case of a child who survives an abortion or attempted abortion.

•S 6 PCSBe it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Born-Alive Abortion 4
Survivors Protection Act’’. 5
SEC. 2. FINDINGS. 6
Congress finds the following: 7
(1) If an abortion results in the live birth of an 8
infant, the infant is a legal person for all purposes 9
under the laws of the United States, and entitled to 10
all the protections of such laws. 11
(2) Any infant born alive after an abortion or 12
within a hospital, clinic, or other facility has the 13
same claim to the protection of the law that would 14
arise for any newborn, or for any person who comes 15
to a hospital, clinic, or other facility for screening 16
and treatment or otherwise becomes a patient within 17
its care. 18
SEC. 3. BORN-ALIVE INFANTS PROTECTION. 19
(a) R EQUIREMENTS PERTAINING TO BORN-ALIVE 20
ABORTION SURVIVORS .—Chapter 74 of title 18, United 21
States Code, is amended by inserting after section 1531 22
the following: 23
VerDate Sep 11 2014 01:02 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\S6.PCS S6kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB

•S 6 PCS‘‘§ 1532. Requirements pertaining to born-alive abor-1
tion survivors 2
‘‘(a) R EQUIREMENTS FOR HEALTH CARE PRACTI - 3
TIONERS .—In the case of an abortion or attempted abor- 4
tion that results in a child born alive: 5
‘‘(1) D EGREE OF CARE REQUIRED ; IMMEDIATE  6
ADMISSION TO A HOSPITAL .—Any health care practi- 7
tioner present at the time the child is born alive 8
shall— 9
‘‘(A) exercise the same degree of profes- 10
sional skill, care, and diligence to preserve the 11
life and health of the child as a reasonably dili- 12
gent and conscientious health care practitioner 13
would render to any other child born alive at 14
the same gestational age; and 15
‘‘(B) following the exercise of skill, care, 16
and diligence required under subparagraph (A), 17
ensure that the child born alive is immediately 18
transported and admitted to a hospital. 19
‘‘(2) M ANDATORY REPORTING OF VIOLA - 20
TIONS .—A health care practitioner or any employee 21
of a hospital, a physician’s office, or an abortion 22
clinic who has knowledge of a failure to comply with 23
the requirements of paragraph (1) shall immediately 24
report the failure to an appropriate State or Federal 25
law enforcement agency, or to both. 26

•S 6 PCS‘‘(b) P ENALTIES .— 1
‘‘(1) I N GENERAL .—Whoever violates subsection 2
(a) shall be fined under this title, imprisoned for not 3
more than 5 years, or both. 4
‘‘(2) I NTENTIONAL KILLING OF CHILD BORN  5
ALIVE .—Whoever intentionally performs or attempts 6
to perform an overt act that kills a child born alive 7
described under subsection (a), shall be punished as 8
under section 1111 of this title for intentionally kill- 9
ing or attempting to kill a human being. 10
‘‘(c) B AR TO PROSECUTION .—The mother of a child 11
born alive described under subsection (a) may not be pros-12
ecuted for a violation of this section, an attempt to violate 13
this section, a conspiracy to violate this section, or an of-14
fense under section 3 or 4 of this title based on such a 15
violation. 16
‘‘(d) C IVILREMEDIES .— 17
‘‘(1) C IVIL ACTION BY A WOMAN ON WHOM AN  18
ABORTION IS PERFORMED .—If a child is born alive 19
and there is a violation of subsection (a), the woman 20
upon whom the abortion was performed or at- 21
tempted may, in a civil action against any person 22
who committed the violation, obtain appropriate re- 23
lief. 24

•S 6 PCS‘‘(2) A PPROPRIATE RELIEF .—Appropriate relief 1
in a civil action under this subsection includes— 2
‘‘(A) objectively verifiable money damage 3
for all injuries, psychological and physical, occa- 4
sioned by the violation of subsection (a); 5
‘‘(B) statutory damages equal to 3 times 6
the cost of the abortion or attempted abortion; 7
and 8
‘‘(C) punitive damages. 9
‘‘(3) A TTORNEY ’S FEE FOR PLAINTIFF .—The 10
court shall award a reasonable attorney’s fee to a 11
prevailing plaintiff in a civil action under this sub- 12
section. 13
‘‘(4) A TTORNEY ’S FEE FOR DEFENDANT .—If a 14
defendant in a civil action under this subsection pre- 15
vails and the court finds that the plaintiff’s suit was 16
frivolous, the court shall award a reasonable attor- 17
ney’s fee in favor of the defendant against the plain- 18
tiff. 19
‘‘(e) D EFINITIONS .—In this section the following 20
definitions apply: 21
‘‘(1) A BORTION .—The term ‘abortion’ means 22
the use or prescription of any instrument, medicine, 23
drug, or any other substance or device— 24

•S 6 PCS‘‘(A) to intentionally kill the unborn child 1
of a woman known to be pregnant; or 2
‘‘(B) to intentionally terminate the preg- 3
nancy of a woman known to be pregnant, with 4
an intention other than— 5
‘‘(i) after viability, to produce a live 6
birth and preserve the life and health of 7
the child born alive; or 8
‘‘(ii) to remove a dead unborn child. 9
‘‘(2) A TTEMPT .—The term ‘attempt’, with re- 10
spect to an abortion, means conduct that, under the 11
circumstances as the actor believes them to be, con- 12
stitutes a substantial step in a course of conduct 13
planned to culminate in performing an abortion. 14
‘‘(3) B ORN ALIVE .—The term ‘born alive’ has 15
the meaning given that term in section 8 of title 1, 16
United States Code (commonly known as the ‘Born- 17
Alive Infants Protection Act’).’’. 18
(b) C ONFORMING AMENDMENTS .— 19
(1) The table of sections for chapter 74 of title 20
18, United States Code, is amended by adding at 21
the end the following: 22
‘‘1532. Requirements pertaining to born-alive abortion survivors.’’. 
(2) The chapter heading for chapter 74 of title 23
18, United States Code, is amended by striking 24

This Act shall take effect one day after the date of 7

event_name: A bill to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to permanently allow a tax deduction at the time an investment in qualified property is made.
blurb: A bill has been introduced to amend the Internal Revenue Code, allowing permanent tax deductions for investments in qualified property at the time of investment. The bill has been read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance for further consideration. This change could enhance investment incentives for businesses.

metadata.event_name: A bill to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to permanently allow a tax deduction at the time an investment in qualified property is made.

event_name: A bill to prohibit taxpayer funded abortions.
blurb: A bill to prohibit taxpayer-funded abortions has been read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance for further consideration. Stakeholders should monitor the committee's progress, as this legislation could significantly impact funding for reproductive health services.

metadata.event_name: A bill to prohibit taxpayer funded abortions.

event_name: A bill to provide a civil remedy for individuals harmed by sanctuary jurisdiction policies, and for other purposes.
blurb: A bill has been introduced to offer civil remedies for individuals harmed by sanctuary jurisdiction policies. It has been read twice and is currently under review by the Committee on the Judiciary. Key takeaway: This legislation could impact legal recourse for those affected by such policies.

metadata.event_name: A bill to provide a civil remedy for individuals harmed by sanctuary jurisdiction policies, and for other purposes.

event_name: Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 471) to expedite under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 and improve forest management activities on National Forest System lands, on public lands under the jurisdiction of the Bureau of Land Management, and on Tribal lands to return resilience to overgrown, fire-prone forested lands, and for other purposes, and providing for consideration of the bill (S. 5) to require the Secretary of Homeland Security to take into custody aliens who have been charged in the United States with theft, and for other purposes.
blurb: The House will consider H.R. 471 to expedite forest management under the National Environmental Policy Act, addressing overgrown, fire-prone lands. S. 5, requiring the Secretary of Homeland Security to detain aliens charged with theft, will also be reviewed. Debate for each bill is limited to one hour, with waived points of order. Amendments are restricted to those specified in the Committee report.
body:
H. Res. 53 
In the House of Representatives, U. S., 
January 22, 2025. 
Resolved, That at any time after adoption of this resolu-
tion the Speaker may, pursuant to clause 2(b) of rule XVIII, declare the House resolved into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union for consideration of the bill (H.R. 471) to expedite under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 and improve forest management activities on National Forest System lands, on public lands under the jurisdiction of the Bureau of Land Management, and on Tribal lands to return resilience to overgrown, fire-prone for-ested lands, and for other purposes. The first reading of the bill shall be dispensed with. All points of order against con-sideration of the bill are waived. General debate shall be con-fined to the bill and shall not exceed one hour equally divided and controlled by the chair and ranking minority member of the Committee on Natural Resources or their respective des-ignees. After general debate the bill shall be considered for amendment under the five-minute rule. The bill shall be con-sidered as read. All points of order against provisions in the 
2 
•HRES 53 EH bill are waived. No amendment to the bill shall be in order 
except those printed in the report of the Committee on Rules accompanying this resolution. Each such amendment may be offered only in the order printed in the report, may be offered only by a Member designated in the report, shall be consid-ered as read, shall be debatable for the time specified in the report equally divided and controlled by the proponent and an opponent, shall not be subject to amendment, and shall not be subject to a demand for division of the question in the House or in the Committee of the Whole. All points of order against such amendments are waived. At the conclusion of consideration of the bill for amendment the Committee shall rise and report the bill to the House with such amendments as may have been adopted. The previous question shall be considered as ordered on the bill and amendments thereto to final passage without intervening motion except one motion to recommit. 
S
EC. 2. Upon adoption of this resolution it shall be in 
order to consider in the House the bill (S. 5) to require the Secretary of Homeland Security to take into custody aliens who have been charged in the United States with theft, and for other purposes. All points of order against consideration of the bill are waived. The bill shall be considered as read. All points of order against provisions in the bill are waived. The previous question shall be considered as ordered on the 
3 
•HRES 53 EH bill and on any amendment thereto to final passage without 
intervening motion except: (1) one hour of debate equally di-vided and controlled by the chair and ranking minority mem-ber of the Committee on the Judiciary or their respective des-ignees; and (2) one motion to commit. 
Attest: 
Clerk.

event_name: Hershel Woody Williams National Medal of Honor Monument Location Act
blurb: The Hershel Woody Williams National Medal of Honor Monument Location Act, passed by the House on January 21, 2025, aims to establish a commemorative monument on the National Mall honoring Medal of Honor recipients. The bill is now in the Senate, referred to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources. This initiative underscores the importance of recognizing valor and inspiring future generations.
body:
IIB 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 186 
IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES 
JANUARY 22, 2025 
Received; read twice and referred to the Committee on Energy and Natural 
Resources 
AN ACT 
To authorize the National Medal of Honor Museum Founda-
tion to establish a commemorative work on the National Mall to honor the extraordinary acts of valor, selfless service, and sacrifice displayed by Medal of Honor recipi-ents. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

HR 186 RFSSECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 1
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Hershel ‘Woody’ Wil- 2
liams National Medal of Honor Monument Location Act’’. 3
SEC. 2. FINDINGS. 4
Congress finds the following: 5
(1) Congress in 2021 unanimously passed, and 6
the President signed, Public Law 117–80 (40 U.S.C. 7
8903 note), which authorized the National Medal of 8
Honor Museum Foundation to establish on Federal 9
land in the District of Columbia a commemorative 10
work to honor the acts of valor, selfless service, and 11
sacrifice displayed by Medal of Honor recipients. 12
(2) The Medal of Honor was established by 13
President Abraham Lincoln and first awarded 160 14
years ago on March 25, 1863, and is part of Lin- 15
coln’s lasting and living legacy. 16
(3) In 1991, during the administration of Presi- 17
dent George H.W. Bush, this legacy was extended 18
further when National Medal of Honor Day was es- 19
tablished as March 25th of each year. 20
(4) The Medal of Honor is awarded to all 21
branches of the United States Armed Forces as our 22
nation’s highest recognition for valor in combat. 23
(5) The number of living Medal of Honor re- 24
cipients has been steadily declining, making it even 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:22 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H186.RFS H186ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
3 
HR 186 RFSmore crucial to honor and recognize their heroic sac- 1
rifices and inspire future generations. 2
(6) Hershel ‘‘Woody’’ Williams, the last World 3
War II Medal of Honor recipient, passed away in 4
2022 and laid in honor at the United States Capitol. 5
(7) The Medal of Honor represents the very 6
best of our Nation—ordinary citizens, who took ex- 7
traordinary action above and beyond the call of duty 8
and became heroes of our Republic. 9
(8) These examples inspire all citizens and ig- 10
nite within us the very spirit of America. 11
(9) The Medal of Honor rises to the level of su- 12
preme national and historical importance necessary 13
to warrant representation on the National Mall. 14
(10) Locating the National Medal of Honor 15
Monument in close proximity to the Lincoln Memo- 16
rial within the Reserve would be a respectful exten- 17
sion of his enduring legacy and recognition of what 18
ordinary people can accomplish when working for 19
the greater good. 20
SEC. 3. NATIONAL MEDAL OF HONOR MONUMENT LOCA-21
TION. 22
(a) S ITE.—Notwithstanding section 8908(c) of title 23
40, United States Code, the commemorative work author-24
ized by section 1(a) of Public Law 117–80 (40 U.S.C. 25

event_name: MAPWaters Act of 2025
blurb: The MAPWaters Act of 2025 aims to standardize and publish data on public recreational use of federal waterways. Currently in the Senate, it mandates interagency cooperation to digitize and make accessible information on waterway access, restrictions, and fishing regulations within five years. Key takeaway: Enhanced transparency and accessibility for outdoor recreation enthusiasts.
body:

IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES 
JANUARY 22, 2025 
Received; read twice and referred to the Committee on Energy and Natural 
Resources 
AN ACT 
To provide for the standardization, consolidation, and publi-
cation of data relating to public outdoor recreational use of Federal waterways among Federal land and water management agencies, and for other purposes.

event_name: Lake Winnibigoshish Land Exchange Act of 2025
blurb: The Lake Winnibigoshish Land Exchange Act of 2025, received by the Senate on January 22, 2025, facilitates a land exchange in Minnesota's Chippewa National Forest. The act mandates the Secretary of Agriculture to execute the exchange within one year, contingent on title approval and environmental assessments. BWLT will cover all associated costs, ensuring the acquired land is managed as part of the National Forest System.
body:

1STSESSION  H. R. 197

JANUARY 22, 2025 
Received; read twice and referred to the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, 
and Forestry 
AN ACT 
To provide for a land exchange in the Chippewa National 
Forest, Minnesota, and for other purposes.

tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

ited Liability Corporation. 8

Chief of the Forest Service. 23
SEC. 3. EXCHANGE OF LAND. 24
(a) E XCHANGE AUTHORIZED .—Subject to the provi- 25
sions of this Act, if BWLT offers to convey the non-Fed-26

Parcel; and 9
(3) accept from BWLT all right, title, and in- 10
terest of BWLT in and to the non-Federal land. 11

section (a) shall be— 13

(3) conditioned on the satisfactory completion 23
of a Phase I Environmental Site Assessment by 24

acceptance of the non-Federal parcel; 2

graph (2), the exchange under subsection (a) shall 8

by mutual agreement, may correct any minor errors 5

change under subsection (a), BWLT shall pay all closing 13

(2) any applicable inspection fees, escrow fees, 16

vey required under Federal law, regulation, or pol- 19
icy, including a Phase I Environmental Site Assess- 20
ment of the non-Federal land. 21
(i) S URVEY .— 22
(1) I N GENERAL .—The exact acreages and legal 23
descriptions of the Federal and non-Federal land to 24

event_name: ACRES Act
blurb: The ACRES Act, received by the Senate on January 22, 2025, mandates the Secretaries of Agriculture and Interior to submit detailed annual reports on hazardous fuels reduction activities on Federal lands. Key requirements include tracking acreage treated, wildfire risk levels, and cost-effectiveness. The Act aims for improved transparency and data accuracy in wildfire risk management, with reports made publicly available. Actionable deadlines include a 90-day implementation of standardized data procedures post-enactment.
body:

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 204 
IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES 
JANUARY 22, 2025 
Received; read twice and referred to the Committee on Energy and Natural 
Resources 
AN ACT 
To require that the Secretary of Agriculture and the Sec-
retary of the Interior submit accurate reports regarding hazardous fuels reduction activities, and for other pur-poses. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

port on the number of acres of Federal land on 15
which the Secretary concerned carried out hazardous 16

year. 18
(2) R EQUIREMENTS .—For purposes of the re- 19
port required under paragraph (1), the Secretary 20
concerned shall— 21
(A) in determining the number of acres of 22
Federal land on which the Secretary concerned 23
carried out hazardous fuels reduction activities 24
during the period covered by the report— 25

which hazardous fuels reduction activities 2
were completed during such period; and 3

land recorded in the report, include information 10
on— 11
(i) which such acres are located in the 12

(ii) the level of wildfire risk (high, 14

tivities completed for such acres, delin- 18
eating between whether such activities 19

(I) in a wildfire managed for re- 21
source benefits; or 22

fuels activities carried out during the pe- 2
riod covered by the report; 3
(v) the region or system unit in which 4
the acres are located; and 5
(vi) the effectiveness of the hazardous 6
fuels reduction activities on reducing the 7
risk of wildfire. 8
(3) T RANSPARENCY .—The Secretary concerned 9
shall make each report submitted under paragraph 10

ment of Agriculture and the Department of the Inte- 12
rior, as applicable. 13
(b) A CCURATE DATACOLLECTION .— 14
(1) I N GENERAL .—Not later than 90 days after 15
the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary 16
concerned shall implement standardized procedures 17
for tracking data related to hazardous fuels reduc- 18
tion activities carried out by the Secretary con- 19
cerned. 20
(2) E LEMENTS .—The standardized procedures 21
required under paragraph (1) shall include— 22
(A) regular, standardized data reviews of 23
the accuracy and timely input of data used to 24
track hazardous fuels reduction activities; 25

HR 204 RFS(B) verification methods that validate 1
whether such data accurately correlates to the 2
hazardous fuels reduction activities carried out 3
by the Secretary concerned; 4
(C) an analysis of the short- and long-term 5
effectiveness of the hazardous fuels reduction 6
activities on reducing the risk of wildfire; and 7
(D) for hazardous fuels reduction activities 8
that occur partially within the wildland-urban 9
interface, methods to distinguish which acres 10

and which acres are located outside the 12

(3) R EPORT .—Not later than 2 weeks after im- 14
plementing the standardized procedures required 15
under paragraph (1), the Secretary concerned shall 16

(A) such standardized procedures; and 18
(B) program and policy recommendations 19
to Congress to address any limitations in track- 20
ing data related to hazardous fuels reduction 21
activities under this subsection. 22
(c) GAO S TUDY .—Not later than 2 years after the 23

HR 204 RFS(1) conduct a study on the implementation of 1
this Act, including any limitations with respect to— 2
(A) reporting hazardous fuels reduction ac- 3
tivities under subsection (a); or 4
(B) tracking data related to hazardous 5
fuels reduction activities under subsection (b); 6
and 7
(2) submit to Congress a report that describes 8
the results of the study under paragraph (1). 9
(d) D EFINITIONS .—In this Act: 10
(1) H AZARDOUS FUELS REDUCTION ACTIV - 11
ITY.—The term ‘‘hazardous fuels reduction activ- 12
ity’’— 13
(A) means any vegetation management ac- 14
tivity to reduce the risk of wildfire, including 15
mechanical treatments and prescribed burning; 16
and 17
(B) does not include the awarding of con- 18
tracts to conduct hazardous fuels reduction ac- 19
tivities. 20
(2) F EDERAL LANDS .—The term ‘‘Federal 21
lands’’ means lands under the jurisdiction of the 22

culture. 24

7 
HR 204 RFS(3) S ECRETARY CONCERNED .—The term ‘‘Sec- 1
retary concerned’’ means— 2
(A) the Secretary of Agriculture, with re- 3
spect to National Forest System lands; and 4
(B) the Secretary of the Interior, with re- 5
spect to public lands and units of the National 6
Park System. 7
(4) W ILDLAND -URBAN INTERFACE .—The term 8
‘‘wildland-urban interface’’ has the meaning given 9
the term in section 101 of the Healthy Forests Res- 10
toration Act of 2003 (16 U.S.C. 6511). 11
(e) N OADDITIONAL FUNDS AUTHORIZED .—No addi- 12
tional funds are authorized to carry out the requirements 13

vance for such purposes. 16

event_name: SHARKED Act of 2025
blurb: The SHARKED Act of 2025, aimed at addressing shark depredation, has been introduced in the Senate. It mandates the Secretary of Commerce to establish a task force for research and management strategies. The task force will report findings every two years, focusing on improving communication, identifying research priorities, and developing educational materials for the fishing community. Key stakeholders will be appointed to enhance coordination across sectors.
body:
IIB 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 207 
IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES 
JANUARY 22, 2025 
Received; read twice and referred to the Committee on Commerce, Science, 
and Transportation 
AN ACT 
To direct the Secretary of Commerce to establish a task 
force regarding shark depredation, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:54 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H207.RFS H207ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
2 
HR 207 RFSSECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 1
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Supporting the Health 2
of Aquatic systems through Research Knowledge and En-3
hanced Dialogue Act of 2025’’ or the ‘‘SHARKED Act 4
of 2025’’. 5
SEC. 2. SHARK DEPREDATION TASK FORCE AND RESEARCH 6
PROJECTS. 7
(a) S HARK DEPREDATION TASKFORCE .— 8
(1) I N GENERAL .—The Secretary of Commerce 9
shall establish a task force (referred to in this sub- 10
section as the ‘‘task force’’) to identify and address 11
critical needs with respect to shark depredation. 12
(2) M EMBERSHIP .—The Secretary of Com- 13
merce shall appoint individuals to the task force, in- 14
cluding— 15
(A) 1 representative from— 16
(i) each Regional Fishery Manage- 17
ment Council established under section 18
302(a)(1) of the Magnuson-Stevens Fish- 19
ery Conservation and Management Act (16 20
U.S.C. 1852(a)(1)); 21
(ii) each Marine Fisheries Commis- 22
sion, as such term is defined in section 3 23
of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Con- 24
servation and Management Act (16 U.S.C. 25
1802); 26

3

coastal State from each Regional Fishery 2
Management Council established under 3
section 302(a)(1) of the Magnuson-Stevens 4
Fishery Conservation and Management Act 5
(16 U.S.C. 1852(a)(1)); and 6
(iv) the National Marine Fisheries 7
Service; 8
(B) an individual with expertise in the 9
management of highly migratory species; 10
(C) a researcher with expertise in shark 11
management and behavior; and 12
(D) a researcher with expertise in shark 13
ecology. 14
(3) R ESPONSIBILITIES .—The task force shall— 15
(A) develop ways to improve coordination 16
and communication across the fisheries man- 17
agement community and shark research com- 18
munity to address shark depredation; 19
(B) identify research priorities and funding 20
opportunities for such priorities, including— 21
(i) identifying shark species involved 22
in interactions; 23
(ii) shark stock assessments; 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:54 Jan 23, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H207.RFS H207ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
4 
HR 207 RFS(iii) how sharks become habituated to 1
humans and thus lead to more interactions 2
between sharks and humans; 3
(iv) how angler behavior and fishery 4
regulatory frameworks may influence shark 5
interactions; 6
(v) techniques and strategies to re- 7
duce harmful interactions between sharks 8
and humans, including the development 9
and use of non-lethal deterrents; 10
(vi) the role of healthy shark popu- 11
lations in the ocean food web; and 12
(vii) climate change impacts on shift- 13
ing shark populations, prey, and shark be- 14
havior; 15
(C) develop recommended management 16
strategies to address shark depredation; and 17
(D) coordinate the development and dis- 18
tribution of educational materials to help the 19
fishing community minimize shark interactions 20
including through changed angler behavior and 21
expectations. 22
(4) R EPORT .—Not later than 2 years after the 23
date of the enactment of this section, and every 2 24
years thereafter until the termination of the task 25

5 
HR 207 RFSforce in accordance with paragraph (5), the task 1
force shall submit to Congress a report regarding 2
the findings of the task force. 3
(5) S UNSET .—The task force shall terminate 4
not later than 7 years after the date on which the 5
Secretary of Commerce establishes the task force. 6
(6) C OASTAL STATE DEFINED .—In this sub- 7
section, the term ‘‘coastal State’’— 8
(A) means a State of the United States in, 9
or bordering on, the Atlantic Ocean, Pacific 10
Ocean, Arctic Ocean, Gulf of Mexico, or Long 11
Island Sound; and 12
(B) includes Puerto Rico, the Virgin Is- 13
lands of the United States, Guam, the Com- 14
monwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, 15
and American Samoa. 16
(b) S HARK DEPREDATION RESEARCH PROJECTS .— 17
Section 318(c) of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Con-18
servation and Management Act (16 U.S.C. 1867(c)) is 19
amended by adding at the end the following: 20
‘‘(6) Projects to better understand shark depre- 21
dation, including identifying what causes increases 22
in shark depredation and determining how to best 23
address shark depredation.’’. 24

event_name: Electing Members to certain standing committees of the House of Representatives.
blurb: On January 22, 2025, the House of Representatives elected new members to key standing committees. Notable appointments include Mr. Doggett and Mr. Scott to the Budget Committee, and Ms. Pressley and Ms. Tlaib to Oversight. The motion to reconsider was laid on the table and agreed to without objection, streamlining the committee formation process.
body:
H. Res. 55 
In the House of Representatives, U. S., 
January 22, 2025. 
Resolved, That the following named Members be, and are 
hereby, elected to the following standing committees of the House of Representatives: 
C
OMMITTEE ON THE BUDGET : Mr. Doggett, Mr. Scott 
of Virginia, Mr. Peters of California, Mr. Panetta, Mrs. Wat-son Coleman, Ms. Plaskett, Ms. Escobar, Ms. Omar, Ms. Balint, Ms. Kaptur, Ms. Jayapal, Mr. Tonko, Mr. McGarvey, Mr. Amo. 
C
OMMITTEE ON HOUSE ADMINISTRATION : Mr. Morelle, 
Ms. Sewell, Mrs. Torres of California, Ms. Johnson of Texas. 
COMMITTEE ON NATURAL RESOURCES : Ms. Vela ´zquez, 
Mrs. Dingell, Mr. Soto, Ms. Brownley. 
COMMITTEE ON OVERSIGHT AND GOVERNMENT RE-
FORM : Ms. Pressley, Ms. Tlaib. 
Attest: 
Clerk.

Currently, it is under review by the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. Stakeholders should monitor developments for potential impacts on energy market dynamics.

metadata.event_name: To require Transmission Organizations to allow bids from aggregators of certain retail customers, and for other purposes.

event_name: To amend title XIX of the Social Security Act and Public Health Service Act to improve the reporting of abortion data to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and for other purposes.
blurb: The bill to amend Title XIX of the Social Security Act aims to enhance abortion data reporting to the CDC. Currently referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, it seeks to improve public health data accuracy. Stakeholders should monitor its progress for potential implications on health policy and reporting practices.

metadata.event_name: To amend title XIX of the Social Security Act and Public Health Service Act to improve the reporting of abortion data to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and for other purposes.

event_name: To require owners of covered federally assisted rental dwelling units to install temperature sensors in such units, and for other purposes.
blurb: The proposed legislation mandates owners of federally assisted rental units to install temperature sensors. This initiative aims to enhance tenant safety and comfort. The bill is currently under review by the House Committee on Financial Services. Stakeholders should monitor its progress for potential impacts on rental property management and tenant rights.

metadata.event_name: To require owners of covered federally assisted rental dwelling units to install temperature sensors in such units, and for other purposes.

event_name: To reform the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives.
blurb: The proposed reform of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives has been referred to the House Judiciary Committee. Key takeaways include potential changes to regulatory practices and enforcement strategies. Stakeholders should monitor developments for implications on gun control and public safety policies.

metadata.event_name: To reform the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives.

event_name: To amend the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to authorize the use of grant amounts for providing training and resources for first responders on the use of containment devices to prevent secondary exposure to fentanyl and other potentially lethal substances, and purchasing such containment devices for use by first responders.
blurb: The proposed amendment to the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act seeks to authorize grants for training first responders on containment devices to mitigate fentanyl exposure risks. It also includes funding for purchasing these devices. This initiative emphasizes enhancing safety measures for emergency personnel dealing with hazardous substances.

metadata.event_name: To amend the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to authorize the use of grant amounts for providing training and resources for first responders on the use of containment devices to prevent secondary exposure to fentanyl and other potentially lethal substances, and purchasing such containment devices for use by first responders.

event_name: To prohibit group health plans, health insurance issuers, and Federal health care programs from applying prior authorization requirements, utilization management techniques, and medical necessity reviews.
blurb: The proposed legislation aims to eliminate prior authorization requirements, utilization management techniques, and medical necessity reviews for group health plans, health insurance issuers, and federal health care programs. Currently referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce and the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform for review. Key takeaway: potential streamlined access to healthcare services.

metadata.event_name: To prohibit group health plans, health insurance issuers, and Federal health care programs from applying prior authorization requirements, utilization management techniques, and medical necessity reviews.

event_name: To direct the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to improve interregional electricity transfer capability between immediately adjacent transmission planning regions, and for other purposes.
blurb: A new directive aims to enhance interregional electricity transfer between adjacent transmission planning regions. The proposal has been referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce for review. Key takeaway: Improved electricity transfer capabilities could increase efficiency and reliability in energy distribution.

metadata.event_name: To direct the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to improve interregional electricity transfer capability between immediately adjacent transmission planning regions, and for other purposes.

event_name: To amend the Omnibus Public Land Management Act of 2009 to increase Tribal access to water conservation and efficiency grants, and for other purposes.
blurb: The bill aims to amend the Omnibus Public Land Management Act of 2009 to enhance Tribal access to water conservation and efficiency grants. Currently referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources, it seeks to promote sustainable water management in Tribal communities. Key takeaway: Increased funding opportunities for Tribal water initiatives.

metadata.event_name: To amend the Omnibus Public Land Management Act of 2009 to increase Tribal access to water conservation and efficiency grants, and for other purposes.

event_name: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to require that the Supreme Court of the United States be composed of nine justices.
blurb: A joint resolution (H.J. Res. 28) has been introduced in the House to amend the U.S. Constitution, mandating the Supreme Court to consist of nine justices. The proposal, sponsored by multiple representatives, is currently referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary. If passed, it requires ratification by three-fourths of state legislatures within seven years.

event_name: To require covered platforms to remove nonconsensual intimate visual depictions, and for other purposes.
blurb: The proposed legislation mandates covered platforms to eliminate nonconsensual intimate visual depictions. Currently referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, this bill aims to enhance user protection and privacy online. Key takeaway: if passed, platforms will face stricter obligations to safeguard against unauthorized intimate content.

metadata.event_name: To require covered platforms to remove nonconsensual intimate visual depictions, and for other purposes.

event_name: To amend the Public Health Service Act to eliminate consideration of the income of organ recipients in providing reimbursement of expenses to donating individuals, and for other purposes.
blurb: A bill has been introduced to amend the Public Health Service Act, removing income considerations for organ recipients when reimbursing expenses for donors. The proposal aims to encourage organ donation by alleviating financial barriers. It is currently under review by the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. Stakeholders should monitor its progress for potential impacts on organ donation practices.

metadata.event_name: To amend the Public Health Service Act to eliminate consideration of the income of organ recipients in providing reimbursement of expenses to donating individuals, and for other purposes.

event_name: A bill to rescind the unobligated balances of amounts appropriated for Internal Revenue Service enhancements and use such funding for an External Revenue Service.
blurb: A bill has been introduced to rescind unobligated funds for IRS enhancements, reallocating them to establish an External Revenue Service. The bill has been read twice and is currently under review by the Committee on Finance. Key implications include potential shifts in federal revenue management.

metadata.event_name: A bill to rescind the unobligated balances of amounts appropriated for Internal Revenue Service enhancements and use such funding for an External Revenue Service.

event_name: A bill to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to increase excise taxes on fuel used by private jets, and for other purposes.
blurb: A bill has been introduced to amend the Internal Revenue Code, proposing increased excise taxes on fuel for private jets. It has been read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance. Stakeholders should monitor this legislation for potential impacts on private aviation costs.

metadata.event_name: A bill to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to increase excise taxes on fuel used by private jets, and for other purposes.

event_name: A bill to clarify the country of origin of certain articles imported into the United States for purposes of certain trade enforcement actions.
blurb: A bill aimed at clarifying the country of origin for specific imported articles in the U.S. has been introduced. It has been read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance for further consideration. Key takeaway: This legislation could enhance trade enforcement actions.

metadata.event_name: A bill to clarify the country of origin of certain articles imported into the United States for purposes of certain trade enforcement actions.

event_name: A bill to improve the transparency of Amtrak operations, and for other purposes.
blurb: A bill aimed at enhancing Amtrak's operational transparency has been introduced. It has been read twice and is currently under review by the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation. Stakeholders should monitor the committee's progress for potential impacts on Amtrak's accountability and service quality.

metadata.event_name: A bill to improve the transparency of Amtrak operations, and for other purposes.

event_name: No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion and Abortion Insurance Full Disclosure Act of 2025
blurb: The No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion and Abortion Insurance Full Disclosure Act of 2025 was introduced in the House on January 22, 2025. It prohibits federal funding for abortions and mandates disclosure of abortion coverage in health plans. The bill is under review by the Committees on Energy and Commerce, Judiciary, and Ways and Means. Key provisions include barring taxpayer-funded abortions and clarifying ACA implications.

event_name: A joint resolution providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Internal Revenue Service relating to "Gross Proceeds Reporting by Brokers That Regularly Provide Services Effectuating Digital Asset Sales".
blurb: On January 21, 2025, a joint resolution was introduced in the Senate to disapprove the IRS rule on "Gross Proceeds Reporting by Brokers for Digital Asset Sales." The resolution, led by Senator Cruz and others, aims to nullify the rule, which currently has no force pending congressional action. It has been referred to the Committee on Finance for further consideration.

event_name: An original resolution expressing the sense of the Senate that the President of the United States possesses legal authority under existing law to take immediate and necessary action to secure the southwest border of the United States.
blurb: The Senate has placed S. RES. 29 on the legislative calendar, affirming the President's authority to take immediate action to secure the U.S.-Mexico border. The resolution urges the reinstatement of effective border policies, including the Migrant Protection Protocols and expedited removal of illegal aliens. Key takeaways include the emphasis on national security and the need for a comprehensive approach to immigration enforcement.
body:
II 
Calendar No. 5 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  S. RES. 29 
Expressing the sense of the Senate that the President of the United States 
possesses legal authority under existing law to take immediate and nec-essary action to secure the southwest border of the United States. 
IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES 
JANUARY 21, 2025 
Mr. P AUL, from the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Af-
fairs, reported the following original resolution; which was placed on the calendar 
RESOLUTION 
Expressing the sense of the Senate that the President of 
the United States possesses legal authority under exist-ing law to take immediate and necessary action to secure the southwest border of the United States. 
Whereas, since the start of the Biden-Harris Administration, 
nearly 11,000,000 individuals have been encountered at-tempting to enter the United States unlawfully; 
Whereas U.S. Customs and Border Protection has— 
(1) apprehended nearly 400 suspected terrorists at-
tempting to enter the United States illegally between ports of entry; 
VerDate Sep 11 2014 02:07 Jan 22, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6300 E:\BILLS\SR29.RS SR29ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
2 
•SRES 29 RS (2) encountered an additional 1,587 suspected ter-
rorists at United States ports of entry; and 
(3) identified more than 1,700,000 special interest 
aliens; 
Whereas, since October 1, 2021, more than 120,000 illegal 
aliens with criminal warrants or convictions were encoun-tered along United States borders, including— 
(1) more than 4,800 illegal aliens who were con-
victed of assault, battery, or domestic violence; 
(2) more than 3,300 illegal aliens who were con-
victed of theft-related offenses; 
(3) nearly 1,400 illegal aliens who were convicted of 
sexual offenses; and 
(4) nearly 200 illegal aliens who were convicted of 
homicide or manslaughter; 
Whereas, under section 235(b)(2)(C) of the Immigration and 
Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1225(b)(2)(C)), the Depart-ment of Homeland Security is authorized to immediately return certain applicants for admission or asylum to a contiguous foreign territory in accordance with the memorandum from the Secretary of Homeland Security entitled ‘‘Policy Guidance for Implementation of the Mi-grant Protection Protocols’’, dated January 25, 2019, or any substantially similar policy changes issued or taken on or after January 20, 2025, whether set forth in a memorandum, executive order, regulation, directive, or by other action; 
Whereas, under section 212(f) of such Act (8 U.S.C. 
1182(f)), the President has been given broad authority to suspend the entry of all aliens, or to impose any restric-tions upon the entry of aliens the President deems appro-priate, allowing the President to bar the entry of nation-
VerDate Sep 11 2014 02:07 Jan 22, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6300 E:\BILLS\SR29.RS SR29ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
3 
•SRES 29 RS als whose admission could be detrimental to the interests 
of the United States; 
Whereas, under section 208(b)(2)(C) of such Act (8 U.S.C. 
1158(b)(2)(C)), the Department of Homeland Security is authorized to promulgate additional limitations and con-ditions under which an alien shall be ineligible for asy-lum, including making asylum seekers ineligible if they enter or attempt to enter the United States across the southern border without first applying for protection from persecution or torture in at least 1 country, other than the alien’s country of citizenship, nationality, or last lawful habitual residence, through which the alien transited en route to the United States; and 
Whereas the ‘‘Remain in Mexico’’ policy (also known as the 
Migrant Protection Protocols) was an effective measure that enhanced border security, helped deter illegal en-tries, and made the United States safer: Now, therefore, be it 
Resolved, That the Senate— 1
(1) affirms that the President has the authority 2
under the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 3
U.S.C. 1101 et seq.), including sections 4
208(a)(2)(A), 212(f), and 235(b)(2)(C) (8 U.S.C. 5
1158(a)(2)(A), 1182(f), and 1225(b)(2)(C)) to take 6
action to secure the southern border and protect the 7
sovereignty and security of the United States; and 8
(2) urges the President and the Secretary of 9
Homeland Security to utilize all available statutory 10
authority to expeditiously reinstate or implement 11
VerDate Sep 11 2014 02:07 Jan 22, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\SR29.RS SR29ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
4 
•SRES 29 RS policies and programs that will promote orderly and 1
lawful entry at the border, deter illegal immigration, 2
and protect national security, including by— 3
(A) immediately removing illegal aliens; 4
(B) immediately returning illegal aliens to 5
Mexico; 6
(C) reinstating the Migrant Protection 7
Protocols (commonly known as ‘‘Remain in 8
Mexico’’) or any substantially similar policy; 9
(D) ending the catch-and-release policy; 10
(E) ending abuses of humanitarian parole 11
authority; 12
(F) detaining inadmissible aliens; 13
(G) making illegal aliens ineligible for asy- 14
lum; 15
(H) using expedited removal authority; and 16
(I) eliminating taxpayer-funded benefits 17
for illegal aliens. 18

event_name: Preventing Violence Against Women by Illegal Aliens Act
blurb: The "Preventing Violence Against Women by Illegal Aliens Act" has been introduced in the Senate after passing the House on January 16, 2025. This legislation amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to make aliens convicted of sex offenses and domestic violence inadmissible and deportable. The bill emphasizes protection for women and children from violent offenders. It is currently under review by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 30 
IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES 
JANUARY 17, 2025 
Received; read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary 
AN ACT 
To amend the Immigration and Nationality Act to provide 
that aliens who have been convicted of or who have committed sex offenses or domestic violence are inadmis-sible and deportable. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

It has been read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance for further consideration. Stakeholders should monitor this bill for potential impacts on disaster-related tax relief.

metadata.event_name: A bill to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to modify the rules for postponing certain deadlines by reason of disaster.

It has been read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance for further consideration. This initiative aims to support nursing education and enhance workforce development in healthcare.

blurb: A new bill aims to reform antitrust laws by amending the Clayton Act to strengthen competition protection, deter harmful exclusionary practices, and enhance enforcement by the DOJ and FTC. It has been read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary for further consideration.

event_name: To require assessments for Foreign Terrorist Organization designations, authorize certain appropriations for certain fiscal years for Operation Stonegarden, and for other purposes.

Key takeaway: Enhanced scrutiny and funding for counterterrorism operations.

event_name: Tennessee Valley Authority Salary Transparency Act
blurb: The Tennessee Valley Authority Salary Transparency Act has been received in the Senate and referred to the Committee on Environment and Public Works. This legislation mandates detailed salary disclosures for management-level employees at the TVA, exempting such information from certain disclosure laws. It passed the House on January 15, 2025, highlighting a push for greater accountability in federal employee compensation.

event_name: POWER Act of 2025
blurb: The POWER Act of 2025, recently passed by the House, aims to enhance electric utility resilience by allowing federal assistance for hazard mitigation activities alongside emergency power restoration. Currently in the Senate, it has been referred to the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs. Key takeaway: The Act facilitates additional support for utilities, promoting proactive disaster preparedness.
body:

IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES 
JANUARY 16, 2025 
Received; read twice and referred to the Committee on Homeland Security and 
Governmental Affairs 
AN ACT 
To amend the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emer-
gency Assistance Act to authorize Federal agencies to provide certain essential assistance for hazard mitigation for electric utilities, and for other purposes.

tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

event_name: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide special rules for the taxation of certain residents of Taiwan with income from sources within the United States.
blurb: The United States-Taiwan Expedited Double-Tax Relief Act has been introduced to amend the Internal Revenue Code, establishing special tax rules for certain Taiwanese residents earning U.S.-sourced income. The bill aims to reduce withholding rates and facilitate tax agreements. Currently, it has been received by the Senate and referred to the Committee on Finance for further consideration. Key outcomes may enhance economic ties and tax equity for Taiwanese individuals.

event_name: A resolution honoring the service of women in combat roles in the Armed Forces.
blurb: On January 16, 2025, the Senate introduced S. Res. 28, honoring the service of women in combat roles in the Armed Forces. The resolution acknowledges their bravery and contributions since the Revolutionary War, highlighting significant achievements, including Combat Action Badges. It aims to inspire future generations and was referred to the Committee on Armed Services for consideration.
body:
III 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  S. RES. 28 
Honoring the service of women in combat roles in the Armed Forces. 
IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES 
JANUARY 16, 2025 
Mrs. M URRAY (for herself, Ms. D UCKWORTH , Mr. V ANHOLLEN , Mr. 
BLUMENTHAL , Mr. S CHIFF , Mr. D URBIN , Mr. C OONS , Mr. B OOKER , Ms. 
SMITH , Mrs. S HAHEEN , Mr. W YDEN , Ms. H IRONO , Mrs. G ILLIBRAND , 
Mr. M ERKLEY , Ms. B ALDWIN , Mr. W ARNOCK , Mr. S CHATZ , Mr. B EN-
NET, Ms. R OSEN , Mr. P ADILLA , Ms. K LOBUCHAR , and Ms. S LOTKIN ) 
submitted the following resolution; which was referred to the Committee on Armed Services 
RESOLUTION 
Honoring the service of women in combat roles in the Armed 
Forces. 
Whereas women have honorably served in the Armed Forces 
with distinction since the Revolutionary War; 
Whereas the Department of Defense announced the opening 
of all military occupations and specialties to women in December 2015; 
Whereas women have received numerous commendations for 
their service in combat since September 2001, including Bronze Stars and Silver Stars;

2 
•SRES 28 IS Whereas, since September 11, 2001, approximately 3,000 
women have earned Combat Action Badges and Combat Action Ribbons; and 
Whereas women in the Armed Forces serve in special forces 
units, including as Army Rangers, Air Force Special Op-erators, and in the Marine Corps Forces Special Oper-ations Command: Now, therefore, be it 
Resolved, That the Senate— 1
(1) recognizes the contribution, bravery, and 2
sacrifices of women serving in combat roles in the 3
Armed Forces; and 4
(2) encourages the continued celebration of the 5
achievements of women in the Armed Forces to in- 6
spire future generations. 7

event_name: Honoring Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., by celebrating diversity, promoting tolerance, and condemning hate.
blurb: On January 16, 2025, the House introduced H. Res. 48 to honor Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. It celebrates diversity, promotes tolerance, and condemns hate. The resolution calls for recognition of Dr. King's legacy and urges all to uphold his values of justice and equality, marking his 96th birthday on January 20.

•HRES 48 IH Whereas the Nation will celebrate the 96th anniversary of the 
birth of Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., on Mon-day, January 20, 2025; 
Whereas Dr. King taught that the blessing of diversity is our 
strength; 
Whereas Dr. King fought, marched, and preached for the in-
alienable rights of all people, particularly Black Ameri-cans; 
Whereas among these rights is the inviolable right of every 
person to cast their vote and make their voice heard in a representative democracy; 
Whereas tolerance for one another’s difference in race, eth-
nicity, gender, culture, religion, sexual orientation, age, or disability is a profound virtue; 
Whereas civil discourse in a land of democratic freedom is the 
true promise of our country; and 
Whereas Dr. King once wrote in his 1963 Letter from a Bir-
mingham Jail, ‘‘Whatever affects one directly, affects all indirectly’’: Now, therefore, be it

(1) celebrates the 96th anniversary of the birth- 2
day of Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., on 3
January 20, 2025, which shall serve as a reminder 4
that hate and hateful conduct based on differences 5
has no place in the United States in tribute to his 6
life and teachings; 7
(2) affirms the words of Reverend Dr. Martin 8
Luther King, Jr., ‘‘Anyone who lives inside the 9

anywhere within its bounds’’; 2

of Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.; 4

nation, or prejudice targeted at any minority ethnic 6
group, including the Black community, Indigenous 7
people, the Jewish community, the Asian-American 8
and Pacific Islander community, the Muslim commu- 9
nity, and the Hispanic and Latino communities; 10
(5) condemns any form of harassment, discrimi- 11
nation, or prejudice based on a person’s gender, in- 12
cluding the trans community and LGBTQ+ individ- 13
uals; 14
(6) abhors the violence and animus that led to 15
the untimely death of Reverend Dr. Martin Luther 16
King, Jr.; and 17
(7) calls on all people across the Nation and the 18
world to uphold Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King, 19
Jr.’s values and teachings of justice, equality, peace, 20
advocacy, and tolerance. 21

event_name: Recognizing that article I, section 10 of the United States Constitution explicitly reserves to the States the sovereign power to repel an invasion and defend their citizenry from the overwhelming and "imminent danger" posed by paramilitary, narco-terrorist cartels, terrorists and criminal actors who seized control of our southern border.
blurb: On January 16, 2025, H. RES. 50 was introduced to the House, asserting states' constitutional right to repel invasions by criminal and terrorist organizations at the southern border. The resolution emphasizes the failures of the Biden administration in border security and highlights the impact on border states. It has been referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary for further consideration.
body:
IV 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. RES. 50 
Recognizing that article I, section 10 of the United States Constitution 
explicitly reserves to the States the sovereign power to repel an invasion and defend their citizenry from the overwhelming and ‘‘imminent danger’’ posed by paramilitary, narco-terrorist cartels, terrorists and criminal actors who seized control of our southern border. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 16, 2025 
Mr. A RRINGTON (for himself, Mr. S ELF, Mr. E LLZEY , Mr. W EBER of Texas, 
Ms. V ANDUYNE , Mr. F ALLON , Mr. N EHLS , Mr. M ORAN , Mr. B ABIN , Mr. 
WILLIAMS of Texas, Mr. C RENSHAW , Mr. G OODEN , Ms. D ELACRUZ, 
Mr. L UTTRELL , Mr. J ACKSON of Texas, Mr. T ONY GONZALES of Texas, 
and Mr. M CCAUL) submitted the following resolution; which was referred 
to the Committee on the Judiciary 
RESOLUTION 
Recognizing that article I, section 10 of the United States 
Constitution explicitly reserves to the States the sov-ereign power to repel an invasion and defend their citi-zenry from the overwhelming and ‘‘imminent danger’’ posed by paramilitary, narco-terrorist cartels, terrorists and criminal actors who seized control of our southern border. 
Whereas the Preamble to the United States Constitution out-
lines the chief responsibility of the Federal Government is to ‘‘insure domestic tranquility’’ and ‘‘provide for the common defense’’;

•HRES 50 IH Whereas article IV, section 4 of the United States Constitu-
tion clearly states ‘‘The United States shall guarantee to every State in this Union a Republican Form of Govern-ment, and shall protect each of them against Invasion’’; 
Whereas President Biden failed to uphold his oath and fulfill 
his constitutional duty to ‘‘faithfully execute’’ the laws of the land; 
Whereas, during the Biden administration there were record-
breaking apprehensions at the southern border; 
Whereas from 2021 through 2024, monthly apprehensions 
exceeded 200,000 for numerous months and continue to increase month over month, eclipsing all-time records for apprehensions at the southern border; 
Whereas from 2021 through 2024, border States spent bil-
lions of dollars annually on the provision of healthcare, housing, education, and other services for illegal aliens; 
Whereas those apprehended came from over 160 nations, in-
cluding many individuals on the terrorist watch list and Special Interest Aliens; 
Whereas thousands of criminal offenses have been committed 
by illegal immigrants, including assault, homicide, illegal drug and contraband possession, trafficking, and sexual offenses; 
Whereas from 2021 through 2024, criminal offenses com-
mitted by illegal immigrants increased one hundred plus percent year over year; 
Whereas from 2021 through 2024, arrests of illegal immi-
grants convicted of sex offenses increased one thousand plus percent year over year according to Customs and Border Protection;

3 
•HRES 50 IH Whereas from 2021 through 2024, authorities seized thou-
sands of pounds of fentanyl—enough to kill every Amer-ican multiple times over; 
Whereas the United States has a drug epidemic whereby tens 
of thousands of Americans die every year and almost 100 percent of drugs, including heroin, methamphetamine, fentanyl, and cocaine, are smuggled across the southern border; 
Whereas migrant women and children, were abused, raped, 
tortured, enslaved, and trafficked as a result of the Biden administration’s failure to secure our southern border; 
Whereas from 2021 through 2024, attempted crossings by, 
and apprehensions of, illegal immigrant criminals on the FBI’s terror watchlist increased exponentially, and even more illegal immigrant criminals and terrorists may have slipped across the border without detection as ‘‘gotaways’’; 
Whereas cartels act as paramilitary, narco-terrorist organiza-
tions that profit from trafficking people and drugs across the southern border into the United States; 
Whereas Customs and Border Protection agents have con-
firmed that cartels facilitate and profit from virtually every illegal border crossing; 
Whereas the Biden administration removed effective meas-
ures that reduced illegal immigration and secured the border, including the Migrant Protection Protocols and border wall construction; 
Whereas the Biden administration implemented measures 
that increased illegal immigration including reinstating ‘‘catch and release’’ policies, weakening asylum require-ments, and countless other policy decisions that encour-

•HRES 50 IH age a disregard for our laws and sovereignty and em-
bolden cartels; 
Whereas States along our southern border—Texas, New Mex-
ico, Arizona, and California—are forced to spend billions of their own taxpayer dollars to address and combat the devastation resulting from an unsecured southern border; 
Whereas from 2021 through 2024, State and local law en-
forcement entities were overwhelmed by criminal activity associated with illegal border crossings, putting officers and communities in danger while draining local re-sources; and 
Whereas from 2021 through 2024, the quality of life and se-
curity of communities in border States, along with every other State in the United States, were threatened, includ-ing ranchers suffering from stolen and damaged prop-erty, healthcare providers with strained capacity, and educators struggling to absorb the high volume of mi-grant children in classrooms: Now, therefore, be it

event_name: Prohibiting Members of the House of Representatives from bringing or displaying a flag of a foreign nation on the floor of the House, and for other purposes.

The Sergeant-at-Arms will enforce this prohibition.

event_name: Recognizing and honoring the work of community organizations and individuals who create and maintain services and educational programs for marginalized groups ensuring the resilience and prosperity of members of the LGBTQIA+ community.
blurb: On January 16, 2025, H. RES. 52 was introduced in the House of Representatives, recognizing the vital contributions of community organizations and individuals supporting the LGBTQIA+ community. The resolution emphasizes the need for continued congressional support for these groups, acknowledging their role in fostering resilience, equality, and safety for marginalized populations. The resolution has been referred to the House Judiciary Committee for further consideration.
body:
IV 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. RES. 52 
Recognizing and honoring the work of community organizations and individ-
uals who create and maintain services and educational programs for marginalized groups ensuring the resilience and prosperity of members of the LGBTQIA+ community. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 16, 2025 
Mrs. W ATSON COLEMAN (for herself, Ms. T LAIB, Mr. E SPAILLAT , Ms. 
VELA´ZQUEZ , Ms. N ORTON , Mrs. M CIVER, Mr. Q UIGLEY , Mr. J OHNSON  
of Georgia, Mr. M ULLIN , Ms. T ITUS, Mr. E VANS of Pennsylvania, Ms. 
SEWELL , Mrs. H AYES , Mr. M OSKOWITZ , Mr. G OTTHEIMER , Mr. 
KRISHNAMOORTHI , Mr. D OGGETT , Mrs. R AMIREZ , Mr. P ALLONE , Mr. 
SWALWELL , and Mr. C ARSON ) submitted the following resolution; which 
was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary 
RESOLUTION 
Recognizing and honoring the work of community organiza-
tions and individuals who create and maintain services and educational programs for marginalized groups ensur-ing the resilience and prosperity of members of the LGBTQIA+ community. 
Whereas LGBTQIA+ community spaces provide critical envi-
ronments, both historically and in the present, where in-dividuals of diverse sexual orientations and gender identi-ties can express themselves authentically, free from dis-crimination, violence, or judgment, while fostering a sense of belonging, mental and emotional well-being, and 
VerDate Sep 11 2014 02:06 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6300 E:\BILLS\HR52.IH HR52ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
2 
•HRES 52 IH community support, and have served as incubators for 
cultural expression, social activism, and education on issues of equality and justice; 
Whereas the term ‘‘LGBTQIA+’’ is understood to mean les-
bian, gay, bisexual, transgender, questioning/queer, intersex, asexual, and other identities; 
Whereas community partnership organizations have been in-
strumental in establishing, maintaining, and expanding these spaces through their dedication, advocacy, and re-source mobilization; 
Whereas LGBTQIA+ community spaces include and uplift 
members who are also from racially and ethnically diverse backgrounds emphasizing the need for solidarity and mu-tual understanding; 
Whereas, in June 1969, the Stonewall Inn—a bar known for 
serving LGBTQIA+ community members at a time when being LGBTQIA+ was illegal—was raided by the City of New York Police Department, leading to a six-day pro-test led by a diverse coalition including transgender women of color such as Marsha P. Johnson and Sylvia Rivera, demonstrating intersectional solidarity in main-taining community support spaces; 
Whereas the Gay and Lesbian Anti-Defamation League, later 
known as GLAAD, held its first meeting in 1985 at the New York Community Center, convening over 400 LGBTQIA+ people and providing an unprecedented op-portunity for members within the LBGTQIA+ commu-nity to openly and unabashedly discuss ongoing political and social issues facing the LGBTQIA+ community; 
Whereas, in 1987, the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, also 
known as ACT UP, was founded through the unity of 
VerDate Sep 11 2014 02:06 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6300 E:\BILLS\HR52.IH HR52ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
3 
•HRES 52 IH smaller LGBTQIA+ organizations and individuals to 
fight discrimination against those with Acquired Im-munodeficiency Syndrome, also known as AIDS, in poli-tics and the health care industry, often facing military and police aggression for holding strategizing meetings in semipublic places, and whose valiant efforts helped com-bat the social and political stigma around AIDS; 
Whereas ballroom, an underground LGBTQIA+ artform that 
emerged out of burlesque shows in the late 1800s and gained mainstream prominence in cities such as New York and Chicago by the 1990s, provided a platform for teams to compete and enhanced recognition of the LGBTQIA+ community; 
Whereas bars and nightclubs that have historically held space 
for the LGBTQIA+ community have declined by 37 per-cent in the last decade, making up only 1.5 percent of the total share of bars and clubs in the United States, with only 32 lesbian bars and nightclubs in existence across the Nation; 
Whereas, according to a 2020 analysis of the National Crime 
Victimization Survey by the Williams Institute at UCLA Law School, sexual and gender minorities disproportion-ately face victimization, experiencing violent victimization at a rate of 71.1 per 1000 people compared with 19.2 per 1000 people for those who are not sexual or gender mi-norities; 
Whereas the New York City Anti-Violence Project’s 
LGBTQIA+ 2022 Safe Spaces National Needs Assess-ment found that 62.1 percent of 380 LGBTQIA+ busi-nesses, groups, and organizations surveyed experienced at least 1 incident of hate violence in 2022 and 9 in 10 or-
VerDate Sep 11 2014 02:06 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6300 E:\BILLS\HR52.IH HR52ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
4 
•HRES 52 IH ganizations expressed a need for security measures they 
do not currently have; 
Whereas ensuring access to resources and investments for 
LGBTQIA+ businesses, groups, and organizations to continue supporting vulnerable populations is a critical need; and 
Whereas when protected spaces are infiltrated by violence and 
hatred, innocent people are the ones who pay the price, oftentimes with their lives, and the 2016 Pulse Nightclub shooting in Orlando took the lives of 49 individuals, and the 2022 Club Q shooting took the lives of 5 individuals, both of which gravely damaged the psyche and sense of security for the respective local communities and LGBTQIA+ organizations: Now, therefore, be it 
Resolved, That the House of Representatives— 1
(1) recognizes the necessity and work of those 2
who create LGBTQIA+ community spaces with the 3
goals of equality; 4
(2) commends those who foster community 5
partnerships between marginalized groups and local 6
resources; 7
(3) acknowledges the historical importance of 8
community-building spaces in the intersectional fight 9
against homophobic, racist, misogynistic, and hateful 10
oppression; 11
(4) honors current and past organizations and 12
individuals dedicated to providing marginalized 13
VerDate Sep 11 2014 02:06 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00004 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\HR52.IH HR52ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
5 
•HRES 52 IH groups, like the LGBTQIA+ community and people 1
of color, with space to commune and organize; 2
(5) affirms the importance of education and 3
awareness initiatives that highlight the historical 4
and cultural significance of LGBTQIA+ community 5
spaces; and 6
(6) encourages continued support by Congress 7
for community organizations and individuals who 8
continue to create community for marginalized 9
groups. 10
Æ

event_name: Honoring Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc., on reaching the historic milestone of 105 years of scholarship, service, sisterhood, and finer womanhood.
blurb: The House of Representatives has introduced H. RES. 51 to honor Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc. for its 105 years of scholarship, service, sisterhood, and finer womanhood. Founded on January 16, 1920, the sorority has over 100,000 members globally. The resolution highlights its pioneering achievements and commitment to community engagement. Key legislators are supporting this initiative, reinforcing Zeta's legacy and impact.
body:
IV 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. RES. 51 
Honoring Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc., on reaching the historic milestone 
of 105 years of scholarship, service, sisterhood, and finer womanhood. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 16, 2025 
Ms. K AMLAGER -DOVE (for herself, Ms. W ILSON of Florida, Ms. K ELLY of Illi-
nois, Mrs. S YKES , Mr. T HOMPSON of Mississippi, Ms. W ILLIAMS of Geor-
gia, Ms. M CCLELLAN , Ms. A DAMS , Mr. B ISHOP , Mr. C LEAVER , Mr. C AR-
TER of Louisiana, Mr. C LYBURN , Mr. C ARSON , Mr. J OHNSON of Georgia, 
Mr. F ROST , Mr. J ACKSON of Illinois, Ms. N ORTON , Ms. C LARKE of New 
York, and Ms. T LAIB) submitted the following resolution; which was re-
ferred to the Committee on Education and Workforce 
RESOLUTION 
Honoring Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc., on reaching the his-
toric milestone of 105 years of scholarship, service, sis-terhood, and finer womanhood. 
Whereas Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc., was founded on Janu-
ary 16, 1920, at Howard University in Washington, DC, by five finer women, Arizona Cleaver Stemons, Pearl Anna Neal, Myrtle Tyler Faithful, Viola Tyler Goings, and Fannie Pettie Watts; 
Whereas these ‘‘Five Pearls’’ who founded Zeta Phi Beta So-
rority, Inc., were dedicated to a core desire to provide true service, embrace scholarship, set a standard for sis-terly love and finer womanhood; 
VerDate Sep 11 2014 02:06 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6300 E:\BILLS\HR51.IH HR51ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
2 
•HRES 51 IH Whereas, on March 30, 1923, in Washington, DC, Zeta Phi 
Beta Sorority, Inc., was incorporated to ensure the per-manence of the organization by Myrtle Tyler Faithful, Gladys Warrington, Joanna Houston, Josephine F. John-son, and L.O. Goldia Smith; 
Whereas, since its founding in 1920, Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, 
Inc., has chartered hundreds of chapters worldwide and has a membership of over 100,000 and is divided into eight intercontinental regions and over 875 chapters lo-cated in the United States, Africa, Europe, Asia, and the Caribbean; 
Whereas the organization’s innovation has resulted in several 
firsts, including being the first National Pan-Hellenic Council organization to centralize its operations in a na-tional headquarters, the first to charter a chapter in Afri-ca, the first to form auxiliary groups, and the first to be constitutionally bound to a fraternity, Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity, Inc.; 
Whereas Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc., is dedicated to expand-
ing their reach and has made a concerted effort to de-velop chapters at both predominantly white institutions and historically Black colleges and universities; 
Whereas Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc., has remained dedi-
cated in realizing the vision statement of being ‘‘an orga-nization aimed towards the people and community by raising awareness, encouraging the highest standards for scholastic achievement, and a greater meaning of unity among members’’; 
Whereas the current members of Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, 
Inc., inherit a legacy built by former members who have left remarkable imprints in their fields, including 
VerDate Sep 11 2014 02:06 Jan 17, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6300 E:\BILLS\HR51.IH HR51ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
3 
•HRES 51 IH Bernette Johnson, the first Black woman to serve on the 
Louisiana Supreme Court and the first Black woman to become Chief Justice, Syleena Johnson, a Grammy Award nominee R&B singer, Dr. Elizabeth Koontz, a re-nowned educator, Dionne Warwick, a former Goodwill Ambassador to the United Nation’s Food and Agriculture Organization, Zora Neale Hurston, an author, filmmaker, and anthropologist, and Sheryl Underwood, a comedian and television host; and 
Whereas Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc., continues to make a 
difference in the United States and around the world, al-ways following the footsteps of its founders and uphold-ing the motto of Zeta Phi Beta, Sorority, Inc., to be ‘‘a community-conscious, action-oriented organization’’: Now, therefore, be it 
Resolved, That the House of Representatives con- 1
gratulates and commends Zeta Phi Beta, Sorority, Inc., 2
on 105 years of scholarship, service, sisterhood, and finer 3
womanhood. 4
Æ
