RESOLUTION 
Recognizing Russian actions in Ukraine as a genocide. 
Whereas the Russian Federation’s illegal, premeditated, 
unprovoked, and brutal war against Ukraine includes ex-tensive, systematic, and flagrant atrocities against the people of Ukraine; 
Whereas Article II of the Convention on the Prevention and 
Punishment of the Crime of Genocide (hereinafter the ‘‘Genocide Convention’’), approved and opened for signa-ture in 1948 and entered into force in 1951, defines genocide as ‘‘any of the following acts committed with in-tent to destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnical, racial or religious group, as such: (a) Killing members of the group; (b) Causing serious bodily or mental harm to members of the group; (c) Deliberately inflicting on the

physical destruction in whole or in part; (d) Imposing measures intended to prevent births within the group; (e) Forcibly transferring children of the group to another group’’; 
Whereas substantial and significant evidence documenting 
widespread, systematic actions against the Ukrainian people committed by Russian Forces under the direction of Russian Federation political leadership meets one or more of the criteria under Article II of the Genocide Con-vention, including— 
(1) killing members of the Ukrainian people in mass 
atrocities through deliberate and regularized murders of fleeing civilians and civilians in passing as well as pur-poseful targeting of homes, schools, hospitals, shelters, and other residential and civilian areas; 
(2) causing serious bodily or mental harm to the 
Ukrainian people by launching indiscriminate attacks against civilians and civilian areas, conducting willful strikes on humanitarian evacuation corridors, and em-ploying widespread and systematic sexual violence against Ukrainian civilians, including women, children, and men; 
(3) deliberately inflicting upon the Ukrainian people 
conditions of life calculated to bring about their physical destruction in whole or in part, including displacement due to annihilated villages, towns, and cities left devoid of food, water, shelter, electricity, and other basic neces-sities, starvation caused by the destruction of farmlands and agricultural equipment, the placing of Russian land-mines across thousands of acres of useable fields, and blocking the delivery of humanitarian food aid; 
(4) imposing measures intended to prevent births 
among the Ukrainian people, demonstrated by the Rus-

nity hospitals and other medical facilities and systematic attacks against residential and civilian areas as well as humanitarian corridors intended to deprive Ukrainians of safe havens within their own country and the material conditions conducive to childrearing; and 
(5) forcibly mass transferring millions of Ukrainian 
civilians, hundreds of thousands of whom are children, to Russia or Russian Federation-controlled territories; 
Whereas the Russian Federation’s State-level intent in favor 
of these heinous crimes against humanity has been dem-onstrated through frequent pronouncements and other forms of official communication denying Ukrainian na-tionhood and sovereignty, including President Putin’s ahistorical claims that Ukraine is part of a ‘‘single whole’’ Russian nation with ‘‘no historical basis’’ for being an independent country; 
Whereas some Russian soldiers and brigades accused of com-
mitting war crimes in Bucha and elsewhere were re-warded with medals by President Putin; 
Whereas the Russian State-owned media outlet RIA Novosti’s 
published the article ‘‘What Should Russia do with Ukraine’’ which outlines ‘‘de-Nazification’’ as meaning ‘‘de-Ukrainianization’’ or the destruction of Ukraine; 
Whereas Article I of the Genocide Convention confirms ‘‘that 
genocide, whether committed in time of peace or in time of war, is a crime under international law which they un-dertake to prevent and to punish’’; and 
Whereas additional documentation and analysis of atrocities 
committed by the Russian Federation in Ukraine may be needed to punish those responsible, the substantial and

event_name: Dental Care for Veterans Act
blurb: The Dental Care for Veterans Act (H.R. 210) mandates the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to provide dental care as a standard medical service. Introduced on January 6, 2025, it aims to enhance dental benefits eligibility over a phased timeline. The bill is currently under review by the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs. Key takeaway: Improved access to dental care for veterans is a priority.

event_name: A concurrent resolution authorizing the use of the rotunda of the Capitol for the lying in state of the remains of the late James Earl Carter, Jr., 39th President of the United States.
blurb: A concurrent resolution has been passed authorizing the lying in state of former President James Earl Carter, Jr. in the Capitol rotunda from January 7-9, 2025. The Architect of the Capitol will oversee arrangements, including the transfer of the catafalque for the services. This honors Carter's significant contributions to the nation.
body:
S. Con. Res. 3 Agreed to January 3, 2025
One Hundred Nineteenth Congress 
of the 
United States of America 
AT THE FIRST SESSION 
Begun and held at the City of Washington on Friday, 
the third day of January, two thousand and twenty five 
Concurrent Resolution 
Resolved by the Senate (the House of Representatives concur-
ring), 
SECTION 1. HONORING JAMES EARL CARTER, JR. 
(a) L YING IN STATE IN ROTUNDA .—In recognition of the long 
and distinguished service rendered to the Nation and to the world by the late James Earl Carter, Jr., the 39th President of the United States, his remains shall be permitted to lie in state in the rotunda of the Capitol from January 7, 2025 until January 9, 2025. The Architect of the Capitol, under the direction of the Majority Leader of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, shall take all necessary steps for the accomplish-ment of that purpose. 
(b) U
SE OF CATAFALQUE .—The Architect of the Capitol is 
authorized and directed to transfer the catafalque which is situated in the Exhibition Hall of the Capitol Visitor Center to the rotunda of the Capitol so that such catafalque may be used in connection with services to be conducted there for the late James Earl Carter, Jr., 39th President of the United States. 
Attest: 
Secretary of the Senate. 
Attest: 
Clerk of the House of Representatives.

metadata.event_name: A concurrent resolution authorizing the use of the rotunda of the Capitol for the lying in state of the remains of the late James Earl Carter, Jr., 39th President of the United States.

event_name: A concurrent resolution to provide for the counting on January 6, 2025, of the electoral votes for President and Vice President of the United States.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, S. Con. Res. 2 was agreed upon, scheduling a joint session of Congress to count electoral votes for President and Vice President on January 6, 2025, at 1 PM. The President of the Senate will preside, with appointed tellers from both chambers overseeing the process. This resolution ensures compliance with constitutional requirements for the electoral vote count.
body:
S. Con. Res. 2 Agreed to January 3, 2025
One Hundred Nineteenth Congress 
of the 
United States of America 
AT THE FIRST SESSION 
Begun and held at the City of Washington on Friday, 
the third day of January, two thousand and twenty five 
Concurrent Resolution 
Resolved by the Senate (the House of Representatives concur-
ring), That the two Houses of Congress shall meet in the Hall 
of the House of Representatives on Monday, the 6th day of January 2025, at 1 o’clock post meridian, pursuant to the requirements of the Constitution and laws relating to the election of President and Vice President of the United States, and the President of the Senate shall be their Presiding Officer; that two tellers shall be previously appointed by the President of the Senate on the part of the Senate and two by the Speaker on the part of the House of Representatives, to whom shall be handed, as they are opened by the President of the Senate, all the certificates and papers purporting to be certificates of the electoral votes, which certificates and papers shall be opened, presented, and acted upon in the alphabetical order of the States, beginning with the letter ‘‘A’’; and said tellers, having then read the same in the presence and hearing of the two Houses, shall make a list of the votes as they shall appear from said certificates; and the votes having been ascertained and counted in the manner and according to the rules by law provided, the result of the same shall be delivered to the President of the Senate, who shall thereupon announce the state of the vote, which announcement shall be deemed a sufficient declaration of the persons, if any, elected President and 
S. Con. Res. 2—2 
Vice President of the United States, and together with a list of 
the votes, be entered on the Journals of the two Houses. 
Attest: 
Secretary of the Senate. 
Attest: 
Clerk of the House of Representatives.

metadata.event_name: A concurrent resolution to provide for the counting on January 6, 2025, of the electoral votes for President and Vice President of the United States.

event_name: A concurrent resolution extending the life of the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, the U.S. Congress agreed to S. Con. Res. 1, reauthorizing the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies. This resolution extends the committee's powers to organize the inauguration of the President-elect and Vice President-elect, and continues the authorization for using the Capitol's rotunda and Emancipation Hall for related events.
body:
S. Con. Res. 1 Agreed to January 3, 2025
One Hundred Nineteenth Congress 
of the 
United States of America 
AT THE FIRST SESSION 
Begun and held at the City of Washington on Friday, 
the third day of January, two thousand and twenty five 
Concurrent Resolution 
Resolved by the Senate (the House of Representatives concur-
ring), 
SEC. 1. REAUTHORIZATION OF JOINT COMMITTEE. 
Effective from January 3, 2025, the joint committee created 
by Senate Concurrent Resolution 34 (118th Congress), to make the necessary arrangements for the inauguration of the President- elect and the Vice President-elect of the United States, is continued with the same power and authority provided for in that resolution. 
SEC. 2. USE OF CAPITOL. 
Effective from January 3, 2025, the provisions of Senate 
Concurrent Resolution 35 (118th Congress), to authorize the use of the rotunda and Emancipation Hall of the Capitol by the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies in connection with the proceedings and ceremonies conducted for the inauguration of the President-elect and the Vice President-elect of the United States are continued with the same power and authority provided for in that resolution. 
Attest: 
Secretary of the Senate. 
Attest: 
Clerk of the House of Representatives.

metadata.event_name: A concurrent resolution extending the life of the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies.

event_name: Fixing the daily hour of meeting of the First Session of the One Hundred Nineteenth Congress.
blurb: The House of Representatives approved H. Res. 6, establishing the daily meeting schedule for the One Hundred Nineteenth Congress. Meetings will occur at 2 p.m. on Mondays, noon on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays, and 9 a.m. on other days. This resolution streamlines legislative operations and sets clear expectations for session timings.
body:
H. Res. 6 
In the House of Representatives, U. S., 
January 3, 2025. 
Resolved, That unless otherwise ordered, the hour of 
daily meeting of the House shall be 2 p.m. on Mondays; noon on Tuesdays (or 2 p.m. if no legislative business was con-ducted on the preceding Monday); noon on Wednesdays and Thursdays; and 9 a.m. on all other days of the week. 
Attest: 
Clerk.

metadata.event_name: Fixing the daily hour of meeting of the First Session of the One Hundred Nineteenth Congress.

event_name: Authorizing the Clerk to inform the President of the election of the Speaker and the Clerk.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, the House of Representatives passed H. Res. 4, authorizing the Clerk to notify President Biden of the election of Mike Johnson (LA) as Speaker and Kevin McCumber (IL) as Clerk for the 119th Congress. This formal communication marks a significant leadership transition in the House.
body:
H. Res. 4 
In the House of Representatives, U. S., 
January 3, 2025. 
Resolved, That the Clerk be instructed to inform the 
President of the United States that the House of Representa-tives has elected Mike Johnson, a Representative from the State of Louisiana as Speaker, and Kevin McCumber, a cit-izen of the State of Illinois as Clerk, of the House of Rep-resentatives of the One Hundred Nineteenth Congress. 
Attest: 
Clerk.

metadata.event_name: Authorizing the Clerk to inform the President of the election of the Speaker and the Clerk.

event_name: Authorizing the Speaker to appoint a committee to notify the President of the assembly of the Congress.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, the House approved H. Res. 3, authorizing the Speaker to appoint a two-member committee to notify the President that Congress is assembled and ready for communication. This procedural step underscores the readiness of both Houses to engage with the President.
body:
H. Res. 3 
In the House of Representatives, U. S., 
January 3, 2025. 
Resolved, That a committee of two Members be ap-
pointed by the Speaker on the part of the House of Rep-resentatives to join with a committee on the part of the Sen-ate to notify the President of the United States that a quorum of each House has assembled and Congress is ready to receive any communication that he may be pleased to make. 
Attest: 
Clerk.

metadata.event_name: Authorizing the Speaker to appoint a committee to notify the President of the assembly of the Congress.

event_name: Adopting the Rules of the House of Representatives for the One Hundred Nineteenth Congress, and for other purposes.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, the House adopted H. Res. 5, establishing the rules for the 119th Congress. Key changes include stricter requirements for Speaker vacancy resolutions, provisions for electronic voting in committees, and enhanced transparency in Congressional operations. Notably, the resolution mandates anti-harassment policies in House offices and outlines budgetary constraints on spending. Members are urged to familiarize themselves with these rules to ensure compliance and effective governance.
body:
H. Res. 5 
In the House of Representatives, U. S., 
January 3, 2025. 
Resolved, 
SECTION 1. ADOPTION OF THE RULES OF THE ONE HUNDRED 
EIGHTEENTH CONGRESS. 
The Rules of the House of Representatives of the One 
Hundred Eighteenth Congress, including applicable provi-sions of law or concurrent resolution that constituted rules of the House at the end of the One Hundred Eighteenth Con-gress, are adopted as the Rules of the House of Representa-tives of the One Hundred Nineteenth Congress, with amend-ments to the standing rules as provided in section 2, and with other orders as provided in this resolution. 
SEC. 2. CHANGES TO THE STANDING RULES. 
(a) R ESOLUTION DECLARING THE OFFICE OF SPEAKER  
VACANT .—In clause 2(a) of rule IX, add the following new 
subparagraph: 
‘‘(3) A resolution causing a vacancy in the Office of 
Speaker shall not be privileged except if it is offered by a 
2

sponsors from the majority party at the time it is offered.’’.

the use of electronic voting in accordance with regulations submitted for printing in the Congressional Record by the chair of the Committee on Rules and the chair of the Com-mittee on House Administration.’’.

(d) D

‘‘(1) the chair of the Committee on the Judiciary 
shall, in the case of such a memorial presented in the One Hundred Fourteenth Congress or succeeding Con-gresses, and may, in the case of such a memorial pre-sented prior to the One Hundred Fourteenth Congress, designate any such memorial for public availability by the Clerk; and 
‘‘(2) the Clerk shall make such memorials as are 
designated pursuant to subparagraph (1) publicly avail-able in electronic form, organized by State of origin and year of receipt, and shall indicate whether the memorial was designated as an application or a rescission.’’. 
(2) N

(3) D
ISTRICT WORK PERIODS .—In rule I, add at

XXIII—

and Nationality Act to provide that aliens who have been convicted of or who have committed sex offenses or do-mestic violence are inadmissible and deportable.

(5) The bill (H.R. 32) to provide that sanctuary ju-
risdictions that provide benefits to aliens who are present in the United States without lawful status under the immigration laws are ineligible for Federal funds in-tended to benefit such aliens. 
(6) The bill (H.R. 35) to impose criminal and immi-
gration penalties for intentionally fleeing a pursuing Federal officer while operating a motor vehicle. 
(7) The bill (H.R. 21) to amend title 18, United 
States Code, to prohibit a health care practitioner from failing to exercise the proper degree of care in the case of a child who survives an abortion or attempted abor-tion. 
(8) The bill (H.R. 23) to impose sanctions with re-

(9) The bill (H.R. 33) to amend the Internal Rev-

(12) The bill (H.R. 26) to prohibit a moratorium on

metadata.event_name: Adopting the Rules of the House of Representatives for the One Hundred Nineteenth Congress, and for other purposes.

event_name: To inform the Senate that a quorum of the House has assembled and of the election of the Speaker and the Clerk.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, the House of Representatives confirmed a quorum and elected Mike Johnson as Speaker and Kevin McCumber as Clerk for the 119th Congress. The Senate was informed of these appointments, marking a significant organizational step for the new legislative session.
body:
H. Res. 2 
In the House of Representatives, U. S., 
January 3, 2025. 
Resolved, That the Senate be informed that a quorum of 
the House of Representatives has assembled; that Mike John-son, a Representative from the State of Louisiana, has been elected Speaker; and that Kevin McCumber, a citizen of the State of Illinois, has been elected Clerk of the House of Rep-resentatives of the One Hundred Nineteenth Congress. 
Attest: 
Clerk.

metadata.event_name: To inform the Senate that a quorum of the House has assembled and of the election of the Speaker and the Clerk.

event_name: Electing officers of the House of Representatives.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, the House of Representatives elected new officers: Kevin McCumber as Clerk, William McFarland as Sergeant-at-Arms, and Catherine Szpindor as Chief Administrative Officer. The motion to reconsider was laid on the table and agreed to without objection, signaling smooth approval of the appointments.
body:
H. Res. 1 
In the House of Representatives, U. S., 
January 3, 2025. 
Resolved, That Kevin McCumber of the State of Illinois 
be, and is hereby, chosen Clerk of the House of Representa-tives. 
Resolved, That William McFarland of the State of Mary-
land be, and is hereby, chosen Sergeant-at-Arms of the House of Representatives. 
Resolved, That Catherine Szpindor of the Commonwealth 
of Virginia be, and is hereby, chosen Chief Administrative Of-ficer of the House of Representatives. 
Attest: 
Clerk.

metadata.event_name: Electing officers of the House of Representatives.

event_name: To direct the Secretary of Homeland Security to relocate to the State of Texas the headquarters of U.S. Customs and Border Protection, and for other purposes.
blurb: The proposed legislation directs the Secretary of Homeland Security to relocate the U.S. Customs and Border Protection headquarters to Texas. Currently referred to the Subcommittee on Oversight, Investigations, and Accountability, this move aims to enhance border security operations. Stakeholders should monitor the bill's progress for potential impacts on resource allocation and regional security strategies.

metadata.event_name: To direct the Secretary of Homeland Security to relocate to the State of Texas the headquarters of U.S. Customs and Border Protection, and for other purposes.

event_name: To immediately resume construction of the border wall system along the international border between the United States and Mexico to secure the border, enforce the rule of law, and expend appropriated funds as mandated by Congress, and for other purposes.
blurb: The proposal to resume construction of the U.S.-Mexico border wall has been referred to the Subcommittee on Border Security and Enforcement. This initiative aims to enhance border security and enforce laws using appropriated funds. Stakeholders should monitor developments closely for potential impacts on immigration policy and funding allocation.

metadata.event_name: To immediately resume construction of the border wall system along the international border between the United States and Mexico to secure the border, enforce the rule of law, and expend appropriated funds as mandated by Congress, and for other purposes.

event_name: Travel Mask Mandate Repeal Act of 2025
blurb: The Travel Mask Mandate Repeal Act of 2025 (H.R. 81) aims to prohibit federal mask mandates on public transportation. Introduced by Mr. Biggs and Mr. Clyde, the bill is currently under review by multiple committees. If enacted, it would nullify existing CDC mask requirements and related orders, impacting travel regulations nationwide. Stakeholders should monitor its progress for potential changes to transportation policies.

event_name: Fentanyl is a WMD Act
blurb: The "Fentanyl is a WMD Act" (H.R. 128), introduced by Ms. Boebert, mandates the Department of Homeland Security to classify illicit fentanyl as a weapon of mass destruction. This bill, referred to the Committee on Homeland Security, aims to enhance federal response to the fentanyl crisis. Key takeaway: This classification may lead to increased resources and urgency in combating fentanyl trafficking and abuse.

event_name: Fund and Complete the Border Wall Act
blurb: The "Fund and Complete the Border Wall Act" (H.R. 76) aims to establish the "Secure the Southern Border Fund" for border security, requiring Treasury to set up an account within 60 days. The bill allows appropriations for barrier construction and U.S. Border Patrol equipment, while imposing fees on remittance transfers to fund border security initiatives. It emphasizes accountability by mandating annual reports on illegal crossings and outlines penalties for non-compliance.

event_name: Proposing a Federal debt limit amendment to the Constitution of the United States.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, Mr. Yakym introduced H.R. 37, proposing a constitutional amendment to limit federal debt to 130% of GDP, reducing to 120% over time. The amendment requires a three-fifths Congressional vote for exceeding limits, with exemptions for defense spending during war. The bill is currently referred to the House Judiciary Committee for consideration.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 37 
Proposing a Federal debt limit amendment to the Constitution of the United 
States. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. Y AKYM introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee 
on the Judiciary 
A BILL 
Proposing a Federal debt limit amendment to the 
Constitution of the United States. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
That the following article is proposed as an amendment 3
to the Constitution of the United States, which shall be 4
valid to all intents and purposes as part of the Constitu-5
tion when ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of 6
the several States within 7 years after the date of its sub-7
mission for ratification: 8

2 
•HR 37 IH‘‘ARTICLE — 1
‘‘SECTION 1. Total amount of debt, including debt 2
held by the public and intragovernmental debt, of the 3
United States Government may not be greater than 130 4
percent of the Gross Domestic Product of the United 5
States during the first fiscal year this article is in effect. 6
Each subsequent fiscal year the limitation in the previous 7
sentence shall be reduced by 1 percent until such limita-8
tion is equal to 120 percent, which shall then be the limita-9
tion for purposes of this section for each subsequent fiscal 10
year. 11
‘‘SECTION 2. Total Federal debt, including debt held 12
by the public and intragovernmental debt, may not exceed 13
the levels prescribed under section 1 unless three-fifths of 14
the whole number of each House of Congress shall provide 15
by law for a specific excess of such debt for specified rea-16
sons by a rollcall vote each fiscal year. 17
‘‘SECTION 3. Prior to each fiscal year, the President 18
shall transmit to the Congress a proposed budget for the 19
United States Government for that fiscal year, and the 20
subsequent 5-year period, in which total debt does not ex-21
ceed the limit set forth in section 1. 22
‘‘SECTION 4. The Congress may waive the provisions 23
of this article in connection with defense spending for any 24
fiscal year in which a declaration of war is in effect. The 25

3 
•HR 37 IHprovisions of this article may be waived for any fiscal year 1
in which the United States is directly engaged in military 2
conflict which causes an imminent and serious military 3
threat to national security and is so declared by a joint 4
resolution, adopted by a majority of the whole number of 5
each House, which becomes law. Any such waiver must 6
identify and be limited to the specific excess or increase 7
for that fiscal year made necessary by the identified mili-8
tary conflict. 9
‘‘SECTION 5. The Congress shall implement and en- 10
force this article by appropriate legislation, which may rely 11
on estimates of outlays and receipts. 12
‘‘SECTION 6. For purposes of this article, Gross Do- 13
mestic Product shall be the sum of personal consumption 14
expenditures, investment, government spending, and net 15
exports, and shall be determined by the Bureau of Eco-16
nomic Analysis or any successor agency. 17
‘‘SECTION 7. This article shall take effect beginning 18
with the third fiscal year beginning after its ratification.’’. 19

event_name: TEAM Veteran Caregivers Act
blurb: The TEAM Veteran Caregivers Act (H.R. 109) aims to formally recognize veteran caregivers, enhance communication about eligibility determinations, and extend benefits for veterans deemed ineligible for caregiver programs. Introduced by Mr. Biggs and referred to the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs, the bill emphasizes transparency and support for caregivers. Key provisions include official caregiver recognition and a 90-day benefits extension post-ineligibility notification.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 109 
To require the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to formally recognize caregivers 
of veterans, notify veterans and caregivers of clinical determinations relating to eligibility for caregiver programs, and temporarily extend benefits for veterans who are determined ineligible for the family care-giver program, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Veterans’ Affairs 
A BILL 
To require the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to formally 
recognize caregivers of veterans, notify veterans and caregivers of clinical determinations relating to eligibility for caregiver programs, and temporarily extend benefits for veterans who are determined ineligible for the family caregiver program, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Transparency and Ef- 4
fective Accountability Measures for Veteran Caregivers 5
Act’’ or the ‘‘TEAM Veteran Caregivers Act’’. 6

event_name: To prohibit the use of Federal funds for congressional earmarks targeted to a State or unit of local government that is a sanctuary jurisdiction.
blurb: The bill to ban Federal funding for congressional earmarks to sanctuary jurisdictions has been referred to the Committee on the Judiciary and the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform. Key actions will be determined by the Speaker. This legislation aims to restrict financial support to states or localities that do not enforce federal immigration laws.

event_name: Alaska Native Settlement Trust Eligibility Act
blurb: The Alaska Native Settlement Trust Eligibility Act (H.R. 42) aims to amend the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act by excluding specific payments to aged, blind, or disabled Alaska Natives from eligibility determinations for certain programs. Introduced by Mr. Begich on January 3, 2025, the bill is currently with the House Committee on Natural Resources. This legislation seeks to enhance financial support for vulnerable Alaska Native populations.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 42 
To amend the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to exclude certain pay-
ments to aged, blind, or disabled Alaska Natives or descendants of Alaska Natives from being used to determine eligibility for certain pro-grams, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B EGICH introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Natural Resources 
A BILL 
To amend the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to ex-
clude certain payments to aged, blind, or disabled Alaska Natives or descendants of Alaska Natives from being used to determine eligibility for certain programs, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Alaska Native Settle- 4
ment Trust Eligibility Act’’. 5

matter following paragraph (3), by striking subparagraph 4
(E) and inserting the following: 5
‘‘(E) an interest in a Settlement Trust and, for 6
the 5-year period beginning on the date of the enact- 7
ment of the Alaska Native Settlement Trust Eligi- 8
bility Act, an amount distributed from or benefit 9
provided by a Settlement Trust to a Native or de- 10
scendant of a Native who is an aged, blind, or dis- 11
abled individual (as defined in section 1614(a) of the 12
Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1382c(a))).’’. 13

event_name: Alaska Native Village Municipal Lands Restoration Act of 2025
blurb: The Alaska Native Village Municipal Lands Restoration Act of 2025 (H.R. 43) aims to amend the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act, ensuring Village Corporations are not obligated to convey land in trust to the State for Municipal Corporations. Introduced by Mr. Begich, the bill is currently with the House Committee on Natural Resources. Key takeaway: It seeks to protect Village Corporations' land rights.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 43 
To amend the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to provide that Village 
Corporations shall not be required to convey land in trust to the State of Alaska for the establishment of Municipal Corporations, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B EGICH introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Natural Resources 
A BILL 
To amend the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to pro-

event_name: To provide for the recognition of certain Alaska Native communities and the settlement of certain claims under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act, and for other purposes.
blurb: The bill aims to recognize specific Alaska Native communities and address claims under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. It has been referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources for further consideration. Stakeholders should monitor developments for potential impacts on community rights and claims settlements.

metadata.event_name: To provide for the recognition of certain Alaska Native communities and the settlement of certain claims under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act, and for other purposes.

event_name: Veteran Overmedication and Suicide Prevention Act of 2025
blurb: The Veteran Overmedication and Suicide Prevention Act of 2025, introduced by Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Connolly, mandates an independent review of veteran suicides over the past five years by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The review will analyze medication usage, demographics, and treatment effectiveness, aiming to enhance veteran safety and care. The bill is currently with the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs.

event_name: Federal Reserve Transparency Act of 2025
blurb: The Federal Reserve Transparency Act of 2025 mandates a full audit of the Federal Reserve System by the Comptroller General within 12 months of enactment. A report detailing findings and recommendations is required within 90 days post-audit. The bill, introduced by Mr. Massie and others, aims to enhance accountability and transparency in the Federal Reserve's operations.
body:

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 24 
To require a full audit of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve 
System and the Federal reserve banks by the Comptroller General of the United States, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. M ASSIE (for himself, Mr. B IGGS of Arizona, Ms. B OEBERT , Mr. B OST,

MACE, Mr. M CCLINTOCK , Mr. M CCORMICK , Mrs. M ILLER of Illinois, Mr. 
MOOLENAAR , Mr. M OORE of Alabama, Mr. N ORMAN , Mr. O GLES , Mr. 
PALMER , Mr. P ERRY , Mr. R OY, Mr. R UTHERFORD , Mrs. S PARTZ , Mr. 
STEUBE , Ms. T ENNEY , Mr. W EBER of Texas, and Mr. W EBSTER of Flor-

A BILL

Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

event_name: CLEAN Elections Act
blurb: The CLEAN Elections Act (H.R. 158), introduced by Mr. Fitzpatrick, mandates independent nonpartisan commissions for congressional redistricting. The bill aims to enhance electoral fairness by ensuring states conduct redistricting without partisan influence. It is currently under review by the House Judiciary Committee. States must certify compliance to receive federal election funds.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 158 
To require the use of independent nonpartisan commissions to carry out 
congressional redistricting. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. F ITZPATRICK introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on the Judiciary 
A BILL 
To require the use of independent nonpartisan commissions 
to carry out congressional redistricting. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Citizen Legislature 4
Anti-Corruption Reform of Elections Act’’ or the 5
‘‘CLEAN Elections Act’’. 6
SEC. 2. REQUIRING USE OF INDEPENDENT NONPARTISAN 7
COMMISSIONS TO CARRY OUT REDIS- 8
TRICTING. 9
(a) R EQUIREMENT .— 10

State shall conduct Congressional redistricting (be- 2
ginning with the redistricting carried out pursuant 3
to the decennial census conducted during 2020) in 4
accordance with a redistricting plan developed by a 5
nonpartisan independent redistricting commission. 6

DISTRICTS .—Notwithstanding any other provision of 8

tion purposes unless the State certifies to the Elec- 11
tion Assistance Commission that the State conducts 12
redistricting for State legislative districts in the 13
State (beginning with the first such redistricting 14
carried out after the date of the enactment of this 15
Act) in accordance with a redistricting plan devel- 16
oped by a nonpartisan independent redistricting 17
commission. 18
(b) N ONPARTISAN INDEPENDENT STATUS .—For 19
purposes of this section, a commission shall be considered 20
to be a nonpartisan independent commission if— 21
(1) the number of its members who are affili- 22
ated with the political party with the largest percent- 23
age of the registered voters in the State who are af- 24
filiated with a political party (as determined with re- 25

It has been referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means for review. Stakeholders should monitor the committee's progress for potential financial assistance opportunities.

event_name: To improve the ability of the Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of the Interior to carry out forest management actives that reduce the risk of catastrophic wildfires, and for other purposes.
blurb: The bill aims to enhance the Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of the Interior's capacity to manage forests, reducing catastrophic wildfire risks. It has been referred to the Committees on Agriculture and Natural Resources for review. Key action: stakeholders should monitor committee discussions for potential impacts on forest management practices.

event_name: SEND THEM BACK Act of 2025
blurb: The SEND THEM BACK Act of 2025, introduced by Mr. Ogles and others, aims to expedite the removal of certain illegal aliens who entered the U.S. since January 20, 2021. The bill excludes current U.S. Armed Forces members. It is currently referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary for consideration.

event_name: To amend title 39, United States Code, to enhance the administrative subpoena authority of the United States Postal Service, and for other purposes.
blurb: The proposed amendment to Title 39, U.S. Code, aims to strengthen the administrative subpoena authority of the United States Postal Service. Currently referred to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, this legislation could enhance USPS's ability to investigate and enforce compliance. Stakeholders should monitor developments for potential implications on postal operations and oversight.

event_name: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to classify certain automatic fire sprinkler system retrofits as 15-year property for purposes of depreciation.
blurb: The proposed amendment to the Internal Revenue Code seeks to classify automatic fire sprinkler system retrofits as 15-year property for depreciation purposes. This change aims to incentivize safety upgrades in buildings. The bill is currently referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means for review.

event_name: Rural Broadband Window of Opportunity Act
blurb: The Rural Broadband Window of Opportunity Act aims to expedite the processing of long-form applications in the Rural Digital Opportunity Fund Phase II auction. Introduced by Mr. Bergman and referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, the bill prioritizes applications in regions with short construction seasons, enhancing broadband access in underserved areas.
body:

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 46 
To direct the Federal Communications Commission to prioritize the timely 
processing of certain long-form applications in the Rural Digital Oppor-tunity Fund Phase II auction. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B ERGMAN introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Energy and Commerce 
A BILL 
To direct the Federal Communications Commission to 
prioritize the timely processing of certain long-form ap-plications in the Rural Digital Opportunity Fund Phase II auction. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Rural Broadband Win- 4
dow of Opportunity Act’’. 5
SEC. 2. PURPOSE. 6
The purpose of this Act is to level the playing field 7
for service providers participating in the Rural Digital Op-8

•HR 46 IHportunity Fund that are disadvantaged by short construc-1
tion seasons. 2

With respect to the long-form applicants of the Rural 4
Digital Opportunity Fund Phase II auction provided for 5
in the Report and Order in the matter of Rural Digital 6
Opportunity Fund and Connect America Fund adopted by 7
the Federal Communications Commission (in this section 8
referred to as the ‘‘Commission’’) on January 30, 2020 9
(FCC 20–5), the Commission shall prioritize the timely 10
processing of long-form applications and any subsequent 11
paperwork (in this section referred to as the ‘‘applica-12
tions’’) submitted by the long-form applicants as follows: 13
The Commission shall prioritize the timely processing of 14
applications which are proposing to provide service in geo-15
graphic areas which the Commission determines to have 16
the shortest construction seasons (such as in areas charac-17
terized by long winters with heavy snowfall). 18

event_name: VOICE Restoration Act
blurb: The VOICE Restoration Act, introduced by Mr. Bergman, aims to re-establish the Victims of Immigration Crime Engagement Office within the Department of Homeland Security. This office will assist victims of crimes committed by undocumented immigrants, providing resources, support, and a dedicated hotline. The bill has been referred to the House Judiciary Committee for further consideration.
body:

(1) In April 2017, the United States Depart- 9

Currently referred to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, this measure underscores the government's stance against such facilities, potentially impacting funding for related programs.

event_name: Constitutional Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act
blurb: The Constitutional Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act (H.R. 38) aims to allow non-residents to carry concealed firearms in states where residents can do so. Introduced on January 3, 2025, it has been referred to the House Judiciary Committee. Key provisions include requiring valid identification and permits, with protections against unlawful detention. The bill's amendments would take effect 90 days post-enactment.
body:

event_name: Sunshine Protection Act of 2025
blurb: The Sunshine Protection Act of 2025, introduced by Mr. Buchanan, aims to make daylight savings time permanent by repealing the temporary period outlined in the Uniform Time Act of 1966. Currently referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, this legislation allows states to opt-out of the new standard time. Key takeaway: potential permanent shift in timekeeping practices.

event_name: To provide for the admission of the State of Washington, D.C. into the Union.
blurb: The bill to admit Washington, D.C. as a state has been referred to multiple committees, including Oversight and Government Reform, Rules, Armed Services, Judiciary, and Energy and Commerce. Each committee will review relevant provisions, with timelines to be set by the Speaker. Key takeaway: This marks a significant step toward D.C. statehood.

event_name: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to limit the number of terms an individual may serve as a Member of Congress.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, H.J. Res. 5 was introduced to propose a constitutional amendment limiting Congressional terms: six two-year terms for Representatives and two six-year terms for Senators. The resolution is currently referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary. If ratified by three-fourths of states within seven years, it aims to enhance political turnover and accountability.
body:
IA 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. J. RES. 5 
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to limit 
the number of terms an individual may serve as a Member of Congress. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. F ITZPATRICK (for himself and Mr. K HANNA ) submitted the following joint 
resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary 
JOINT RESOLUTION 
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United 
States to limit the number of terms an individual may serve as a Member of Congress. 
Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives 1
of the United States of America in Congress assembled2
(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol- 3
lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con-4
stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all 5
intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when 6
ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several 7
States within seven years after the date of its submission 8
for ratification: 9
VerDate Sep 11 2014 22:14 Jan 04, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\HJ5.IH HJ5kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
2 
•HJ 5 IH ‘‘ARTICLE — 1
‘‘SECTION 1. No person shall serve as a Representa- 2
tive for more than six two-year terms. Service as a Rep-3
resentative for more than one year of any two-year term 4
shall be treated as a complete term for purposes of this 5
section, without regard to whether the service was com-6
pleted by the individual originally elected to the term. 7
‘‘SECTION 2. No person shall serve as a Senator for 8
more than two six-year terms. Service as a Senator for 9
more than three years of any six-year term shall be treated 10
as a complete term for purposes of this section, without 11
regard to whether the service was completed by the indi-12
vidual originally elected to the term. 13
‘‘SECTION 3. This article shall not apply to any per- 14
son who served as a Representative or as a Senator during 15
any Congress occurring before the One Hundred Eight-16
eenth Congress.’’. 17
Æ

event_name: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relative to balancing the budget.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, Rep. Buchanan introduced H.J. Res. 3, proposing a constitutional amendment to require a balanced federal budget. Key provisions include limits on outlays relative to receipts and GDP, with exceptions requiring supermajority votes in Congress. The resolution is currently referred to the House Judiciary Committee for consideration. Ratification would require approval from three-fourths of state legislatures.
body:
IA 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. J. RES. 3 
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relative 
to balancing the budget. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B UCHANAN submitted the following joint resolution; which was referred 
to the Committee on the Judiciary 
JOINT RESOLUTION 
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United 
States relative to balancing the budget. 
Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives 1
of the United States of America in Congress assembled2
(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol- 3
lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con-4
stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all 5
intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when 6
ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several 7
States: 8
VerDate Sep 11 2014 22:13 Jan 04, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\HJ3.IH HJ3kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
2 
•HJ 3 IH ‘‘ARTICLE — 1
‘‘SECTION 1. Total outlays for any fiscal year shall 2
not exceed total receipts for that fiscal year, unless two- 3
thirds of the duly chosen and sworn Members of each 4
House of Congress shall provide by law for a specific ex-5
cess of outlays over receipts by a rollcall vote. 6
‘‘SECTION 2. Total outlays for any fiscal year shall 7
not exceed 18 percent of the gross domestic product of 8
the United States for the calendar year ending before the 9
beginning of such fiscal year, unless two-thirds of the duly 10
chosen and sworn Members of each House of Congress 11
shall provide by law for a specific amount in excess of such 12
18 percent by a rollcall vote. 13
‘‘SECTION 3. Prior to each fiscal year, the President 14
shall transmit to the Congress a proposed budget for the 15
United States Government for that fiscal year in which— 16
‘‘(1) total outlays do not exceed total receipts; 17
and 18
‘‘(2) total outlays do not exceed 18 percent of 19
the gross domestic product of the United States for 20
the calendar year ending before the beginning of 21
such fiscal year. 22
‘‘SECTION 4. Any bill that imposes a new tax or in- 23
creases the statutory rate of any tax or the aggregate 24
amount of revenue may pass only by a two-thirds majority 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 22:13 Jan 04, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\HJ3.IH HJ3kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
3 
•HJ 3 IH of the duly chosen and sworn Members of each House of 1
Congress by a rollcall vote. For the purpose of determining 2
any increase in revenue under this section, there shall be 3
excluded any increase resulting from the lowering of the 4
statutory rate of any tax. 5
‘‘SECTION 5. The limit on the debt of the United 6
States shall not be increased, unless three-fifths of the 7
duly chosen and sworn Members of each House of Con-8
gress shall provide for such an increase by a rollcall vote. 9
‘‘SECTION 6. The Congress may waive the provisions 10
of sections 1, 2, 3, and 5 of this article for any fiscal year 11
in which a declaration of war against a nation-state is in 12
effect and in which a majority of the duly chosen and 13
sworn Members of each House of Congress shall provide 14
for a specific excess by a rollcall vote. 15
‘‘SECTION 7. The Congress may waive the provisions 16
of sections 1, 2, 3, and 5 of this article in any fiscal year 17
in which the United States is engaged in a military conflict 18
that causes an imminent and serious military threat to 19
national security and is so declared by three-fifths of the 20
duly chosen and sworn Members of each House of Con-21
gress by a rollcall vote. Such suspension must identify and 22
be limited to the specific excess of outlays for that fiscal 23
year made necessary by the identified military conflict. 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 22:13 Jan 04, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\HJ3.IH HJ3kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
4 
•HJ 3 IH ‘‘SECTION 8. No court of the United States or of any 1
State shall order any increase in revenue to enforce this 2
article. 3
‘‘SECTION 9. Total receipts shall include all receipts 4
of the United States Government except those derived 5
from borrowing. Total outlays shall include all outlays of 6
the United States Government except those for repayment 7
of debt principal. 8
‘‘SECTION 10. The Congress shall have power to en- 9
force and implement this article by appropriate legislation, 10
which may rely on estimates of outlays, receipts, and gross 11
domestic product. 12
‘‘SECTION 11. This article shall take effect beginning 13
with the fifth fiscal year beginning after its ratification.’’. 14
Æ

event_name: Protecting our Communities from Sexual Predators Act
blurb: The "Protecting our Communities from Sexual Predators Act" aims to amend the Immigration and Nationality Act to enhance the detention, inadmissibility, and removal of aliens convicted of sexual assault. Introduced by Mr. Buchanan and others on January 3, 2025, the bill is currently with the House Judiciary Committee. Key takeaways include stricter immigration consequences for sexual assault offenses.

UAL ASSAULT. 7

event_name: Lowering Costs for Caregivers Act of 2025
blurb: The Lowering Costs for Caregivers Act of 2025 (H.R. 138) aims to amend the Internal Revenue Code to include parental care expenses as medical expenses. Introduced by Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Thompson, the bill is currently with the House Committee on Ways and Means. Key provisions take effect after December 31, 2024, enhancing health savings accounts and flexible spending arrangements for caregiver costs.

to be taken into account as medical expenses, and for other purposes.

following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means 
A BILL 
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to allow ex-
penses for parents to be taken into account as medical expenses, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

Caregivers Act of 2025’’. 5

(a) I NGENERAL .—Subparagraph (A) of section 7
223(d)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amend-8
ed by inserting ‘‘, any parent of either such individual or 9
such spouse’’ after ‘‘the spouse of such individual’’. 10

event_name: Election Day Act
blurb: The Election Day Act, introduced by Mr. Fitzpatrick and Mrs. Dingell, proposes to establish Election Day as a federal holiday. The bill is currently under review by the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform. If enacted, this legislation aims to enhance voter participation by ensuring citizens have the day off to vote.

event_name: Rural 340B Access Act of 2025
blurb: The Rural 340B Access Act of 2025 (H.R. 44) aims to include rural emergency hospitals in the 340B drug discount program. Introduced by Mr. Bergman and Mrs. Dingell on January 3, 2025, the bill is currently with the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. This change could enhance access to affordable medications for low-income individuals in rural areas.

event_name: Manatee Protection Act of 2025
blurb: The Manatee Protection Act of 2025 (H.R. 135) aims to designate the West Indian manatee as an endangered species under the Endangered Species Act. Introduced by Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Frost, the bill is currently referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources. Key takeaway: This legislation seeks enhanced protections for the West Indian manatee, emphasizing conservation efforts.

JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B UCHANAN (for himself and Mr. F ROST ) introduced the following bill; 
which was referred to the Committee on Natural Resources

event_name: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to make permanent certain provisions of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act affecting individuals, families, and small businesses, and for other purposes.
blurb: The proposed amendment to the Internal Revenue Code aims to permanently extend key provisions of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act that benefit individuals, families, and small businesses. Currently under review by the House Committee on Ways and Means, this legislation could significantly impact tax rates and deductions. Stakeholders should monitor its progress for potential changes in tax policy.

metadata.event_name: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to make permanent certain provisions of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act affecting individuals, families, and small businesses, and for other purposes.

event_name: Protecting American Energy Production Act
blurb: The Protecting American Energy Production Act (H.R. 133) aims to prohibit presidential moratoriums on hydraulic fracturing without Congressional approval. Introduced by Ms. Boebert on January 3, 2025, the bill emphasizes state regulation of hydraulic fracturing on state and private lands. It is currently under review by the Committees on Natural Resources and Energy and Commerce.

mittee on Natural Resources, and in addition to the Committee on En-ergy and Commerce, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

To prohibit a moratorium on the use of hydraulic fracturing. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

Energy Production Act’’. 5

(a) S ENSE OF CONGRESS .—It is the sense of Con- 7
gress that States should maintain primacy for the regula-8

tion on State and private lands. 10

event_name: Western Water Accelerated Revenue Repayment Act
blurb: The Western Water Accelerated Revenue Repayment Act, introduced by Ms. Boebert, aims to amend the Water Infrastructure Improvements for the Nation Act, extending contract prepayment authority. The bill is currently referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources. This legislation could enhance funding flexibility for water infrastructure projects.

event_name: To direct the Secretary concerned to coordinate with impacted parties when conducting a forest management activity, and for other purposes.
blurb: The bill directs the Secretary to coordinate with affected parties during forest management activities. It has been referred to the Committees on Agriculture and Natural Resources for review. Stakeholders should monitor developments for potential impacts on forest management practices.

event_name: To amend the Act of December 19, 1913 (38 Stat. 242), to expand access to the Hetch Hetchy Reservoir and Lake Eleanor Basin areas for recreational purposes, and for other purposes.
blurb: The proposed amendment aims to enhance recreational access to the Hetch Hetchy Reservoir and Lake Eleanor Basin. Currently referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources, stakeholders are encouraged to engage with the committee to support expanded public access and recreational opportunities in these areas.

event_name: MEGOBARI Act
blurb: The MEGOBARI Act aims to counter the influence of the Chinese Communist Party, Iranian regime, and Russian Federation in Georgia. Introduced on January 3, 2025, it emphasizes U.S. support for Georgian democracy and Euro-Atlantic integration. The bill mandates reports on Russian intelligence and proposes sanctions against officials undermining these goals. Key actions include suspending U.S.-Georgia partnerships until democratic reforms are made. The Act is set to sunset in five years.

metadata.event_name: MEGOBARI Act

event_name: To require the Secretary of Agriculture to carry out activities to suppress wildfires, and for other purposes.
blurb: The bill mandates the Secretary of Agriculture to implement wildfire suppression activities. It has been referred to the Committees on Agriculture and Natural Resources for review. Key takeaway: This initiative aims to enhance wildfire management and prevention efforts.

metadata.event_name: To require the Secretary of Agriculture to carry out activities to suppress wildfires, and for other purposes.

event_name: To amend the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to require publication on the internet of the basis for determinations that species are endangered species or threatened species, and for other purposes.
blurb: The proposed amendment to the Endangered Species Act of 1973 mandates online publication of the rationale behind determinations of species status as endangered or threatened. This aims to enhance transparency and public access to information. The bill is currently under review by the House Committee on Natural Resources.

metadata.event_name: To amend the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to require publication on the internet of the basis for determinations that species are endangered species or threatened species, and for other purposes.

event_name: To amend the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to provide that artificially propagated animals shall be treated the same under that Act as naturally propagated animals, and for other purposes.
blurb: A bill has been introduced to amend the Endangered Species Act of 1973, ensuring artificially propagated animals receive the same protections as naturally propagated ones. It is currently referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources for further consideration. Key takeaway: This amendment could enhance conservation efforts for both types of species.

metadata.event_name: To amend the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to provide that artificially propagated animals shall be treated the same under that Act as naturally propagated animals, and for other purposes.

event_name: Action Versus No Action Act
blurb: The "Action Versus No Action Act" (H.R. 184) mandates that only two alternatives—proposed forest management activities or no action—be analyzed in environmental assessments. Introduced by Mr. McClintock on January 3, 2025, the bill is currently under consideration by the Committees on Natural Resources and Agriculture. This legislation aims to streamline decision-making in collaborative forest management, impacting timber production and wildfire risk assessments.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 184 
To require that only two alternatives be considered with respect to certain 
proposed collaborative forest management activities, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. M CCLINTOCK introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Natural Resources, and in addition to the Committee on Agriculture, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the juris-diction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To require that only two alternatives be considered with 
respect to certain proposed collaborative forest manage-ment activities, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Action Versus No Ac- 4
tion Act’’. 5

event_name: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide certain line item veto authority to the President.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, H.J. Res. 8 was introduced to grant the President line item veto authority. This proposed constitutional amendment allows the President to reduce appropriations in bills, with Congress having the option to disapprove such reductions within 10 days. The resolution is currently referred to the House Judiciary Committee for consideration.
body:
IA 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. J. RES. 8 
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide 
certain line item veto authority to the President. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. M CCLINTOCK (for himself and Mr. W EBER of Texas) submitted the fol-
lowing joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judi-ciary 
JOINT RESOLUTION 
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United 
States to provide certain line item veto authority to the President. 
Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives 1
of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two- 2
thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol- 3
lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con-4
stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all 5
intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when 6
ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several 7
States within seven years after the date of its submission 8
for ratification: 9

come law with such reduction incorporated. 6
‘‘SECTION 2. If the President reduces an appropria- 7
tion under section 1 of this article— 8
‘‘(1) not later than 10 days after the date of 9
such reduction, the President shall notify the House 10

‘‘(2) the House of Representatives and the Sen- 12
ate may consider disapproval of such reduction; and 13
‘‘(3) if two-thirds of each House votes to dis- 14
approve of such reduction, the amount of the appro- 15
priation in law subject to such reduction shall be 16
treated as returned to the amount originally pre- 17
sented to the President under section 1.’’. 18

event_name: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States prohibiting the United States Government from increasing its debt except for a specific purpose by law adopted by three-fourths of the membership of each House of Congress.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, H.J. Res. 9 was introduced to propose a constitutional amendment restricting U.S. government debt increases unless specifically authorized by a law passed by three-fourths of Congress. The resolution is currently under review by the House Judiciary Committee. If ratified by three-fourths of state legislatures, the amendment would take effect ten years post-ratification.

event_name: To amend the Immigration and Nationality Act with respect to aliens who carried out, participated in, planned, financed, supported, or otherwise facilitated the attacks against Israel.
blurb: A bill to amend the Immigration and Nationality Act targeting aliens involved in attacks against Israel has been introduced and referred to the House Judiciary Committee. Key takeaways include potential immigration restrictions for those implicated in such acts. Further committee discussions are anticipated.

event_name: Law Enforcement Officer Recreation Pass Act
blurb: The Law Enforcement Officer Recreation Pass Act (H.R. 183) proposes a lifetime National Recreational Pass for law enforcement officers, amending the Federal Lands Recreation Enhancement Act. Introduced by Mr. McClintock on January 3, 2025, the bill is under review by the Committees on Natural Resources and Agriculture. This pass aims to recognize and support law enforcement personnel by granting them free access to national parks and federal recreational lands.

a lifetime National Recreational Pass for law enforcement officers. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

Committee on Natural Resources, and in addition to the Committee on Agriculture, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the juris-diction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To amend the Federal Lands Recreation Enhancement Act 
to provide for a lifetime National Recreational Pass for law enforcement officers. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Law Enforcement Offi- 4
cer Recreation Pass Act’’. 5

event_name: Default Prevention Act
blurb: The Default Prevention Act (H.R. 182), introduced by Mr. McClintock, aims to ensure timely payment of U.S. debt obligations. Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means, it establishes a tiered payment system for obligations and mandates weekly reporting on payments. Key takeaway: This legislation seeks to prevent default by prioritizing debt service amid potential borrowing limits.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 182 
To ensure the payment of interest and principal of the debt of the United 
States. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. M CCLINTOCK introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Ways and Means 
A BILL 
To ensure the payment of interest and principal of the debt 
of the United States. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1

metadata.event_name: Default Prevention Act

event_name: To amend the Immigration and Nationality Act to provide that aliens who have been convicted of or who have committed Social Security fraud are inadmissible and deportable.
blurb: The proposed amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act aims to make aliens convicted of Social Security fraud inadmissible and deportable. Currently referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary, this legislation emphasizes stricter immigration controls related to financial crimes. Key takeaway: potential impact on immigration status for those involved in Social Security fraud.

metadata.event_name: To amend the Immigration and Nationality Act to provide that aliens who have been convicted of or who have committed Social Security fraud are inadmissible and deportable.

event_name: Deport Alien Gang Members Act
blurb: The "Deport Alien Gang Members Act" (H.R. 175) aims to amend the Immigration and Nationality Act to enhance the deportation of aliens associated with criminal gangs. Introduced on January 3, 2025, by Rep. McClintock and others, the bill is currently with the House Judiciary Committee. Key provisions include defining gang membership, establishing grounds for inadmissibility, and mandating annual reports on detentions related to gang affiliations.

event_name: Commission to Relocate the Federal Bureaucracy Act
blurb: The "Commission to Relocate the Federal Bureaucracy Act" (H.R. 202) aims to establish a commission to study relocating certain federal agencies outside the Washington, D.C. area. Introduced by Ms. Tenney on January 3, 2025, the bill is currently with the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform. A report is due within one year, focusing on financial efficiency and infrastructure suitability for relocation.
body:

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Ms. T ENNEY introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Oversight and Government Reform 
A BILL 
To establish a commission to study the relocation of certain 
agencies outside of the Washington, D.C. metropolitan area, and for other purposes.

meaning given the term in section 551 of title 5, 9
United States Code. 10

event_name: Finish the Arkansas Valley Conduit Act
blurb: The "Finish the Arkansas Valley Conduit Act" (H.R. 131), introduced by Ms. Boebert, aims to modify repayment terms for the Arkansas Valley Conduit in Colorado, eliminating interest and extending repayment to 100 years. Currently referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources, this legislation seeks to facilitate funding during construction. Stakeholders should monitor its progress for potential impacts on local water infrastructure financing.

event_name: Trust the Science Act
blurb: The "Trust the Science Act" (H.R. 130) was introduced by Ms. Boebert and referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources. This bill mandates the Secretary of the Interior to reissue regulations to remove the gray wolf from the endangered species list within 60 days of enactment, with no judicial review allowed. Key takeaway: If passed, this legislation could significantly impact gray wolf conservation efforts.
body:

tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Trust the Science 4
Act’’. 5

event_name: Maintaining Innovation and Safe Technologies Act
blurb: The Maintaining Innovation and Safe Technologies Act (H.R. 193) directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to issue Medicare payment guidance for AI-integrated remote monitoring devices by January 1, 2027. The bill aims to enhance healthcare technology while ensuring safe and effective reimbursement processes. It has been referred to the Committees on Energy and Commerce and Ways and Means for further consideration.
body:

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 193

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. S CHWEIKERT introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Energy and Commerce, and in addition to the Committee on Ways and Means, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to 
issue guidance on payment under the Medicare program for certain items involving artificial intelligence. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Maintaining Innova- 4
tion and Safe Technologies Act’’. 5

event_name: FIND Act
blurb: The FIND Act (H.R. 45) aims to prevent the federal government from contracting with entities that discriminate against the firearm and ammunition industry. Introduced on January 3, 2025, it mandates contractors to certify non-discriminatory practices and includes penalties for violations. The bill is currently under review by the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform. Key takeaway: The act seeks to protect firearm-related businesses from discrimination in federal contracting.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 45 
To amend title 41, United States Code, to prohibit the Federal Government 
from entering into contracts with an entity that discriminates against the firearm and ammunition industry, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B ERGMAN (for himself, Mr. C RENSHAW , Mr. C RANE , Mrs. M ILLER of Illi-
nois, Mr. F INSTAD , Mr. O GLES , Ms. T ENNEY , Mr. M ESSMER , Mr. 
RESCHENTHALER , Mr. C LOUD , Mr. K ENNEDY of Utah, Mr. E STES , Mr. 
LANGWORTHY , Mr. L AMALFA , Mr. H IGGINS of Louisiana, Mr. W EBER of 
Texas, Mrs. H INSON , Mrs. H OUCHIN , Mr. K USTOFF , Mr. M OORE of Ala-
bama, Mr. M ILLER of Ohio, Mr. G UTHRIE , Mr. A LLEN , Mr. B URLISON , 
Mr. A USTIN SCOTT of Georgia, Mrs. H ARSHBARGER , Mr. A MODEI of Ne-
vada, Mr. H UIZENGA , Mr. G RAVES , Mr. F EENSTRA , Mr. J OYCE of Penn-
sylvania, Mr. M OOLENAAR , Mr. J ACKSON of Texas, Mr. C ARTER of Geor-
gia, and Mrs. F ISCHBACH ) introduced the following bill; which was re-
ferred to the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform 
A BILL 
To amend title 41, United States Code, to prohibit the Fed-
eral Government from entering into contracts with an entity that discriminates against the firearm and ammu-nition industry, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

2 
•HR 45 IHSECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 1
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Firearm Industry Non- 2
Discrimination Act’’ or the ‘‘FIND Act’’. 3
SEC. 2. PROHIBITION ON ENTERING INTO CONTRACTS 4
WITH ENTITIES DISCRIMINATING AGAINST 5
THE FIREARM AND AMMUNITION INDUSTRY. 6
(a) P ROHIBITION .—Chapter 47 of title 41, United 7
States Code, is amended by adding at the end the fol-8
lowing: 9
‘‘§ 4715. Prohibition on entering into contracts with 10
entities discriminating against the fire- 11
arm and ammunition industry. 12
‘‘(a) P ROHIBITION .— 13
‘‘(1) I N GENERAL .—The head of an executive 14
agency shall include in each contract for the pro- 15
curement of goods or services awarded by the execu- 16
tive agency, a clause requiring the prime contractor 17
to certify that the contractor— 18
‘‘(A) has no policy, practice, guidance, or 19
directive that discriminates against a firearm 20
entity or firearm trade association; and 21
‘‘(B) will not adopt a policy, practice, guid- 22
ance, or directive that discriminates against a 23
firearm entity or firearm trade association dur- 24
ing the term of the contract. 25

3 
•HR 45 IH‘‘(2) S UBCONTRACTS .—The head of an execu- 1
tive agency shall include in each contract for the 2
procurement of goods or services awarded by the ex- 3
ecutive agency, a clause that prohibits the prime 4
contractor on such contract from— 5
‘‘(A) awarding a first-tier subcontract with 6
a value greater than 10 percent of the total 7
value of the prime contract to an entity that 8
fails to certify in writing to the prime con- 9
tractor that the entity— 10
‘‘(i) has no policy, practice, guidance, 11
or directive that discriminates against a 12
firearm entity or firearm trade association; 13
and 14
‘‘(ii) will not adopt a policy, practice, 15
guidance, or directive that discriminates 16
against a firearm entity or firearm trade 17
association during the term of the con- 18
tract; and 19
‘‘(B) structuring subcontract tiers in a 20
manner designed to avoid violating subpara- 21
graph (A) by enabling a subcontractor to per- 22
form more than 10 percent of the total value of 23
the prime contract as a lower-tier subcon- 24
tractor. 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 05:21 Jan 28, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H45.IH H45kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
4 
•HR 45 IH‘‘(3) P ENALTIES .—The clause included in con- 1
tracts pursuant to paragraph (1) or paragraph (2) 2
shall provide that, in the event that the prime con- 3
tractor violates the clause— 4
‘‘(A) the prime contract shall be termi- 5
nated for default; and 6
‘‘(B) a suspension or debarment pro- 7
ceeding will be initiated for the contractor on 8
the basis of the violation. 9
‘‘(b) E XCEPTION .—Subsection (a) shall not apply to 10
a contract for the procurement of goods or services that 11
is a sole-source contract. 12
‘‘(c) D EFINITIONS .—In this section: 13
‘‘(1) D ISCRIMINATE .—The term ‘discriminate’ 14
means to— 15
‘‘(A) make a judgement about a policy, 16

Currently referred to the House Committee on Financial Services, this initiative seeks to strengthen fair housing enforcement and support equitable access to housing.

event_name: To amend the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 to authorize partnerships between States and nongovernmental entities for the purpose of reclaiming and restoring land and water resources adversely affected by coal mining activities before August 3, 1977, and for other purposes.
blurb: The proposed amendment to the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 seeks to enable partnerships between States and NGOs to reclaim land and water harmed by pre-1977 coal mining. This initiative aims to enhance environmental restoration efforts. The bill is currently under review by the House Committee on Natural Resources.

blurb: The bill authorizes grants for states and local governments to combat repeat violence. It is currently referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary for review. Key takeaway: This initiative aims to enhance funding for preventive measures against recurring violent offenses.

event_name: .Proposing a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution requiring that each agency and department's funding is justified.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, Rep. Perry and others introduced H.J. Res. 11, proposing a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution. The amendment mandates that federal agencies justify their funding, limits outlays to total receipts, and requires a three-fifths congressional majority for revenue increases. It aims to enforce fiscal responsibility and is currently referred to the House Judiciary Committee for further consideration.
body:
IA 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. J. RES. 11 
Proposing a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution requiring that 
each agency and department’s funding is justified. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. P ERRY (for himself, Mr. C LOUD , Mr. O GLES , and Mr. Z INKE ) submitted 
the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary 
JOINT RESOLUTION 
Proposing a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution 
requiring that each agency and department’s funding is justified. 
Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives 1
of the United States of America in Congress assembled2
(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol- 3
lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con-4
stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all 5
intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when 6
ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several 7
States within seven years after the date of its submission 8
for ratification: 9
