2 
•HJ 11 IH ‘‘ARTICLE — 1
‘‘SECTION 1. Total outlays for any fiscal year shall 2
not exceed total receipts for that fiscal year, unless three- 3
fifths of the whole number of each House of Congress shall 4
provide by law for a specific excess of outlays over receipts 5
by a rollcall vote, but in no event shall total outlays for 6
any fiscal year exceed the following: for the first fiscal year 7
for which this article takes effect, 20 percent of the esti-8
mated gross domestic product of the United States for 9
that year, and for each subsequent fiscal year, a percent-10
age of the estimated gross domestic product equal to the 11
applicable percentage for the preceding fiscal year reduced 12
by .1 percentage point. Under this section, total spending 13
for any fiscal year is not required to be less than 16 per-14
cent of the estimated gross domestic product of the United 15
States. 16
‘‘SECTION 2. The limit on the debt of the United 17
States held by the public shall not be increased, unless 18
three-fifths of the whole number of each House shall pro-19
vide by law for such an increase by a rollcall vote. 20
‘‘SECTION 3. Prior to each fiscal year, the President 21
shall transmit to the Congress a proposed budget for the 22
United States Government for that fiscal year in which 23
total outlays do not exceed total receipts. 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 22:16 Jan 04, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\HJ11.IH HJ11kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
3 
•HJ 11 IH ‘‘SECTION 4. No bill to increase revenue shall become 1
law unless approved by a three-fifths majority of the whole 2
number of each House by a rollcall vote. 3
‘‘SECTION 5. Any budget plan for a fiscal year for 4
the Government submitted by the President to the Con-5
gress shall include a justification by each department or 6
agency of the Government for any funding proposed for 7
that department or agency in that plan. The justification 8
shall include a justification of each line item in the budget 9
of that department or agency based upon its effect on car-10
rying out its mission and its effect, if any, on the gross 11
domestic product of the United States and an additional 12
funding level below the requested number that would allow 13
that department or agency to complete all of its critical 14
mission functions. 15
‘‘SECTION 6. Total receipts shall include all receipts 16
of the United States Government except those derived 17
from borrowing. Total outlays shall include all outlays of 18
the United States Government except for those for repay-19
ment of debt principal. 20
‘‘SECTION 7. The Congress shall enforce and imple- 21
ment this article by appropriate legislation, which may rely 22
on estimates of outlays and receipts. 23
‘‘SECTION 8. The Congress may waive the provisions 24
of this article for any fiscal year in which a declaration 25
VerDate Sep 11 2014 22:16 Jan 04, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00003 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\HJ11.IH HJ11kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
4 
•HJ 11 IH of war is in effect. The provisions of this article may be 1
waived for any fiscal year in which the United States is 2
engaged in military conflict or after any event which 3
causes an imminent and serious military threat to national 4
security and is so declared by a joint resolution or during 5
which a natural disaster is declared by a joint resolution, 6
adopted by a vote by two-thirds of each House, which be-7
comes law. 8
‘‘SECTION 9. This article shall take effect beginning 9
with the earlier of the tenth fiscal year beginning after 10
its ratification or the first fiscal year beginning after any 11
fiscal year in which the budget of the United States is 12
not in deficit.’’. 13

event_name: Judicial Administration and Improvement Act of 2025
blurb: The Judicial Administration and Improvement Act of 2025 aims to split the Ninth Circuit into two separate circuits, enhancing judicial efficiency. Introduced by Mr. Biggs and referred to the House Judiciary Committee, the bill proposes changes to circuit composition and judge assignments, set to take effect one year post-enactment. Stakeholders should monitor the bill's progress for potential impacts on judicial operations and appointments.
body:

event_name: To establish an Office of Fair Lending Testing to test for compliance with the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, to strengthen the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, to ensure that persons injured by discriminatory practices, including organizations that have diverted resources to address discrimination and whose mission has been frustrated by illegal acts, can seek relief under such Act and to provide for criminal penalties for violating such Act, and for other purposes.
blurb: The proposed legislation aims to establish an Office of Fair Lending Testing to enforce compliance with the Equal Credit Opportunity Act. It seeks to strengthen protections against discrimination, allow affected individuals and organizations to seek relief, and introduce criminal penalties for violations. The bill is currently referred to the House Committee on Financial Services for further consideration.

event_name: Protect the Gig Economy Act of 2025
blurb: The Protect the Gig Economy Act of 2025, introduced by Rep. Biggs, aims to amend Rule 23 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure to shield gig economy businesses from class action lawsuits related to contractor misclassification. The bill is currently under review by the House Judiciary Committee. Key takeaway: This legislation seeks to reduce litigation risks for small businesses relying on independent contractors.

omy Act of 2025’’. 5

event_name: Responsible Path to Full Obamacare Repeal Act
blurb: The "Responsible Path to Full Obamacare Repeal Act" (H.R. 114) aims to repeal the Affordable Care Act and the Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act, effective October 1, 2025. The bill has been referred to multiple committees for review. Key takeaway: this legislation could significantly alter healthcare access and regulations in the U.S. if passed.
body:

1STSESSION  H. R. 114 
To repeal the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act and the Health 
Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025

Committee on Energy and Commerce, and in addition to the Committees on Ways and Means, Education and Workforce, Natural Resources, the Judiciary, House Administration, Rules, and Appropriations, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consider-ation of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To repeal the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act 
and the Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Responsible Path to 4
Full Obamacare Repeal Act’’. 5

event_name: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to allow an above-the-line deduction for health insurance premiums.
blurb: H.R. 111, introduced by Mr. Biggs, proposes an above-the-line deduction for health insurance premiums under the Internal Revenue Code. This bill, referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means, aims to enhance tax benefits for individuals by allowing deductions regardless of itemization. Effective for taxable years post-December 31, 2024, this legislation could significantly reduce tax burdens for taxpayers and their dependents.

event_name: Original Students Voicing Opinions in Today’s Elections (VOTE) Act
blurb: The Original Students Voicing Opinions in Today’s Elections (VOTE) Act aims to establish a pilot program providing funds to local educational agencies for voter registration initiatives targeting 12th-grade students. Introduced by Mr. Green of Texas, the bill is currently with the House Committee on House Administration. Educational agencies must apply to receive funds and report on their initiatives' effectiveness. This legislation seeks to enhance civic engagement among high school seniors.

event_name: Proposing a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution of the United States.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, House Joint Resolution 10 was introduced, proposing a balanced budget amendment to the U.S. Constitution. Key provisions include limiting outlays to receipts, requiring a supermajority for debt increases, and mandating the President's budget to align with this framework. The resolution is currently referred to the House Judiciary Committee for further consideration.
body:
IA 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. J. RES. 10 
Proposing a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution of the United 
States. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. N UNN of Iowa (for himself, Mr. A LLEN , Mr. L ATTA , Mr. Z INKE , Mr. 
HILLof Arkansas, Mr. E STES , Mrs. H OUCHIN , Mr. G ROTHMAN , Mr. 
MANN, Mr. C ALVERT , and Mr. B ACON ) submitted the following joint res-
olution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary 
JOINT RESOLUTION 
Proposing a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution 
of the United States. 
Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives 1
of the United States of America in Congress assembled2
(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol- 3
lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con-4
stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all 5
intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when 6
ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several 7
States within seven years after the date of its submission 8
for ratification: 9

2 
•HJ 10 IH ‘‘ARTICLE — 1
‘‘SECTION 1. Total outlays for any fiscal year shall 2
not exceed total receipts for that fiscal year, unless three- 3
fifths of the whole number of each House of Congress shall 4
provide by law for a specific excess of outlays over receipts 5
by a rollcall vote. 6
‘‘SECTION 2. The limit on the debt of the United 7
States held by the public shall not be increased, unless 8
three-fifths of the whole number of each House shall pro-9
vide by law for such an increase by a rollcall vote. 10
‘‘SECTION 3. Prior to each fiscal year, the President 11
shall transmit to the Congress a proposed budget for the 12
United States Government for that fiscal year in which 13
total outlays do not exceed total receipts. 14
‘‘SECTION 4. No bill to increase revenue shall become 15
law unless approved by a majority of the whole number 16
of each House by a rollcall vote. 17
‘‘SECTION 5. The Congress may waive the provisions 18
of this article for any fiscal year in which a declaration 19
of war is in effect. The provisions of this article may be 20
waived for any fiscal year in which the United States is 21
engaged in military conflict which causes an imminent and 22
serious military threat to national security and is so de-23
clared by a joint resolution, adopted by a majority of the 24
whole number of each House, which becomes law. Any 25

3 
•HJ 10 IH such waiver must identify and be limited to the specific 1
excess or increase for that fiscal year made necessary by 2
the identified military conflict. 3
‘‘SECTION 6. The Congress shall enforce and imple- 4
ment this article by appropriate legislation, which may rely 5
on estimates of outlays and receipts. 6
‘‘SECTION 7. Total receipts shall include all receipts 7
of the United States Government except those derived 8
from borrowing. Total outlays shall include all outlays of 9
the United States Government except for those for repay-10
ment of debt principal. 11
‘‘SECTION 8. This article shall take effect beginning 12
with the fifth fiscal year beginning after its ratification.’’. 13

event_name: First Amendment Accountability Act
blurb: The First Amendment Accountability Act (H.R. 162) aims to allow individuals to sue federal employees for violations of First Amendment rights. Introduced on January 3, 2025, by Ms. Hageman and others, it has been referred to the House Judiciary Committee. The bill permits recovery of attorney's fees for prevailing parties, excluding suits against the federal government itself. Key takeaway: enhances accountability for federal employees regarding constitutional rights.
body:

Mr. M OORE of Alabama) introduced the following bill; which was referred 
to the Committee on the Judiciary

To provide for a right of action against Federal employees 
for violations of First Amendment rights. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘First Amendment Ac- 4
countability Act’’. 5

event_name: New Source Review Permitting Improvement Act
blurb: The New Source Review Permitting Improvement Act (H.R. 161) aims to clarify modifications and construction definitions under the Clean Air Act. It specifies conditions under which changes to stationary sources are considered modifications, focusing on emissions increases and pollution control. The bill was introduced by Mr. Griffith and is currently with the House Committee on Energy and Commerce for review. Key takeaways include potential regulatory relief for facilities making efficiency or safety improvements.

119 THCONGRESS

Committee on Energy and Commerce 
A BILL 
To amend sections 111, 169, and 171 of the Clean Air 
Act to clarify when a physical change in, or change in the method of operation of, a stationary source con-stitutes a modification or construction, and for other purposes.

tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

Permitting Improvement Act’’. 5

‘‘(B) Notwithstanding subparagraph (A), the 19

RATION. 13

event_name: Amtrak Transparency and Accountability for Passengers and Taxpayers Act
blurb: The Amtrak Transparency and Accountability for Passengers and Taxpayers Act (H.R. 188) mandates that Amtrak's Board of Directors adhere to federal open meetings laws. Introduced on January 3, 2025, by Reps. Nehls and Graves, the bill is currently with the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure. Key provisions include ensuring public access to Amtrak meetings while allowing confidentiality in specific contract and employment matters.

event_name: Commission to Study and Develop Reparation Proposals for African Americans Act
blurb: The "Commission to Study and Develop Reparation Proposals for African Americans Act" (H.R. 40) has been introduced in the House and referred to the Judiciary Committee. This legislation aims to establish a commission to investigate the impacts of slavery and systemic discrimination against African Americans, ultimately recommending reparations and a national apology. The commission's findings will be reported to Congress within 18 months.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 40 
To address the fundamental injustice, cruelty, brutality, and inhumanity of 
slavery in the United States and the 13 American colonies between 1619 and 1865 and to establish a commission to study and consider a national apology and proposal for reparations for the institution of slavery, its subsequent de jure and de facto racial and economic discrimi-nation against African Americans, and the impact of these forces on living African Americans, to make recommendations to the Congress on appropriate remedies, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Ms. P RESSLEY introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on the Judiciary 
A BILL 
To address the fundamental injustice, cruelty, brutality, and 
inhumanity of slavery in the United States and the 13 American colonies between 1619 and 1865 and to estab-lish a commission to study and consider a national apol-ogy and proposal for reparations for the institution of slavery, its subsequent de jure and de facto racial and economic discrimination against African Americans, and the impact of these forces on living African Americans, to make recommendations to the Congress on appro-priate remedies, and for other purposes.

•HR 40 IHBe it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Commission to Study 4
and Develop Reparation Proposals for African Americans 5
Act’’. 6
SEC. 2. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE. 7
(a) F INDINGS .—The Congress finds that— 8
(1) approximately 4,000,000 Africans and their 9
descendants were enslaved in the United States and 10
colonies that became the United States from 1619 to 11
1865; 12
(2) the institution of slavery was constitu- 13
tionally and statutorily sanctioned by the Govern- 14
ment of the United States from 1789 through 1865; 15
(3) the slavery that flourished in the United 16
States constituted an immoral and inhumane depri- 17
vation of Africans’ life, liberty, African citizenship 18
rights, and cultural heritage, and denied them the 19
fruits of their own labor; 20
(4) a preponderance of scholarly, legal, commu- 21
nity evidentiary documentation and popular culture 22
markers constitute the basis for inquiry into the on- 23
going effects of the institution of slavery and its leg- 24
acy of persistent systemic structures of discrimina- 25

United States; 2
(5) the brutal overthrow of Reconstruction, 3
which represented a significant but constrained mo- 4
ment of advances for Black rights as epitomized by 5
the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments to the Con- 6
stitution, the Civil Rights Acts of 1866 and 1875 7
and the Freedman’s Bureau, failed African Ameri- 8
cans by failing to ensure their safety and security; 9
(6) following the abolition of slavery and end of 10
Reconstruction the United States Government, 11
through laws enacted at the Federal, State, and 12
local level, continued to perpetuate, condone and 13
profit from practices that continued to brutalize and 14
disadvantage African Americans, including share 15
cropping, convict leasing, Jim Crow, redlining, un- 16
equal education, and disproportionate treatment at 17
the hands of the criminal justice system, resulting in 18
stolen labor and ultimately forestalling landmark 19
contributions in science, arts, commerce and public 20
service; 21
(7) the civil rights movement, and other efforts 22
to redress grievances arising from systemic inequi- 23
ties, were sabotaged, both intentionally and uninten- 24
tionally, thus rendering the accomplishments of 25

ther embedding racial inequality in society; 2

ment actions directed against African Americans in- 4
clude— 5
(A) the creation of the Federal Housing 6
Administration, which adopted specific policies 7
designed to incentivize residential segregation; 8
(B) the enactment of legislation creating 9
the Social Security program, for which most Af- 10
rican Americans were purposely rendered ineli- 11
gible during its first two decades; 12

1944 (commonly known as the GI Bill of 14
Rights; 58 Stat. 284, chapter 268), which left 15
administration of its programs to the States, 16
thus enabling discrimination against African- 17
American veterans; and 18
(D) the Fair Labor Standards Act of 19
1938, which allowed labor unions to discrimi- 20
nate based on race; and 21
(9) as a result of the historic and continued dis- 22
crimination, African Americans continue to suffer 23
debilitating economic, educational, and health hard- 24
ships including but not limited to having nearly 25

ment rate more than twice the current White unem- 2
ployment rate; and an average of less than 1⁄16of 3
the wealth of White families, a disparity which has 4
worsened, not improved over time. 5

lish a commission to study and develop Reparation pro-7

and on society in the United States; 24

event_name: Inflation Reduction Act of 2025
blurb: On January 3, 2025, the House introduced H.R. 191, the Inflation Reduction Act of 2025, aimed at repealing the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022. The bill has been referred to multiple committees for review. Key actions include rescinding unobligated funds from the previous act. Stakeholders should monitor committee discussions for potential impacts on fiscal policy.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 191 
To repeal the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. O GLES (for himself, Mr. B URLISON , Mr. P ERRY , Mr. G OSAR , Mr. B IGGS 
of Arizona, Mr. C LOUD , Ms. H AGEMAN , Mr. B RECHEEN , Mr. C RANE , 
Mrs. M ILLER of Illinois, Mr. S ELF, Mrs. L UNA, Mr. R OY, Mr. M OORE  
of Alabama, Mr. Z INKE , and Mr. T IFFANY ) introduced the following bill; 
which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means, and in addi-tion to the Committees on Energy and Commerce, Agriculture, Natural Resources, Financial Services, Science, Space, and Technology, Transpor-tation and Infrastructure, and Oversight and Government Reform, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the com-mittee concerned 
A BILL 
To repeal the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Inflation Reduction 4
Act of 2025’’. 5

event_name: Original Honoring Our WWII Merchant Mariners Act of 2025
blurb: The "Original Honoring Our WWII Merchant Mariners Act of 2025" aims to establish the Merchant Mariner Equity Compensation Fund, providing $25,000 to eligible WWII merchant mariners. Introduced by Mr. Green of Texas, the bill is currently under review by the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs. Eligible individuals must apply within one year of enactment. Funding of $125 million is proposed for fiscal year 2026.
body:

event_name: Original LAW Act
blurb: The Original Living American Wage Act (H.R. 122) aims to amend the Fair Labor Standards Act, linking the minimum wage to the federal poverty threshold for a family of four. Introduced by Mr. Green of Texas on January 3, 2025, it proposes incremental wage increases starting at $10.59 in 2026, reaching $26.59 by 2030. The bill is currently in the House Committee on Education and Workforce. Key takeaway: potential for significant wage

To amend the Fair Labor Standards Act to provide for the calculation 
of the minimum wage based on the Federal supplemental poverty thresh-old for a renter family of 4, with 2 children under the age of 18, as determined by the Bureau of the Census, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. G REEN of Texas introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Education and Workforce 
A BILL 
To amend the Fair Labor Standards Act to provide for 
the calculation of the minimum wage based on the Fed-eral supplemental poverty threshold for a renter family of 4, with 2 children under the age of 18, as determined by the Bureau of the Census, and for other purposes.

tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

event_name: Reclaiming Congress’s Constitutional Mandate in Trade Resolution
blurb: The "Reclaiming Congress’s Constitutional Mandate in Trade Resolution" establishes a Joint Ad Hoc Committee to shift U.S. Trade Representative functions to Congress, enhancing legislative oversight on trade. Members will be appointed within 60 days, and the committee must report its plan within 16 months. This initiative aims to reinforce congressional authority under the Constitution and improve trade policy governance.

event_name: To hold the salaries of Members of a House of Congress in escrow if the House of Congress does not pass regular appropriation bills on a timely basis during a Congress, and for other purposes.
blurb: A new proposal aims to hold Congressional salaries in escrow if regular appropriation bills are not passed on time. Currently referred to the House Committee on House Administration, this initiative seeks to enforce accountability among lawmakers regarding timely budget approvals.

metadata.event_name: To hold the salaries of Members of a House of Congress in escrow if the House of Congress does not pass regular appropriation bills on a timely basis during a Congress, and for other purposes.

event_name: NOSHA Act
blurb: The NOSHA Act (H.R. 86), introduced by Mr. Biggs, aims to abolish the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) and repeal the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970. Currently referred to the House Committee on Education and Workforce, this bill could significantly impact workplace safety regulations. Stakeholders should monitor developments closely.
body:

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 86 
To abolish the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, and for other 
purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Education and Workforce 
A BILL 
To abolish the Occupational Safety and Health 
Administration, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Nullify Occupational 4
Safety and Health Administration Act’’ or the ‘‘NOSHA 5
Act’’. 6

event_name: To provide that the salaries of Members of a House of Congress will be held in escrow if that House has not agreed to a concurrent resolution on the budget for the next fiscal year by April 15.
blurb: A proposal has been introduced to hold the salaries of Congress members in escrow if a concurrent resolution on the budget for the next fiscal year is not agreed upon by April 15. This measure aims to encourage timely budget negotiations. The bill is currently under review by the House Committee on House Administration.

metadata.event_name: To provide that the salaries of Members of a House of Congress will be held in escrow if that House has not agreed to a concurrent resolution on the budget for the next fiscal year by April 15.

event_name: Stay on Schedule (S.O.S.) Resolution
blurb: The Stay on Schedule (S.O.S.) Resolution (H. RES. 12) aims to amend House rules to prevent recesses after July 31 unless all regular appropriation bills for the upcoming fiscal year are approved. Submitted by Mr. Wittman on January 3, 2025, the resolution emphasizes fiscal responsibility and timely legislative action. It is currently referred to the House Committee on Rules for consideration.
body:
IV 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. RES. 12 
Amending the Rules of the House of Representatives to prohibit the consider-
ation of a concurrent resolution to provide for a recess of the House after July 31 of any year unless the House has approved each regular appropriation bill for the next fiscal year. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. W ITTMAN submitted the following resolution; which was referred to the 
Committee on Rules 
RESOLUTION 
Amending the Rules of the House of Representatives to 
prohibit the consideration of a concurrent resolution to provide for a recess of the House after July 31 of any year unless the House has approved each regular appro-priation bill for the next fiscal year. 
Resolved, 1
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 2
This resolution may be cited as the ‘‘Stay on Sched- 3
ule (S.O.S.) Resolution’’. 4

PROVAL OF ALL REGULAR APPROPRIATION 2

tives is amended by adding at the end the following new 5
clause: 6
‘‘Concurrent resolution providing for adjournment 7
during August 8

has not passed each of the regular appropriation bills for 10

annual appropriation bill which is under the jurisdiction 17
of a single subcommittee of the Committee on Appropria-18

under the Rules for the fiscal year involved).’’. 20

event_name: Freedom for Families Act
blurb: The Freedom for Families Act (H.R. 74) aims to amend the Internal Revenue Code to permit tax-advantaged distributions from health savings accounts (HSAs) during family or medical leave. Introduced on January 3, 2025, by Mr. Biggs and Mr. Burlison, the bill is currently with the House Committee on Ways and Means. Key provisions include increased HSA contribution limits and removal of high-deductible health plan requirements.
body:

To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to allow for tax-advantaged 
distributions from health savings accounts during family or medical leave, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona (for himself and Mr. B URLISON ) introduced the 
following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means 
A BILL 
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to allow for 
tax-advantaged distributions from health savings ac-counts during family or medical leave, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Freedom for Families 4
Act’’. 5

event_name: ALVIN Act
blurb: The ALVIN Act (H.R. 63) seeks to prohibit federal funding for the Manhattan District Attorney's Office. Introduced by Rep. Biggs and others on January 3, 2025, the bill mandates the rescission of existing federal funds and requires reimbursement for amounts expended since January 1, 2022. The proposal is currently under review by the House Judiciary Committee.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 63 
To prohibit Federal funds from being awarded or otherwise made available 
to the Manhattan District Attorney’s Office. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona (for himself, Mr. C RANE , Mr. B RECHEEN , and Mrs. 
LUNA) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee 
on the Judiciary 
A BILL 
To prohibit Federal funds from being awarded or otherwise 
made available to the Manhattan District Attorney’s Office. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Accountability for 4
Lawless Violence In our Neighborhoods Act’’ or the 5
‘‘ALVIN Act’’. 6
SEC. 2. PROHIBITION ON FEDERAL FUNDING WITH RE-7
SPECT TO MANHATTAN DISTRICT ATTORNEY. 8
(a) P ROHIBITION ON FEDERAL FUNDING .—Notwith- 9
standing any other provision of law, no Federal funds may 10

event_name: WILLIS Act
blurb: The WILLIS Act (H.R. 62), introduced by Rep. Biggs and others, seeks to prohibit federal funding to the Fulton County District Attorney’s Office. The bill mandates the rescission of any federal funds allocated since January 1, 2021, and requires reimbursement for expenditures. Currently referred to the House Judiciary Committee, this legislation aims to curb federal financial support for what it deems "lawless litigators."

Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Withholding Invest- 4
ments from Lawless Litigators In States Act’’ or the 5
‘‘WILLIS Act’’. 6

event_name: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to prohibit Members of Congress from receiving compensation during a fiscal year unless both Houses of Congress have agreed to a concurrent resolution on the budget for that fiscal year prior to the beginning of that fiscal year.
blurb: A joint resolution (H.J. Res. 7) was introduced to amend the U.S. Constitution, prohibiting Congressional compensation unless both Houses agree on a budget resolution before the fiscal year starts. Referred to the House Judiciary Committee, this proposal aims to enforce fiscal accountability among lawmakers. Ratification requires approval from three-fourths of state legislatures within seven years.
body:
IA 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. J. RES. 7 
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to prohibit 
Members of Congress from receiving compensation during a fiscal year unless both Houses of Congress have agreed to a concurrent resolution on the budget for that fiscal year prior to the beginning of that fiscal year. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. F ITZPATRICK submitted the following joint resolution; which was referred 
to the Committee on the Judiciary 
JOINT RESOLUTION 
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United 
States to prohibit Members of Congress from receiving compensation during a fiscal year unless both Houses of Congress have agreed to a concurrent resolution on the budget for that fiscal year prior to the beginning of that fiscal year. 
Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives 1
of the United States of America in Congress assembled2
(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol- 3
lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con-4
stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all 5
intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when 6

States within seven years after the date of its submission 2
for ratification: 3

‘‘SECTION 1. A Member of Congress may not receive 5
a compensation for service as a Member of Congress dur-6
ing a fiscal year unless both Houses of Congress have 7
agreed to an identical concurrent resolution on the budget 8
for that fiscal year prior to the beginning of that fiscal 9
year. 10
‘‘SECTION 2. This article shall apply with respect to 11

part of the Constitution.’’. 13

event_name: To amend chapter 211 of title 18, United States Code, to modify venue for certain offenses.
blurb: The proposed amendment to Chapter 211 of Title 18, U.S. Code, seeks to modify the venue for specific offenses. Currently referred to the House Judiciary Committee, this legislation aims to enhance judicial efficiency. Stakeholders should monitor its progress for potential impacts on legal proceedings.

metadata.event_name: To amend chapter 211 of title 18, United States Code, to modify venue for certain offenses.

event_name: No Federal Funds for Political Prosecutions Act
blurb: The "No Federal Funds for Political Prosecutions Act" (H.R. 118) aims to prohibit state and local law enforcement from using forfeited funds to investigate or prosecute the President, Vice President, or candidates for these offices. Introduced by Mr. Biggs, the bill has been referred to the Judiciary and Energy and Commerce Committees for consideration. Compliance certification to the Attorney General is required, with penalties for non-compliance.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 118 
To prohibit the use of forfeited funds made available to certain State or 
local law enforcement agencies pursuant to equitable sharing for certain purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on the Judiciary, and in addition to the Committee on Energy and Commerce, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speak-er, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the ju-risdiction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To prohibit the use of forfeited funds made available to 
certain State or local law enforcement agencies pursuant to equitable sharing for certain purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘No Federal Funds for 4
Political Prosecutions Act’’. 5

event_name: To establish the People-Centered Assistance Reform Effort Commission, to improve the social safety net and increase social mobility by increasing access to resources which address the underlying causes of poverty.
blurb: The People-Centered Assistance Reform Effort Commission aims to enhance the social safety net and boost social mobility by addressing poverty's root causes. The proposal has been referred to multiple committees, including Ways and Means, Education, and Agriculture, for jurisdictional review. Stakeholders should monitor developments for opportunities to engage in the reform process.

metadata.event_name: To establish the People-Centered Assistance Reform Effort Commission, to improve the social safety net and increase social mobility by increasing access to resources which address the underlying causes of poverty.

event_name: Fair Representation Amendment
blurb: The Fair Representation Amendment (H. Res. 11) has been referred to the House Committee on Rules. It mandates specific committees to review existing laws and propose changes to reduce excessive Executive Branch discretion within six months. The resulting recommendations will be reported by the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform as the Article One Restoration Act.

event_name: To ensure election integrity and security and enhance Americans' access to the ballot box by establishing consistent standards and procedures for voter registration and voting in elections for Federal office, and for other purposes.
blurb: The bill aims to enhance election integrity and accessibility by establishing uniform standards for voter registration and voting in federal elections. It has been referred to the House Administration Committee and the Science, Space, and Technology Committee for review. Key takeaway: consistent voting procedures are crucial for safeguarding democracy.

event_name: To ensure election integrity and security by establishing consistent photo identification requirements for voting in elections for Federal office, and for other purposes.
blurb: The proposed legislation aims to enhance election integrity by mandating consistent photo ID requirements for federal elections. Currently referred to the House Committee on House Administration, this measure seeks to standardize voting procedures and ensure secure electoral processes. Stakeholders should monitor developments for potential implications on voter access and election administration.

event_name: Unauthorized Spending Accountability Act
blurb: The Unauthorized Spending Accountability Act establishes a three-year budgetary reduction schedule for unauthorized programs, starting in fiscal year 2026. It mandates a 10% reduction in the budget for programs lacking authorization, increasing to 15% in subsequent years. Programs will be terminated after three unauthorized years unless reauthorized. The bill aims to enhance fiscal accountability and streamline government spending.
body:

To establish a budgetary level reduction schedule, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025

which was referred to the Committee on Oversight and Government Re-form, and in addition to the Committees on the Budget, and Rules, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the com-mittee concerned

event_name: Lead by Example Act of 2025
blurb: The Lead by Example Act of 2025 mandates that Members of Congress and their staff receive healthcare exclusively from the Department of Veterans Affairs, starting January 3, 2027. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs and the Director of the Office of Personnel Management must submit an implementation plan by September 15, 2025. This legislation aims to align Congressional healthcare with veteran services.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 149 
To ensure that Members of Congress and Congressional staff receive health 
care from the Department of Veterans Affairs instead of under the Federal Health Benefits Program or health care exchanges. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. D AVIDSON introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Com-
mittee on House Administration, and in addition to the Committee on Veterans’ Affairs, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To ensure that Members of Congress and Congressional staff 
receive health care from the Department of Veterans Affairs instead of under the Federal Health Benefits Program or health care exchanges. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Lead by Example Act 4
of 2025’’. 5

event_name: HEALTH Act
blurb: The HEALTH Act, introduced by Mr. Davidson, aims to establish a standing Committee on Health within the House of Representatives. This committee will oversee biomedical research, healthcare facilities, and public health initiatives. The resolution has been referred to the House Committee on Rules for consideration. Key takeaway: This act could significantly reshape healthcare legislative processes.

as paragraphs (k) through (u); and 10

blurb: The proposed amendment to Chapter 8 of Title 5, U.S. Code, mandates that major executive branch rules require a joint resolution of approval to take effect. Currently referred to the Committees on Judiciary, Rules, and Budget for review, this legislation aims to enhance congressional oversight of executive regulations.

Stakeholders should monitor committee activities for updates.

event_name: Keep Your Coins Act of 2025
blurb: The "Keep Your Coins Act of 2025" (H.R. 148), introduced by Mr. Davidson, aims to prevent federal agencies from restricting individuals' use of convertible virtual currency for personal purchases. The bill emphasizes user control over digital assets and prohibits limitations on self-custody wallets. Currently referred to the House Committee on Financial Services, it highlights the growing importance of cryptocurrency autonomy.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 148 
To prohibit Federal agencies from restricting the use of convertible virtual 
currency by a person to purchase goods or services for the person’s own use, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. D AVIDSON introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Financial Services 
A BILL 
To prohibit Federal agencies from restricting the use of 
convertible virtual currency by a person to purchase goods or services for the person’s own use, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Keep Your Coins Act 4
of 2025’’. 5

IBLE VIRTUAL CURRENCY BY A PERSON TO 2
RETAIN FULL CONTROL OVER CONVERTIBLE 3
VIRTUAL CURRENCY. 4
(a) I NGENERAL .—The head of a Federal agency 5
may not prohibit, restrict, or otherwise impair the ability 6
of a covered user to— 7
(1) use convertible virtual currency or its equiv- 8
alent for such user’s own purposes, such as to pur- 9
chase real or virtual goods and services for the 10
user’s own use; or 11
(2) self-custody digital assets using a self- 12
hosted wallet or other means to conduct transactions 13
for any lawful purpose. 14
(b) D EFINITIONS .—In this section: 15
(1) C ONVERTIBLE VIRTUAL CURRENCIES .—The 16
term ‘‘convertible virtual currency’’ means a medium 17
of exchange that— 18
(A) has an equivalent value as currency (as 19
defined in section 1010.100 of title 31, Code of 20
Federal Regulations (or successor regulations)); 21
or 22
(B) acts as a substitute for currency but 23
may not possess all the attributes (including 24
legal tender status) specified under such section 25
1010.100 (or successor regulations). 26

means a person that obtains convertible virtual cur- 2
rency to purchase goods or services on that person’s 3
own behalf, without regard to the method in which 4
such covered user obtained such convertible virtual 5
currency. 6
(3) S ELF-HOSTED WALLET .—The term ‘‘self- 7
hosted wallet’’ means a digital interface— 8
(A) used to secure and transfer convertible 9
virtual currency; and 10
(B) under which the owner of convertible 11
virtual currency retains independent control 12
over such convertible virtual currency that is se- 13
cured by such digital interface. 14

event_name: FinCEN Oversight and Accountability Act of 2025
blurb: The FinCEN Oversight and Accountability Act of 2025 aims to enhance the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network's transparency and accountability. Key provisions include mandatory reporting of unlawful activities to Congress, improved oversight mechanisms, and the establishment of annual small business working groups. The bill, introduced by Mr. Davidson, is currently under review by the House Financial Services Committee.

event_name: Trailer Safety Improvement Act
blurb: The Trailer Safety Improvement Act (H.R. 141) aims to enhance state highway safety programs by incorporating education on proper trailer use and safety equipment. Introduced by Mr. Burchett and Mr. Bishop, the bill has been referred to the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure. Key takeaway: This legislation seeks to reduce trailer-related accidents through public education.

event_name: Budget Process Enhancement Act
blurb: The Budget Process Enhancement Act (H.R. 113) aims to improve congressional budget accountability by removing the discretionary inflater from the baseline and placing Congressional salaries in escrow if no budget resolution is passed by April 15, 2025. The bill emphasizes timely budget submissions and compliance, holding key budget officials accountable for delays. The act was introduced by Mr. Biggs and is currently under committee review.

JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on the Budget, and in addition to the Committees on House Administration, and Oversight and Government Reform, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consider-ation of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To remove the discretionary inflater from the baseline and 
to provide that the salaries of Members of a House of Congress will be held in escrow if that House has not agreed to a concurrent resolution on the budget for fiscal year 2026, and for other purposes.

tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

hancement Act’’. 5

event_name: Return to Work Act
blurb: The Return to Work Act (H.R. 107) mandates Executive agencies to reinstate telework policies from December 31, 2019, within 60 days of enactment. Introduced by Mr. Biggs on January 3, 2025, this legislation aims to standardize remote work practices across federal agencies. Key takeaway: agencies must align with pre-pandemic telework policies, overriding conflicting agreements.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 107 
To require Executive agencies to reinstate telework policies that were in 
place on December 31, 2019, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Oversight and Government Reform 
A BILL 
To require Executive agencies to reinstate telework policies 
that were in place on December 31, 2019, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Return to Work Act’’. 4
SEC. 2. REINSTATE PRIOR REMOTE WORK POLICIES. 5
(a) I NGENERAL .—Not later than 60 days after the 6
date of the enactment of this Act, the head of each Execu-7
tive agency shall reinstate the telework policies in use by 8
such Executive agency on December 31, 2019. 9

date on which the head of an Executive agency reinstates 2

December 31, 2019, the reinstated telework policy of such 4
Executive agency shall apply in place of any telework pro-5
vision of a teleworking, collective bargaining, or other em-6
ployment agreement of such Executive agency to the ex-7
tent that such telework provision conflicts with, or applies 8
a different telework policy than, the reinstated telework 9
policy of such Executive agency. 10

(1) E XECUTIVE AGENCY .—The term ‘‘Executive 12
agency’’ has the meaning given such term in section 13

(2) R EINSTATED TELEWORK POLICY .—The 15
term ‘‘reinstated telework policy’’ means the 16
telework policies in use by an Executive agency on 17
December 31, 2019. 18
(3) T ELEWORK .—The term ‘‘telework’’ has the 19
meaning given such term in section 6501 of title 5, 20
United States Code. 21

event_name: Recognizing the importance of access to comprehensive, high-quality, life-affirming medical care for women of all ages.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, H. Res. 7 was introduced in the House, emphasizing the necessity for comprehensive, high-quality, life-affirming medical care for women. The resolution underscores women's empowerment in health advocacy and recognizes Pro Women’s Healthcare Centers as a model for nationwide standards. It has been referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce for further consideration.
body:
IV 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. RES. 7 
Recognizing the importance of access to comprehensive, high-quality, life- 
affirming medical care for women of all ages. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona (for himself and Mr. H IGGINS of Louisiana) submitted 
the following resolution; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce 
RESOLUTION 
Recognizing the importance of access to comprehensive, high- 
quality, life-affirming medical care for women of all ages. 
Whereas women of all ages should have access to comprehen-
sive, convenient, compassionate, life-affirming, high-qual-ity medical services; 
Whereas all women should feel empowered and equipped with 
the knowledge to listen to their body and advocate for their health; 
Whereas health care for women should emphasize the whole 
woman, including her physical, mental, and spiritual wellness; 
Whereas health care for women should also address the needs 
of men, families, and communities as they relate to wom-en’s health care; 
VerDate Sep 11 2014 22:16 Jan 04, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6300 E:\BILLS\HR7.IH HR7kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
2 
•HRES 7 IH Whereas health care centers should include access to social 
services that empower women to care for their health; 
Whereas Pro Women’s Healthcare Centers is a consortium of 
centers that serves as an example of the high-quality, comprehensive, life-affirming care that women deserve; 
Whereas every Pro Women’s Healthcare Center certified clin-
ic has a licensed medical professional; 
Whereas every Pro Women’s Healthcare Center offers com-
prehensive health services, including well-woman exams, sexually transmitted disease testing and treatment, breast exams, pregnancy testing, prenatal and pregnancy care, miscarriage support, fertility awareness instruction, infertility consultation, and onsite or nearby, direct refer-rals for material, emotional, practical, and spiritual re-sources; and 
Whereas Pro Women’s Healthcare Centers has certified 
health care centers nationwide that meet its standards for high-quality, life-affirming care and continue to do so: Now, therefore, be it 
Resolved, That the House of Representatives— 1
(1) expresses its support for women nationwide 2
to have access to comprehensive, convenient, com- 3
passionate, life-affirming, high-quality health care; 4
and 5
(2) recognizes the high standards established by 6
Pro Women’s Healthcare Centers consortium as 7
standards worth implementing nationwide. 8
Æ

event_name: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide that debate upon legislation pending before the Senate may not be brought to a close without the concurrence of a minimum of three-fifths of the Senators.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, a joint resolution was introduced in the House, proposing a constitutional amendment to require a three-fifths Senate majority to close debate on pending legislation. The resolution is currently referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary. If ratified by three-fourths of the states, this amendment would significantly impact Senate debate procedures.

lowing joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judi-ciary 
JOINT RESOLUTION 
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United 
States to provide that debate upon legislation pending before the Senate may not be brought to a close without the concurrence of a minimum of three-fifths of the Senators. 
Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives 1
of the United States of America in Congress assembled2
(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol- 3
lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con-4
stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all 5
intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when 6

‘‘The debate on any measure or motion pending be- 4
fore the Senate, excluding Presidential nominations, shall 5
not be brought to a close except as provided under laws 6

the concurrence of a minimum of three-fifths of the Sen-8
ators duly chosen and sworn.’’. 9

event_name: Abortion Is Not Health Care Act of 2025
blurb: The "Abortion Is Not Health Care Act of 2025" (H.R. 73) aims to amend the Internal Revenue Code to exclude abortion costs from medical expense deductions. Introduced by Rep. Biggs and others, the bill is currently referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means. If enacted, it will affect taxable years post-enactment. Key takeaway: This legislation seeks to redefine abortion's classification in tax law.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 73 
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide that amounts 
paid for an abortion are not taken into account for purposes of the deduction for medical expenses. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona (for himself, Mr. A LLEN , Mr. M OORE of Alabama, and 
Mr. J OYCE of Pennsylvania) introduced the following bill; which was re-
ferred to the Committee on Ways and Means 
A BILL 
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide 
that amounts paid for an abortion are not taken into account for purposes of the deduction for medical ex-penses. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Abortion Is Not Health 4
Care Act of 2025’’. 5

enue Code of 1986 is amended by adding at the end the 5

blurb: The "No Pro-Abortion Task Force Act" (H.R. 49) aims to prohibit federal funding for the HHS Reproductive Healthcare Access Task Force. Introduced by Mr. Biggs and Mr. Lamalfa, the bill has been referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. If enacted, it would prevent any federal resources from supporting this task force or similar initiatives.

blurb: The "No SmartPay for Anti-2A Companies Act" (H.R. 70) was introduced on January 3, 2025, to prevent the General Services Administrator from awarding SmartPay contracts to payment systems that categorize gun retailers. The bill emphasizes support for Second Amendment rights and excludes contracts awarded prior to its enactment. It is currently under review by the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform.

event_name: Pregnant Women Health and Safety Act of 2025
blurb: The Pregnant Women Health and Safety Act of 2025, introduced by Mr. Biggs, aims to amend Title 18 of the U.S. Code to prohibit certain abortion procedures. It mandates that physicians performing abortions have admitting privileges at nearby hospitals and informs patients of follow-up care options. The bill is currently under review by the Committees on the Judiciary and Energy and Commerce. Key takeaway: compliance with new requirements is essential for physicians and clinics to avoid penalties.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 78 
To amend title 18, United States Code, to prohibit certain abortion 
procedures, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

metadata.event_name: Pregnant Women Health and Safety Act of 2025

event_name: Ultrasound Informed Consent Act
blurb: The Ultrasound Informed Consent Act (H.R. 48) mandates that women seeking an abortion receive an ultrasound and the chance to review it before consenting. Introduced on January 3, 2025, by Rep. Biggs and others, it is currently with the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. Key provisions include civil penalties for non-compliance and exceptions in medical emergencies.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 48 
To amend the Public Health Service Act to ensure that women seeking 
an abortion receive an ultrasound and the opportunity to review the ultrasound before giving informed consent to receive an abortion. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona (for himself, Mr. C RENSHAW , and Mr. B URLISON ) in-
troduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on En-ergy and Commerce 
A BILL 
To amend the Public Health Service Act to ensure that 
women seeking an abortion receive an ultrasound and the opportunity to review the ultrasound before giving informed consent to receive an abortion. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Ultrasound Informed 4
Consent Act’’. 5

•HR 48 IHSEC. 2. AMENDMENT TO THE PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE 1
ACT. 2
The Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 201 et 3
seq.) is amended by adding at the end the following: 4
‘‘TITLE XXXIV—INFORMED 5
CONSENT 6
‘‘SEC. 3401. DEFINITIONS. 7
‘‘In this title: 8
‘‘(1) A BORTION .—The term ‘abortion’ means 9
the intentional use or prescription of any instru- 10
ment, medicine, drug, substance, device, or method 11
to terminate the life of an unborn child, or to termi- 12
nate the pregnancy of a woman known to be preg- 13
nant, with an intention other than— 14
‘‘(A) to produce a live birth and preserve 15
the life and health of the child after live birth; 16
or 17
‘‘(B) to remove an ectopic pregnancy, or to 18
remove a dead unborn child who died as the re- 19
sult of a spontaneous abortion, accidental trau- 20
ma, or a criminal assault on the pregnant fe- 21
male or her unborn child. 22
‘‘(2) A BORTION PROVIDER .—The term ‘abortion 23
provider’ means any person legally qualified to per- 24
form an abortion under applicable Federal and State 25
laws. 26

•HR 48 IH‘‘(3) U NBORN CHILD .—The term ‘unborn child’ 1
means a member of the species homo sapiens, at any 2

‘‘(4) U NEMANCIPATED MINOR .—The term 4
‘unemancipated minor’ means a minor who is sub- 5
ject to the control, authority, and supervision of his 6
or her parent or guardian, as determined under 7
State law. 8
‘‘(5) W OMAN .—The term ‘woman’ means a fe- 9
male human being whether or not she has reached 10
the age of majority. 11
‘‘SEC. 3402. REQUIREMENT OF INFORMED CONSENT. 12
‘‘(a) R EQUIREMENT OF COMPLIANCE BY PRO- 13
VIDERS .—Any abortion provider in or affecting interstate 14
or foreign commerce, who knowingly performs any abor-15
tion, shall comply with the requirements of this title. 16
‘‘(b) P ERFORMANCE AND REVIEW OF  17
ULTRASOUND .—Prior to a woman giving informed con- 18
sent to having any part of an abortion performed, the 19
abortion provider who is to perform the abortion, or an 20
agent under the supervision of the provider, shall— 21
‘‘(1) perform an obstetric ultrasound on the 22
pregnant woman; 23
‘‘(2) provide a simultaneous explanation of 24
what the ultrasound is depicting; 25

•HR 48 IH‘‘(3) display the ultrasound images so that the 1
pregnant woman may view them; and 2
‘‘(4) provide a complete medical description of 3
the ultrasound images, which shall include— 4
‘‘(A) the dimensions of the embryo or 5
fetus; 6
‘‘(B) cardiac activity if present and visible; 7
and 8
‘‘(C) the presence of external members and 9
internal organs if present and viewable. 10
‘‘(c) A BILITY TOTURN EYES AWAY.—Nothing in 11
this section shall be construed to prevent a pregnant 12
woman from turning her eyes away from the ultrasound 13
images required to be displayed and described to her. Nei-14
ther the abortion provider nor the pregnant woman shall 15
be subject to any penalty under this title if the pregnant 16
woman declines to look at the displayed ultrasound im-17
ages. 18
‘‘SEC. 3403. EXCEPTION FOR MEDICAL EMERGENCIES. 19
‘‘(a) E XCEPTION .—The provisions of section 3402 20
shall not apply to an abortion provider if the abortion is 21
necessary to save the life of a mother whose life is endan-22
gered by a physical disorder, physical illness, or physical 23
injury, including a life-endangering physical condition 24
caused by or arising from the pregnancy itself. 25

•HR 48 IH‘‘(b) C ERTIFICATION .—Upon a determination by an 1
abortion provider under subsection (a) that an abortion 2
is necessary to save the life of a mother, such provider 3
shall include in the medical file of the pregnant woman 4

circumstances that support such determination. 6
‘‘SEC. 3404. PENALTIES FOR FAILURE TO COMPLY. 7
‘‘(a) C IVILPENALTIES .— 8
‘‘(1) I N GENERAL .—The Attorney General may 9
commence a civil action in Federal court under this 10
section against any abortion provider who knowingly 11
commits an act constituting a violation of this title 12
for a penalty in an amount not to exceed— 13
‘‘(A) $100,000 for each such violation that 14
is adjudicated in the first proceeding against 15
such provider under this title; and 16
‘‘(B) $250,000 for each violation of this 17
title that is adjudicated in a subsequent pro- 18
ceeding against such provider under this title. 19
‘‘(2) N OTIFICATION .—Upon the assessment of 20
a civil penalty under paragraph (1), the Attorney 21
General shall notify the appropriate State medical li- 22
censing authority. 23
‘‘(b) P RIVATE RIGHT OF ACTION .—A woman upon 24
whom an abortion has been performed in violation of this 25

•HR 48 IHtitle may commence a civil action against the abortion pro-1
vider for any violation of this title for actual and punitive 2
damages. For purposes of the preceding sentence, actual 3
damages are objectively verifiable money damages for all 4
injuries.’’. 5
SEC. 3. PREEMPTION. 6
Nothing in this Act or the amendment made by this 7
Act shall be construed to preempt any provision of State 8
law to the extent that such State law establishes, imple-9
ments, or continues in effect disclosure requirements re-10
garding abortion or penalties for failure to comply with 11
such requirements that are more extensive than those pro-12
vided under the amendment made by this Act. 13
SEC. 4. SEVERABILITY. 14
If any provision of this Act or the amendment made 15
by this Act, or any application thereof, is found to be un-16
constitutional, the remainder of this Act and the amend-17
ment made by this Act, and any application thereof, shall 18
not be affected by such finding. 19

event_name: LIST Act of 2025
blurb: The LIST Act of 2025, introduced by Mr. Biggs, aims to enhance the Endangered Species Act by refining the processes for listing, delisting, and downlisting species. Key provisions include mandatory initiation of delisting upon recovery and expedited review of erroneous listings. The bill is currently in the House Committee on Natural Resources, highlighting the need for precise species management. Stakeholders should monitor its progress for potential impacts on conservation efforts.
body:

To amend the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to provide for improved 
precision in the listing, delisting, and downlisting of endangered species and potentially endangered species.

Mr. B IGGS of Arizona introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Natural Resources 
A BILL 
To amend the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to provide 
for improved precision in the listing, delisting, and downlisting of endangered species and potentially endan-gered species. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Less Imprecision in 4
Species Treatment Act of 2025’’ or the ‘‘LIST Act of 5
2025’’. 6

event_name: Responsible Borrower Protection Act of 2025
blurb: The Responsible Borrower Protection Act of 2025, introduced by Rep. Biggs and others, aims to cancel proposed changes to credit fees by the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The bill, referred to the House Financial Services Committee, seeks to maintain risk-based pricing while nullifying updates announced on January 19, 2023. Key takeaway: It protects borrowers from increased fees.
body:

of Texas, Mr. C LINE , Mr. B OST, and Mr. C LOUD ) introduced the fol-
lowing bill; which was referred to the Committee on Financial Services

The Federal Housing Finance Agency and the enter- 7
prises (as such term is defined in section 1303 of the Fed-8

event_name: Increasing Public Access to Recreation Act
blurb: The Increasing Public Access to Recreation Act (H.R. 105), introduced by Mr. Biggs, aims to enhance public access to federal recreational areas by increasing funding from $15 million to $50 million and raising access limits from 3% to 10%. Currently referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources, this bill seeks to expand outdoor opportunities for the public.

event_name: Strategic Production Response and Implementation Act
blurb: The Strategic Production Response and Implementation Act (H.R. 92) aims to enhance oil and gas production on federal lands while managing the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Introduced by Mr. Biggs on January 3, 2025, the bill mandates a plan to increase leased federal lands by up to 10% before any reserve drawdown. The proposal is currently under review by the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.

and gas production under oil and gas leases of Federal lands under the jurisdiction of the Secretary of Agri-culture, the Secretary of Energy, the Secretary of the Interior, and the Secretary of Defense in conjunction with a drawdown of petroleum reserves from the Stra-tegic Petroleum Reserve. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

Response and Implementation Act’’. 5

event_name: Fourth Amendment Restoration Act
blurb: The Fourth Amendment Restoration Act (H.R. 117), introduced by Mr. Biggs, aims to repeal the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978. It mandates a warrant for surveillance of U.S. citizens and prohibits using information obtained without authorization in legal proceedings. The bill is currently referred to the Judiciary and Intelligence Committees for review. Key takeaway: Enhanced privacy protections for citizens against unwarranted surveillance.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 117 
To repeal the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on the Judiciary, and in addition to the Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall with-in the jurisdiction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To repeal the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Fourth Amendment 4
Restoration Act’’. 5
SEC. 2. REPEAL OF FOREIGN SURVEILLANCE AUTHORI-6
TIES. 7
The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 8
(50 U.S.C. 1801 et seq.) is repealed. 9

For the purposes of this Act— 2
(a) P ENREGISTER AND TRAP AND TRACE DE- 3
VICE.—The terms ‘‘pen register’’ and ‘‘trap and trace de- 4
vice’’ have the meanings given such terms in section 3127 5
of title 18, United States Code. 6
(b) U NITED STATES CITIZEN .—The term ‘‘United 7
States citizen’’ means an individual who is a citizen of the 8
United States. 9
(c) F OREIGN INTELLIGENCE INFORMATION .—The 10
term ‘‘foreign intelligence information’’ means— 11
(1) information that relates to, and if con- 12
cerning a United States citizen is necessary to, the 13
ability of the United States to protect against— 14
(A) actual or potential attack or other 15
grave hostile acts of a foreign power or an 16
agent of a foreign power; 17
(B) sabotage, international terrorism, or 18
the intentional proliferation of weapons of mass 19
destruction by a foreign power or an agent of 20
a foreign power; or 21
(C) clandestine intelligence activities by an 22
intelligence service or network of a foreign 23
power or by an agent of a foreign power; or 24

3 
•HR 117 IH(2) information with respect to a foreign power 1
or foreign territory that relates to, and if concerning 2
a United States citizen, is necessary to— 3
(A) the national defense or the security of 4
the United States; or 5
(B) the conduct of the foreign affairs of 6
the United States. 7
(d) E LECTRONIC SURVEILLANCE .—The term ‘‘elec- 8
tronic surveillance’’ means— 9
(1) the acquisition by an electronic, mechanical, 10
or other surveillance device of the contents of any 11

be received by a particular, known United States cit- 13
izen who is in the United States, if the contents are 14
acquired by intentionally targeting that United 15
States citizen, under circumstances in which a cit- 16
izen has a reasonable expectation of privacy and a 17
warrant would be required for law enforcement pur- 18
poses; or 19
(2) the installation or use of an electronic, me- 20
chanical, or other surveillance device in the United 21
States for monitoring to acquire information, other 22
than from a wire or radio communication, under cir- 23
cumstances in which a citizen has a reasonable ex- 24

4

quired for law enforcement purposes. 2
(e) W IRECOMMUNICATION .—The term ‘‘wire com- 3
munication’’ means any communication while it is being 4
carried by a wire, cable, or other like connection furnished 5
or operated by any person engaged as a common carrier 6
in providing or operating such facilities for the trans-7
mission of interstate or foreign communications. 8
SEC. 4. PROHIBITIONS ON SURVEILLING UNITED STATES 9
CITIZENS. 10
(a) An officer of the United States must obtain a 11
warrant issued using the procedures described in the Fed-12
eral Rules of Criminal Procedure by a Federal court in 13
order to conduct or request— 14
(1) electronic surveillance of a United States 15
citizen; 16
(2) a physical search of a premises, informa- 17

under the open and exclusive control of, a United 19

(3) approval of the installation and use of a pen 21

cant purpose of which is to obtain foreign intel- 23
ligence information concerning a United States cit- 24
izen; 25

SEC. 5. LIMITATION ON USE OF INFORMATION CON-14
CERNING UNITED STATES CITIZENS. 15
Any information concerning a United States citizen 16
acquired during surveillance of a non-United States citizen 17
shall not be used in evidence against that United States 18
citizen in any criminal, civil, or administrative proceeding 19
or as part of any criminal, civil, or administrative inves-20
tigation. 21
SEC. 6. CRIMINAL SANCTIONS. 22
(a) A person is guilty of an offense if he inten- 23
tionally— 24

(d) There is a Federal jurisdiction over an offense 23
under this section if the person committing the offense 24

event_name: WHO Withdrawal Act
blurb: The WHO Withdrawal Act (H.R. 54) aims to direct the President to withdraw the U.S. from the World Health Organization's Constitution and prohibits federal funding for participation. Introduced on January 3, 2025, by Mr. Biggs and co-sponsors, it has been referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs. Key takeaway: This legislation seeks to end U.S. involvement in the WHO.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 54 
To direct the President to withdraw the United States from the Constitution 
of the World Health Organization, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona (for himself, Mr. L AMALFA , Mr. B URLISON , Ms. 
HAGEMAN , Mr. M ASSIE , Mr. C RANE , Mr. M OOLENAAR , Ms. M ACE, Mr. 
HIGGINS of Louisiana, Mr. N ORMAN , Mr. O GLES , Ms. T ENNEY , Mr. 
EDWARDS , Mr. B RECHEEN , Mr. M CCORMICK , and Mrs. H ARSHBARGER ) 
introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs 
A BILL 
To direct the President to withdraw the United States from 
the Constitution of the World Health Organization, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘WHO Withdrawal 4
Act’’. 5
VerDate Sep 11 2014 18:55 Jan 28, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H54.IH H54ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS

STITUTION OF THE WORLD HEALTH ORGANI- 2
ZATION; PROHIBITION ON USE OF FUNDS. 3
Effective on the date of the enactment of this Act— 4
(1) the President shall withdraw the United 5
States from the Constitution of the World Health 6
Organization (62 Stat. 2679; 14 U.N.T.S 186); and 7
(2) no funds available to any Federal depart- 8
ment or agency may used to provide for the partici- 9
pation of the United States in the World Health Or- 10
ganization or any successor organization. 11
SEC. 3. REPEAL OF THE ACT OF JUNE 14, 1948. 12
The Act of June 14, 1948 (Public Law 806–43; 62 13
Stat. 441; 22 U.S.C. 290 et seq.), providing for member-14
ship and participation by the United States in the World 15
Health Organization and authorizing an appropriation 16
therefor, is repealed. 17
Æ

event_name: Let America Vote Act
blurb: The "Let America Vote Act" (H.R. 155) aims to allow unaffiliated voters to participate in primary elections for federal office. Introduced on January 3, 2025, it is currently under review by the House Administration and Judiciary Committees. States must certify compliance to receive federal election funds, ensuring unaffiliated voters can vote without being treated as party members. Key provisions include safeguarding voter information and prohibiting non-citizen voting.

event_name: No Free Rent for Freeloaders Act of 2025
blurb: The "No Free Rent for Freeloaders Act of 2025" aims to penalize the Department of Housing and Urban Development for non-compliance with public housing community service requirements. It mandates annual monitoring by the Inspector General and requires publication of non-compliance subsidy amounts. The bill has been referred to the Committees on Financial Services and Appropriations for further consideration.

Committee on Financial Services, and in addition to the Committee on Appropriations, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speak-er, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the ju-risdiction of the committee concerned

loaders Act of 2025’’. 5

event_name: To require a particular jury instruction in Federal civil actions that include a claim for damages based on negligence arising from the transmission of COVID-19.
blurb: A new bill mandates specific jury instructions in federal civil cases involving negligence claims related to COVID-19 transmission. Currently referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary, this legislation aims to clarify legal standards for such cases. Stakeholders should monitor its progress for potential implications on liability and damages.

metadata.event_name: To require a particular jury instruction in Federal civil actions that include a claim for damages based on negligence arising from the transmission of COVID-19.

event_name: CLEAN Congress Act
blurb: The CLEAN Congress Act (H.R. 157), introduced by Mr. Fitzpatrick, aims to ensure that congressional bills address only one subject and mandates equal application of laws to all Members of Congress. Currently referred to the House Judiciary Committee, this legislation seeks to enhance transparency and accountability in the legislative process. Key takeaway: single-subject bills could prevent legislative bundling and improve governance.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 157 
To prohibit a single bill or joint resolution presented by Congress to the 
President from containing multiple subjects and to require the equal application of laws to Members of Congress. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. F ITZPATRICK introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on the Judiciary 
A BILL 
To prohibit a single bill or joint resolution presented by 
Congress to the President from containing multiple sub-jects and to require the equal application of laws to Members of Congress. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Citizen Legislature 4

event_name: To promote freedom, fairness, and economic opportunity by repealing the income tax and other taxes, abolishing the Internal Revenue Service, and enacting a national sales tax to be administered primarily by the States.
blurb: A proposal aims to promote freedom and economic opportunity by repealing the income tax, abolishing the IRS, and implementing a national sales tax managed by states. The bill has been referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means for further consideration. Key takeaways include potential shifts in tax structure and state-level administration of tax collection.

event_name: Freedom to Petition the Government Act
blurb: The Freedom to Petition the Government Act (H.R. 69) aims to exempt nonprofit organizations from registering in D.C. when meeting federal officials at government-owned or leased locations. Introduced by Mr. Biggs and others on January 3, 2025, the bill is currently under review by the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform. This legislation could streamline nonprofit interactions with the government.

treat meetings held by nonprofit organizations with offi-cials of the Federal Government which are held in the District of Columbia at locations owned or leased by the Federal Government as activities not constituting doing business in the District of Columbia for purposes of determining whether such organizations are required to register with the District of Columbia.

tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

event_name: Stop Woke Investing Act
blurb: The "Stop Woke Investing Act" (H.R. 52) was introduced in the House on January 3, 2025, and referred to the Financial Services Committee. It mandates the SEC to revise rules on shareholder proposals, limiting the number of proposals companies must include based on their filing status. Key takeaways: non-accelerated filers can include 2 proposals, while large accelerated filers can include up to 7, provided they materially affect financial performance.
