event_name: Proposing a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution of the United States.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, Rep. Andy Biggs introduced H.J. Res. 2, proposing a balanced budget amendment to the U.S. Constitution. The resolution aims to limit federal spending to total receipts, restrict debt increases, and require a two-thirds majority for revenue-raising bills. It is currently under review by the House Judiciary Committee. Key takeaway: a potential shift in fiscal policy requiring stricter budgetary controls.
body:
IA 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. J. RES. 2 
Proposing a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution of the United 
States. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona submitted the following joint resolution; which was 
referred to the Committee on the Judiciary 
JOINT RESOLUTION 
Proposing a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution 
of the United States. 
Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives 1
of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two- 2
thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol- 3
lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con-4
stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all 5
intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when 6
ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several 7
States: 8

‘‘SECTION 1. Total outlays for any fiscal year shall 2
not exceed total receipts for that fiscal year. 3
‘‘SECTION 2. The limit on the debt of the United 4
States held by the public shall not be increased. 5
‘‘SECTION 3. No bill to increase revenue shall become 6
law unless approved by two-thirds of the whole number 7
of each House by a rollcall vote.’’. 8

event_name: FUEL Reform Act
blurb: The FUEL Reform Act (H.R. 112), introduced by Mr. Biggs on January 3, 2025, aims to repeal Department of Agriculture bioenergy subsidy programs. The bill is currently under review by the Committees on Agriculture, Oversight and Government Reform, and Science, Space, and Technology. Key takeaway: if passed, this legislation could significantly alter federal support for bioenergy initiatives.

event_name: CLEAN Public Service Act
blurb: The CLEAN Public Service Act (H.R. 159), introduced by Mr. Fitzpatrick, aims to terminate pensions for Members of Congress. The bill is currently under review by the Committee on House Administration and the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform. If enacted, it will eliminate retirement benefits for future congressional members, effective 90 days post-enactment. This legislation seeks to enhance accountability in public service.

Andy Biggs, the bill has been referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources. Key takeaway: This legislation seeks to give Arizona greater control over federal land designations.

event_name: HOUSE Act of 2025
blurb: The HOUSE Act of 2025, introduced by Rep. Biggs and others, aims to revoke energy efficiency standards for HUD- and USDA-financed housing. It mandates the withdrawal of a prior determination and prohibits federal funding for enforcement. The bill is currently under review by the Financial Services and Veterans' Affairs Committees. Key takeaway: This legislation seeks to revert to previous energy standards, impacting housing policy and funding.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 75 
To require the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and the Sec-
retary of Agriculture to withdraw a final determination relating to energy efficiency standards for housing, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona (for himself, Mr. O GLES , and Mr. H IGGINS of Lou-
isiana) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Financial Services, and in addition to the Committee on Veterans’ Af-fairs, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned 
A BILL

event_name: KAMALA Act
blurb: The KAMALA Act (H.R. 50), introduced on January 3, 2025, aims to restrict federal housing grants from aiding non-U.S. nationals or those not lawfully present. Currently under review by the House Committee on Financial Services, the bill emphasizes accountability in municipal aid. Key takeaway: Non-compliance with this provision could lead to funding limitations for local governments.
body:

1STSESSION  H. R. 50 
To prohibit grants provided under section 106 of the Housing and Community 
Development Act of 1974 from being used to assist persons who are neither a national of the United States nor lawfully admitted for perma-nent residence, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona (for himself, Mr. O GLES , Mr. C RANE , and Mrs. L UNA) 
introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Fi-nancial Services 
A BILL 
To prohibit grants provided under section 106 of the Hous-
ing and Community Development Act of 1974 from being used to assist persons who are neither a national of the United States nor lawfully admitted for permanent residence, and for other purposes.

tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Keeping Aid for Mu- 4
nicipalities And Localities Accountable Act’’ or the 5
‘‘KAMALA Act’’. 6

event_name: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide for balanced budgets for the Government.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, H.J. Res. 6 was introduced to propose a constitutional amendment for balanced federal budgets. It mandates that annual outlays not exceed receipts unless approved by a two-thirds Congressional vote. The resolution is currently referred to the House Judiciary Committee. Key provisions include waivers for war, national emergencies, and natural disasters, with enforcement through appropriate legislation.
body:
IA 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. J. RES. 6 
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide 
for balanced budgets for the Government. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. F ITZPATRICK submitted the following joint resolution; which was referred 
to the Committee on the Judiciary 
JOINT RESOLUTION 
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United 
States to provide for balanced budgets for the Government. 
Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives 1
of the United States of America in Congress assembled2
(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol- 3
lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con-4
stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all 5
intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when 6
ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several 7
States: 8
VerDate Sep 11 2014 22:14 Jan 04, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\HJ6.IH HJ6kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
2 
•HJ 6 IH ‘‘ARTICLE — 1
‘‘SECTION 1. Total outlays for any fiscal year shall 2
not exceed total receipts for that fiscal year, unless two- 3
thirds of the whole number of each House of Congress 4
shall provide by law for a specific excess of outlays over 5
receipts by a rollcall vote. 6
‘‘SECTION 2. Prior to each fiscal year, the President 7
shall transmit to the Congress a proposed budget for the 8
United States Government for that fiscal year in which 9
total outlays do not exceed total receipts. 10
‘‘SECTION 3. The Congress may waive the provisions 11
of this article for any fiscal year in which a declaration 12
of war is in effect by a rollcall vote. 13
‘‘SECTION 4. The Congress may waive the provisions 14
of this article for any fiscal year in which a declaration 15
of national emergency is in effect, as so declared by a joint 16
resolution, adopted by a majority of the whole number of 17
each House, which becomes law. 18
‘‘SECTION 5. The Congress may waive the provisions 19
of this article for any fiscal year in which a declaration 20
of a natural disaster is in effect, as so declared by a joint 21
resolution, adopted by a majority of the whole number of 22
each House, which becomes law. 23
VerDate Sep 11 2014 22:14 Jan 04, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\HJ6.IH HJ6kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
3 
•HJ 6 IH ‘‘SECTION 6. The Congress shall enforce and imple- 1
ment this article by appropriate legislation, which may rely 2
on estimates of outlays and receipts. 3
‘‘SECTION 7. This article shall take effect beginning 4
with the fifth fiscal year beginning after its ratification.’’. 5

event_name: Ensuring United Families at the Border Act
blurb: The "Ensuring United Families at the Border Act" (H.R. 61) aims to amend the 2008 Trafficking Victims Protection Act, clarifying family detention standards. Introduced by Rep. Biggs and referred to the House Judiciary Committee, it allows detention of families together, overriding state licensing requirements for facilities. This legislation emphasizes the importance of maintaining family unity during immigration proceedings.

event_name: No Vaccine Passports Act
blurb: The "No Vaccine Passports Act" (H.R. 121) was introduced on January 3, 2025, to prohibit federal agencies from issuing vaccine passports or requiring proof of COVID-19 vaccination for access to federal properties and services. The bill is currently under consideration by the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform and the Committee on House Administration. Key takeaway: it aims to protect citizens from mandatory vaccination documentation.

Act’’. 5

cine passport, vaccine pass, or other standardized docu-9

event_name: Modernizing Retrospective Regulatory Review
blurb: The "Modernizing Retrospective Regulatory Review Act" (H.R. 67) aims to enhance the review of federal regulations. It mandates a report on making regulations machine-readable within 180 days, and agencies must submit implementation plans within two years. The act emphasizes using technology for efficient reviews, ensuring regulations are relevant and effective. Key deadlines include a guidance issuance in 18 months and agency implementation within 180 days of plan submission.

event_name: To protect the right of law-abiding citizens to transport knives interstate, notwithstanding a patchwork of State and local prohibitions that burden citizens.
blurb: The proposed legislation aims to safeguard law-abiding citizens' rights to transport knives across state lines, addressing conflicting state and local laws. Currently referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary, this bill seeks to unify regulations and reduce legal burdens for citizens. Key takeaway: Watch for committee discussions that may shape future interstate transport rights.

event_name: To specify the state of mind required for conviction for criminal offenses that lack an expressly identified state of mind, and for other purposes.
blurb: The proposed legislation aims to clarify the required state of mind for convictions in criminal offenses without an explicitly defined mental state. It has been referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary for review. Key takeaway: Understanding the mental state criteria is crucial for fair legal proceedings.

metadata.event_name: To specify the state of mind required for conviction for criminal offenses that lack an expressly identified state of mind, and for other purposes.

event_name: Space Research Innovation Act
blurb: The Space Research Innovation Act, introduced by Mr. Biggs, aims to establish a university-affiliated research center for deep space and interplanetary research under NASA. Referred to the House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology, it seeks to enhance capabilities for cis-lunar and deep-space missions through public-private partnerships. Eligible participants include higher education institutions and nonprofit research organizations.
body:

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 108 
To allow the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Adminis-
tration to establish a research center for deep space and interplanetary research, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Science, Space, and Technology 
A BILL 
To allow the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and 
Space Administration to establish a research center for deep space and interplanetary research, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3

event_name: Small Business Flexibility Act
blurb: The Small Business Flexibility Act (H.R. 85), introduced by Mr. Biggs, aims to amend the Fair Labor Standards Act to permit tip pooling among all employees. Currently referred to the House Committee on Education and Workforce, this bill seeks to enhance wage equity in tip-receiving industries. Key takeaway: If passed, it could significantly change how tips are distributed, benefiting a broader range of workers.

ployees who customarily and regularly receive tips’’ 10

The bill is currently under review by the House Committee on Natural Resources. Key takeaway: This legislation facilitates congressional oversight of border security on tribal lands.

event_name: End Endless Criminal Statutes Act
blurb: The "End Endless Criminal Statutes Act" (H.R. 98) aims to repeal outdated federal criminal offenses, such as minor check writing and specific food labeling regulations. Introduced by Rep. Andy Biggs and referred to the House Judiciary Committee, this bill seeks to reduce unnecessary legal penalties. Key takeaways include potential legal simplification and a focus on modernizing criminal statutes.

JANUARY 3, 2025

Committee on the Judiciary

To repeal certain unnecessary criminal offenses, and for 
other purposes.

tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

Statutes Act’’. 5

carry criminal penalties under Federal statues include the 8
following: 9
(1) Writing a check for less than $1. 10

event_name: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to require that the Supreme Court of the United States be composed of nine justices.
blurb: A joint resolution (H.J. Res. 1) has been introduced to amend the U.S. Constitution, mandating that the Supreme Court consist of nine justices. Submitted by Mr. Biggs of Arizona on January 3, 2025, the resolution is currently referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary. If passed, it requires ratification by three-fourths of state legislatures within seven years.
body:

Mr. B IGGS of Arizona submitted the following joint resolution; which was 
referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United 
States to require that the Supreme Court of the United States be composed of nine justices.

of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two- 2
thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol- 3
lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con-4
stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all 5
intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when 6
ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several 7
States within seven years after the date of its submission 8
for ratification: 9

event_name: To terminate the designation of the Islamic Republic of Pakistan as a major non-NATO ally, and for other purposes.
blurb: The House has introduced H.R. 94 to revoke Pakistan's status as a major non-NATO ally. The bill requires the President to certify Pakistan's military actions against the Haqqani Network and cooperation with Afghanistan before any future designation. It is currently referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs. Key takeaway: This move reflects U.S. concerns over Pakistan's counterterrorism efforts.
body:

event_name: Injunctive Authority Clarification Act of 2025
blurb: The Injunctive Authority Clarification Act of 2025, introduced by Mr. Biggs, aims to amend Title 28 of the U.S. Code to prohibit national injunctions against non-parties. The bill has been referred to the House Judiciary Committee for consideration, marking a significant shift in judicial authority. Stakeholders should monitor its progress for potential impacts on legal practices.
body:

Clarification Act of 2025’’. 5

MENT AGAINST NON-PARTIES. 7
(a) I NGENERAL .—Chapter 155 of title 28, United 8
States Code, is amended by adding at the end the fol-9
lowing: 10

event_name: Buzz Off Act
blurb: The Buzz Off Act, introduced by Mr. Biggs on January 3, 2025, aims to prohibit federal agencies from using unmanned aerial vehicles for surveillance of U.S. citizens without consent. Exceptions exist for authorized counter-terrorism efforts or with a judicial warrant. The bill has been referred to the House Judiciary Committee for further consideration.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 96 
To prevent agencies from using unmanned aerial vehicles to conduct 
surveillance of United States citizens, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on the Judiciary 
A BILL 
To prevent agencies from using unmanned aerial vehicles 
to conduct surveillance of United States citizens, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Buzz Off Act’’. 4
SEC. 2. PROHIBITING USE OF UNMANNED AERIAL VEHI-5
CLES. 6
(a) S URVEILLANCE .—A Federal law enforcement 7
agency may not use an unmanned aerial vehicle to inten-8
tionally conduct surveillance of, gather evidence or collect 9
information about, or photographically or electronically 10
VerDate Sep 11 2014 05:13 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H96.IH H96kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
2 
•HR 96 IHrecord a specifically targeted United States citizen or the 1
specifically targeted private property of a United States 2
citizen. 3
(b) E XCEPTION .—Notwithstanding subsection (a), a 4
Federal law enforcement agency may use an unmanned 5
aerial vehicle to photograph, or otherwise record a United 6
States citizen for the purposes of publishing or otherwise 7
publicly disseminating such photograph or recording if the 8
agency obtains the written consent of such United States 9
citizen. 10
(c) A PPLICABILITY .—Subsection (a) shall not apply 11
in the case that— 12
(1) the President, acting through the Secretary 13
of Homeland Security, authorizes use of an un- 14
manned aerial vehicle to conduct surveillance if the 15
Secretary certifies in writing under oath that the 16
surveillance is necessary to counter a high risk of a 17
terrorist attack by a specific individual or organiza- 18
tion; or 19
(2) the head of a Federal law enforcement 20
agency first obtains a search warrant signed by a 21
judge authorizing the use of an unmanned aerial ve- 22
hicle. 23
Æ

event_name: One Bill, One Subject Transparency Act
blurb: The One Bill, One Subject Transparency Act (H.R. 95) was introduced by Mr. Biggs and referred to the House Judiciary Committee. This bill mandates that each congressional bill focus on a single subject, ensuring clarity and accountability. Key provisions include voiding any bill with multiple subjects in its title and allowing legal action against non-compliant laws. This legislation aims to enhance legislative transparency and prevent unrelated provisions in bills.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 95 
To require that each bill enacted by Congress be limited to only one subject, 
and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on the Judiciary 
A BILL 
To require that each bill enacted by Congress be limited 
to only one subject, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘One Bill, One Subject 4
Transparency Act’’. 5
SEC. 2. ONE SUBJECT PER BILL. 6
(a) O NESUBJECT .—Each bill or joint resolution 7
shall embrace no more than one subject. 8
VerDate Sep 11 2014 02:36 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H95.IH H95ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
2 
•HR 95 IH(b) S UBJECT IN TITLE.—The subject of a bill or joint 1
resolution shall be clearly and descriptively expressed in 2
the title. 3
(c) A PPROPRIATION BILLS.—An appropriations bill 4
shall not contain any general legislation or change of exist-5
ing law provision which is not germane to the subject mat-6
ter of the underlying bill. This subsection does not prohibit 7
any provision imposing limitations upon the expenditure 8
of appropriated funds. 9
SEC. 3. ENFORCEMENT. 10
(a) M ULTIPLE SUBJECTS IN TITLE.—If the title of 11
an Act or joint resolution addresses two or more unrelated 12
subjects, then the entire Act or joint resolution is void. 13
(b) P ROVISIONS NOTEXPRESSED IN TITLE.—If an 14
Act or joint resolution contains provisions concerning a 15
subject that is not clearly and descriptively expressed in 16
its title, those provisions shall be void. 17
(c) A PPROPRIATION PROVISIONS OUTSIDE SUB- 18
COMMITTEE JURISDICTION .—If an Act appropriating 19
funds contains a provision outside of the jurisdiction of 20
the relevant subcommittee of the Committees on Appro-21
priations of the House and of the Senate, and therefore 22
outside the subject of the bill, then such provision shall 23
be void. 24
VerDate Sep 11 2014 02:36 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6201 E:\BILLS\H95.IH H95ssavage on LAPJG3WLY3PROD with BILLS
3 
•HR 95 IH(d) P ROVISIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS BILLS NOT 1
GERMANE TO SUBJECT MATTER .—If an Act appro- 2
priating funds contains general legislation or change of ex-3
isting law provision not germane to the subject matter of 4
the underlying bill, then every such provision shall be void. 5
(e) C OMMENCEMENT OF AN ACTION .—Any person, 6
including a Member of the House of Representatives or 7
a Member of the Senate, aggrieved by the enforcement or 8
threat of enforcement of Acts that do not comply with sec-9
tion 2 shall have a cause of action under sections 2201 10
and 2202 of title 28, United States Code, against the 11
United States to seek appropriate relief, including an in-12
junction against the enforcement of any law, the passage 13
of which did not conform to section 2 or this section. The 14
cause of action only applies to an Act or joint resolution 15
signed into law on or after the date of enactment of this 16
Act. 17
(f) S TATE OF REVIEW .—In any judicial action 18
brought pursuant to subsection (e), the standard of review 19

event_name: Native American Education Opportunity Act
blurb: The Native American Education Opportunity Act, introduced by Mr. Biggs, aims to enhance educational options for Native American children. It proposes funding for Tribal education savings accounts, allowing Tribes to disburse $8,000 annually per eligible student for various educational expenses. The bill has been referred to the House Committee on Education and Workforce for further consideration. Key takeaway: This initiative seeks to empower Tribes in managing educational resources effectively.

event_name: Midnight Rules Relief Act
blurb: The Midnight Rules Relief Act (H.R. 77) aims to amend U.S. Code to allow en bloc consideration of resolutions disapproving "midnight rules" issued in a president's final year. Introduced by Rep. Biggs and others, the bill has been referred to the Judiciary and Rules Committees for further review. Key takeaway: This legislation could streamline the process for Congress to reject last-minute regulations.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 77 
To amend chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, to provide for en bloc 
consideration in resolutions of disapproval for ‘‘midnight rules’’, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona (for himself, Mr. L AMALFA , Mr. G ROTHMAN , Mr. 
BRECHEEN , and Mr. O GLES ) introduced the following bill; which was re-
ferred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and in addition to the Com-mittee on Rules, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To amend chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, to provide 
for en bloc consideration in resolutions of disapproval for ‘‘midnight rules’’, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Midnight Rules Relief 4
Act’’. 5

event_name: Voter Integrity Protection Act
blurb: The Voter Integrity Protection Act (H.R. 58), introduced by Mr. Biggs and Ms. Mace, aims to classify voting in federal elections by unlawfully present aliens as an aggravated felony. The bill has been referred to the House Judiciary Committee. Key takeaway: If enacted, this legislation would enhance penalties for unlawful voting and increase deportation risks for offenders.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 58 
To amend the Immigration and Nationality Act to make voting in a Federal 
election by an unlawfully present alien an aggravated felony, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona (for himself and Ms. M ACE) introduced the following 
bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary 
A BILL 
To amend the Immigration and Nationality Act to make 
voting in a Federal election by an unlawfully present alien an aggravated felony, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Voter Integrity Protec- 4
tion Act’’. 5
SEC. 2. UNLAWFUL VOTING. 6

event_name: To close loopholes in the immigration laws that serve as incentives to aliens to attempt to enter the United States unlawfully, and for other purposes.
blurb: The bill aims to close immigration law loopholes that incentivize unlawful entry into the U.S. It has been referred to the Committee on the Judiciary and the Committee on Foreign Affairs for review. Key provisions will be considered based on each committee's jurisdiction. Stakeholders should monitor for further developments and committee discussions.

event_name: Ending Common Core and Expanding School Choice Act
blurb: The "Ending Common Core and Expanding School Choice Act" (H.R. 83) aims to amend the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, allowing federal education funds for disadvantaged children to follow them to public, charter, or private schools. Introduced by Mr. Biggs, the bill promotes state flexibility in funding allocation and eliminates mandates for specific academic standards. Currently referred to the House Committee on Education and Workforce for further consideration.
body:

Act of 1965 to allow States, in accordance with State law, to let Federal funds for the education of disadvantaged children follow low-income chil-dren to the public school, charter school, accredited private school, or supplemental educational service program they attend, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025

Committee on Education and Workforce 
A BILL

Education Act of 1965 to allow States, in accordance with State law, to let Federal funds for the education of disadvantaged children follow low-income children to the public school, charter school, accredited private school, or supplemental educational service program they attend, and for other purposes.

tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

event_name: American Sovereignty and Species Protection Act of 2025
blurb: The American Sovereignty and Species Protection Act of 2025 aims to amend the Endangered Species Act to prevent nonnative species from being classified as endangered or threatened. It also prohibits certain financial assistance related to land acquisition abroad. The bill has been referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources for further consideration.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 102 
To amend the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to prevent a species that 
is not native to the United States from being listed as an endangered species or a threatened species, to prohibit certain types of financial assistance, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Natural Resources 
A BILL 
To amend the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to prevent 
a species that is not native to the United States from being listed as an endangered species or a threatened species, to prohibit certain types of financial assistance, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘American Sovereignty 4
and Species Protection Act of 2025’’. 5

event_name: Freedom for Farmers Act of 2025
blurb: The Freedom for Farmers Act of 2025, introduced by Mr. Biggs, aims to abolish the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, effective one year post-enactment. The bill has been referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. Key actions include transferring the agency's functions to the Department of Health and Human Services. Stakeholders should monitor developments closely as this may impact regulatory frameworks related to toxic substances.

event_name: Ending Catch and Release Act of 2025
blurb: The "Ending Catch and Release Act of 2025" (H.R. 57) aims to amend the Immigration and Nationality Act to prohibit the parole or release of asylum applicants into the U.S. It mandates detention or return to contiguous territories for further asylum consideration. The bill was introduced by Mr. Biggs and Ms. Mace and has been referred to the House Judiciary Committee for review. Key takeaway: stricter measures on asylum applicant processing are proposed.

event_name: Health Coverage Choice Act
blurb: The Health Coverage Choice Act (H.R. 90) was introduced by Mr. Biggs on January 3, 2025, and is currently under review by the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. This bill aims to define short-term limited duration insurance, specifying coverage contracts lasting under 12 months and renewable for up to 3 years. Key takeaway: This legislation seeks to clarify insurance options for consumers.

INSURANCE. 7

U.S.C. 300gg–91(b)) is amended by adding at the end the 9
following new paragraph: 10

event_name: Medical Innovation Acceleration Act of 2025
blurb: The Medical Innovation Acceleration Act of 2025, introduced by Mr. Biggs, aims to exempt non-invasive diagnostic devices from FDA regulation under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. This bill, currently with the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, seeks to streamline the approval process for innovative medical technologies. Key takeaway: Non-invasive devices will be defined as those not penetrating the skin or using ionizing radiation.
body:

119 THCONGRESS

regulation as devices non-invasive diagnostic devices, and for other purposes.

Mr. B IGGS of Arizona introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Energy and Commerce

To amend the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to

Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Medical Innovation Ac- 4
celeration Act of 2025’’. 5
SEC. 2. EXEMPTING NON-INVASIVE DIAGNOSTIC DEVICES 6
FROM REGULATION AS DEVICES. 7

metic Act (21 U.S.C. 321(h)) is amended— 9

agnostic device’’; and 3
(2) by adding at the end the following: ‘‘For 4
purposes of the preceding sentence, the term ‘non- 5
invasive’ means, with respect to a diagnostic device, 6
that the device does not penetrate the skin or any 7

ionizing radiation.’’. 12

event_name: To amend the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to further restrict the Secretary of the Interior from designating certain lands used for national defense-related purposes as critical habitat for any species under that Act and to broaden exclusions and exemptions from that Act for such defense-related purposes.
blurb: The proposed amendment to the Endangered Species Act seeks to limit the Secretary of the Interior's authority to designate defense-related lands as critical habitat. It aims to expand exemptions for national defense purposes. The bill is currently under review by the House Committee on Natural Resources. Stakeholders should monitor developments for potential impacts on conservation efforts and military operations.

event_name: Prescription Freedom Act of 2025
blurb: The Prescription Freedom Act of 2025, introduced by Mr. Biggs, aims to repeal the FDA's authority requiring prescriptions for certain drugs. If enacted, this change will take effect six months post-enactment, shifting oversight to state laws. Notably, the Secretary of Health and Human Services retains authority over drugs for pregnancy termination. The bill is currently with the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.

event_name: Defund National Endowment for the Humanities Act of 2025
blurb: The "Defund National Endowment for the Humanities Act of 2025" (H.R. 82) was introduced by Mr. Biggs and referred to the House Committee on Education and Workforce. The bill aims to prohibit any funds allocated to the National Endowment for the Humanities from being used to implement section 7 of the National Foundation on the Arts and Humanities Act of 1965. If enacted, it takes effect at the start of the next fiscal year.

event_name: Reaffirming that the United States is not a party to the Rome Statute and does not recognize the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, H. Res. 9 was introduced in the House, reaffirming that the U.S. is not a party to the Rome Statute and does not recognize the International Criminal Court's jurisdiction. The resolution condemns recent ICC arrest warrants for Israeli leaders and emphasizes U.S. support for Israel's right to self-defense. It is currently referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs for further consideration.
body:
IV 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. RES. 9 
Reaffirming that the United States is not a party to the Rome Statute 
and does not recognize the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona submitted the following resolution; which was referred 
to the Committee on Foreign Affairs 
RESOLUTION 
Reaffirming that the United States is not a party to the 
Rome Statute and does not recognize the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court. 
Whereas the Constitution requires approval from two-thirds 
of the Senators present for ratification and confirmation of international treaties; 
Whereas President Bill Clinton signed the Rome Statute on 
December 31, 2000, but did not submit the treaty to the Senate for ratification; 
Whereas, on May 6, 2002, the Bush administration an-
nounced that the United States does not intend to be-come a party to the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court; 
VerDate Sep 11 2014 22:17 Jan 04, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6300 E:\BILLS\HR9.IH HR9kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
2 
•HRES 9 IH Whereas Article 125 of the Rome Statute states that it is 
‘‘subject to ratification, acceptance, or approval by signa-tory States’’; 
Whereas, on May 20, 2024, the Prosecutor of the Inter-
national Criminal Court, Karim Khan, took unprece-dented measures announcing arrest warrant applications for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Min-ister of Defense Yoav Gallant; 
Whereas the United States and Israel are not parties to the 
Rome Statute or members of the International Criminal Court; and 
Whereas the United States does not recognize the legitimacy 
or jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court: Now, therefore, be it 
Resolved, That the House of Representatives— 1
(1) reaffirms that the United States is not a 2
party to the Rome Statute and does not recognize 3
the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court; 4
(2) condemns the International Criminal 5
Court’s issuance of arrest warrant applications for 6
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and 7
Minister of Defense Yoav Gallant; and 8
(3) reiterates its unwavering support for the 9
State of Israel and its right to defend itself and its 10
leaders from unwarranted international legal actions. 11
Æ 
VerDate Sep 11 2014 22:17 Jan 04, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6301 E:\BILLS\HR9.IH HR9kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB

event_name: Limiting Emergency Powers Act of 2025
blurb: The Limiting Emergency Powers Act of 2025, introduced by Mr. Biggs, aims to amend the National Emergencies Act, requiring national emergencies declared by the President to terminate after 30 days unless Congress enacts a joint resolution affirming the declaration. The bill has been referred to multiple committees for further consideration. Key takeaway: This legislation seeks to enhance congressional oversight of emergency powers.
body:

119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 125

declared by the President terminates 30 days after the declaration unless a joint resolution affirming such declaration is enacted into law, and for other purposes.

JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure, and in addition to the Committees on Foreign Affairs, and Rules, for a period to be subse-quently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

To amend the National Emergencies Act to provide that 
a national emergency declared by the President termi-nates 30 days after the declaration unless a joint resolu-tion affirming such declaration is enacted into law, and for other purposes.

tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

Powers Act of 2025’’. 5

event_name: Protection from Obamacare Mandates and Congressional Equity Act
blurb: The "Protection from Obamacare Mandates and Congressional Equity Act" (H.R. 127) aims to exempt individuals in counties with fewer than two health insurance issuers from the individual mandate. Additionally, it mandates that Congress members and staff comply with the Affordable Care Act. The bill is currently under review by multiple committees. Key takeaway: potential relief for residents in underserved areas and accountability for congressional health coverage.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 127 
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide an exemption 
to the individual mandate to maintain health coverage for individuals residing in counties with fewer than 2 health insurance issuers offering plans on an Exchange; to require Members of Congress and congressional staff to abide by the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act with respect to health insurance coverage; and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Ways and Means, and in addition to the Committees on Energy and Commerce, House Administration, and Oversight and Gov-ernment Reform, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide 
an exemption to the individual mandate to maintain health coverage for individuals residing in counties with fewer than 2 health insurance issuers offering plans on an Exchange; to require Members of Congress and con-gressional staff to abide by the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act with respect to health insurance coverage; and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

event_name: No Bailout for Sanctuary Cities Act
blurb: The "No Bailout for Sanctuary Cities Act" (H.R. 32) aims to deny federal funds to sanctuary jurisdictions that provide benefits to undocumented immigrants. Introduced by Rep. LaLota and referred to the House Judiciary Committee on January 3, 2025, the bill defines sanctuary jurisdictions and sets a compliance deadline. Key takeaway: jurisdictions must comply with federal immigration requests or lose funding.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 32 
To provide that sanctuary jurisdictions that provide benefits to aliens who 
are present in the United States without lawful status under the immi-gration laws are ineligible for Federal funds intended to benefit such aliens. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. L ALOTA (for himself, Mr. F EENSTRA , Mrs. H OUCHIN , Mr. M CCAUL, and 
Mr. N UNN of Iowa) introduced the following bill; which was referred to 
the Committee on the Judiciary 
A BILL 
To provide that sanctuary jurisdictions that provide benefits 
to aliens who are present in the United States without lawful status under the immigration laws are ineligible for Federal funds intended to benefit such aliens. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘No Bailout for Sanc- 4
tuary Cities Act’’. 5

section (b), for purposes of this Act, the term ‘‘sanctuary 3
jurisdiction’’ means any State or political subdivision of 4
a State that has in effect a statute, ordinance, policy, or 5
practice that prohibits or restricts any government entity 6
or official from— 7
(1) sending, receiving, maintaining, or exchang- 8
ing with any Federal, State, or local government en- 9
tity information regarding the citizenship or immi- 10
gration status (lawful or unlawful) of any individual; 11
or 12
(2) complying with a request lawfully made by 13
the Department of Homeland Security under section 14
236 or 287 of the Immigration and Nationality Act 15
(8 U.S.C. 1226 and 1357) to comply with a detainer 16
for, or notify about the release of, an individual. 17
(b) E XCEPTION .—A State or political subdivision of 18
a State shall not be deemed a sanctuary jurisdiction based 19
solely on its having a policy whereby its officials will not 20
share information regarding, or comply with a request 21
made by the Department of Homeland Security under sec-22
tion 236 or 287 of the Immigration and Nationality Act 23
(8 U.S.C. 1226 and 1357) to comply with a detainer re-24
garding, an individual who comes forward as a victim or 25

of the fiscal year that begins after the date of enactment 5
of this Act, a sanctuary jurisdiction is ineligible to receive 6
any Federal funds that the sanctuary jurisdiction intends 7
to use for the benefit (including the provision of food, shel-8

of aliens who are present in the United States without law-10
ful status under the immigration laws (as such terms are 11
defined in section 101 of the Immigration and Nationality 12
Act). 13
SEC. 4. REPORT ON NONCOMPLIANCE. 14
Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment 15
of this Act, and annually thereafter, the Secretary of 16

cludes a list of States, and political subdivisions of States, 20

tion 2(a)(2). 22

event_name: Drain the Intelligence Community Swamp Act of 2025
blurb: The "Drain the Intelligence Community Swamp Act of 2025" aims to revoke security clearances for specific former intelligence officials linked to the Hunter Biden laptop controversy. Introduced by Representatives Biggs and Davidson, the bill mandates revocation within 24 hours of enactment and calls for investigations by the Secretary of Defense and Attorney General. This legislation emphasizes accountability within the intelligence community.

event_name: Protecting Our Children from the CDC Act
blurb: The "Protecting Our Children from the CDC Act" (H.R. 87) aims to prevent COVID-19 vaccines from being added to the child and adolescent immunization schedule without the prior public disclosure of all safety and efficacy data by the CDC. Introduced on January 3, 2025, by Rep. Andy Biggs, the bill requires transparency in vaccine data before inclusion, impacting existing vaccines as well. The bill is currently with the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 87 
To amend the Public Health Service Act to prohibit the Secretary of Health 
and Human Services from placing any vaccine for COVID–19 on the child and adolescent immunization schedule unless the Secretary has posted on the public website of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention all clinical data in the possession of the Department of Health and Human Services relating to the safety and efficacy of such vaccine, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona introduced the following bill; which was referred to the 
Committee on Energy and Commerce 
A BILL 
To amend the Public Health Service Act to prohibit the 
Secretary of Health and Human Services from placing any vaccine for COVID–19 on the child and adolescent immunization schedule unless the Secretary has posted on the public website of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention all clinical data in the possession of the Department of Health and Human Services relating to the safety and efficacy of such vaccine, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

event_name: Reaffirming the House of Representatives's commitment to ensuring secure elections throughout the United States by recognizing that the presentation of valid photograph identification is a fundamental component of secure elections.
blurb: On January 3, 2025, the House of Representatives introduced H. RES. 8, reaffirming its commitment to secure elections by emphasizing the necessity of valid photo identification. The resolution highlights that secure voting is essential for public trust and calls for the Committee on House Administration to review measures to enhance election security. Key takeaway: valid photo ID is deemed crucial for maintaining election integrity.
body:
IV 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. RES. 8 
Reaffirming the House of Representatives’s commitment to ensuring secure 
elections throughout the United States by recognizing that the presen-tation of valid photograph identification is a fundamental component of secure elections. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona (for himself and Mr. C RANE ) submitted the following 
resolution; which was referred to the Committee on House Administration 
RESOLUTION 
Reaffirming the House of Representatives’s commitment to 
ensuring secure elections throughout the United States by recognizing that the presentation of valid photograph identification is a fundamental component of secure elec-tions. 
Whereas elections allow United States citizens to empower 
their fellow citizens to be their voice in the constitutional republic; 
Whereas the operation of free and fair elections is vital to 
Americans’ trust in government; 
Whereas countries that hold elections without very basic secu-
rity measures eventually lose the support of their people and erode faith in elections and the rule of law; 
VerDate Sep 11 2014 22:17 Jan 04, 2025 Jkt 059200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6300 E:\BILLS\HR8.IH HR8kjohnson on DSK7ZCZBW3PROD with $$_JOB
2 
•HRES 8 IH Whereas absentee voting systems and voting by mail systems 
that lack photograph verification are less secure than in- person voting with photograph verification; 
Whereas United States citizens are required by law to present 
valid photograph identification to prove identity for a wide array of other interactions with government, includ-ing applications for taxpayer-funded food stamps, wel-fare, Social Security, and Medicaid; 
Whereas United States citizens are required by law to present 
valid photograph identification to prove identity for a wide array of interactions with private institutions, in-cluding to open a bank account, rent or buy a house, apply for a mortgage, buy, rent, or operate a motor vehi-cle, board an airplane, get married, purchase firearms, buy a cell phone, apply for fishing and hunting licenses, pick up prescription medication, and many other func-tions; and 
Whereas United States citizens possess no greater commodity 
than the franchise, and understand that protection of the security of voting and elections is crucial for the mainte-nance of the Republic and its way of life: Now, therefore, be it 
Resolved, That the House of Representatives— 1
(1) reaffirms and reiterates its commitment to 2
ensuring secure elections throughout the United 3
States; and 4
(2) recognizes that the presentation of valid 5
photograph identification is a fundamental compo- 6

3 
•HRES 8 IH nent of secure elections throughout the United 1
States. 2

event_name: POLICE Act of 2025
blurb: The POLICE Act of 2025, introduced by Rep. Garbarino and others, aims to make assaulting a law enforcement officer a deportable offense. Currently referred to the House Judiciary Committee, the bill mandates annual reports from the Department of Homeland Security on deportations related to such assaults. This legislation emphasizes the protection of law enforcement personnel and enhances immigration enforcement measures.
body:

To make the assault of a law enforcement officer a deportable offense, 
and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

MALLIOTAKIS , Mr. F EENSTRA , and Mr. N UNN of Iowa) introduced the 
following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary 
A BILL 
To make the assault of a law enforcement officer a 
deportable offense, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

forcement with Immigration Control and Enforcement Act 5
of 2025’’ or the ‘‘POLICE Act of 2025’’. 6

Section 237(a)(2) of the Immigration and Nationality 8
Act (8 U.S.C. 1227(a)(2)) is amended by adding at the 9
end the following: 10

forcement officer is deportable. 8

that the law enforcement officer was as- 11

cial duties; 15

‘‘(III) because of his or her sta- 18
tus as a law enforcement officer. 19
‘‘(iii) D EFINITIONS .—In this subpara- 20
graph— 21

meaning given that term in the juris- 23
diction where the act occurred; and 24

event_name: Improving Science in Chemical Assessments Act
blurb: The Improving Science in Chemical Assessments Act (H.R. 123) aims to enhance chemical toxicity assessments by directing the EPA's program offices to conduct these evaluations. Introduced by Rep. Biggs on January 3, 2025, the bill emphasizes scientific standards and coordination among EPA offices. It mandates regular reporting on assessment compliance and establishes a steering committee to avoid duplication. Key takeaway: This legislation seeks to improve the scientific rigor and efficiency of chemical safety evaluations.

event_name: Federal Employee Student Debt Transparency Act
blurb: The Federal Employee Student Debt Transparency Act (H.R. 66) mandates Senior Executive Service and Schedule C employees to disclose their federal student loan debt. Reports are due within 60 days of enactment and annually by February 28. The Office of Government Ethics will report total debt and non-compliance to Congress by May 1 each year. This legislation aims to enhance transparency among high-level federal employees regarding student debt.

event_name: To prohibit any entity that receives Federal funds from the COVID relief packages from mandating employees receive a COVID19 vaccine, and for other purposes.
blurb: The proposed legislation aims to prohibit entities receiving federal COVID relief funds from mandating employee vaccinations. It has been referred to the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform and the Committee on Energy and Commerce for review. Key takeaway: This could impact vaccination policies for federally funded organizations.

metadata.event_name: To prohibit any entity that receives Federal funds from the COVID relief packages from mandating employees receive a COVID19 vaccine, and for other purposes.

event_name: Freedom from Mandates Act
blurb: The Freedom from Mandates Act (H.R. 79) aims to nullify COVID-19 vaccine mandates established by Executive Orders and prevent the Secretary of Labor from enforcing vaccination requirements for employees. Currently referred to multiple committees for review, the bill seeks to protect individual choice regarding vaccination in federal employment and healthcare settings. Key takeaway: It emphasizes personal autonomy over mandated health measures.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 79 
To nullify certain Executive orders regarding COVID–19 vaccine mandates 
and to prohibit the Secretary of Labor from issuing a rule mandating vaccination against COVID–19, and for other purposes. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. B IGGS of Arizona (for himself and Mr. C LOUD ) introduced the following 
bill; which was referred to the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, and in addition to the Committees on Education and Workforce, Energy and Commerce, and Ways and Means, for a period to be subse-quently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To nullify certain Executive orders regarding COVID–19 
vaccine mandates and to prohibit the Secretary of Labor from issuing a rule mandating vaccination against COVID–19, and for other purposes. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Freedom from Man- 4
dates Act’’. 5

event_name: TBI and PTSD Treatment Act
blurb: The TBI and PTSD Treatment Act, introduced by Rep. Biggs and others, aims to provide hyperbaric oxygen therapy to veterans with traumatic brain injury or PTSD. Currently referred to the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs, this legislation seeks to amend title 38 of the U.S. Code to enhance treatment options for affected veterans. Key takeaway: Support for veterans' mental and physical health through innovative therapies.

ment Act’’. 5

event_name: Small Business Prosperity Act of 2025
blurb: The Small Business Prosperity Act of 2025, introduced by Mr. Biggs, aims to amend the Internal Revenue Code to permanently expand the qualified business income deduction to 43%, with an increase to 47% after 2025. It also repeals limitations based on W-2 wages and excludes certain service trades. The bill is currently referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means. Effective for tax years beginning after December 31, 2024.

event_name: To amend the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 to require proof of United States citizenship to register an individual to vote in elections for Federal office, and for other purposes.
blurb: The proposed amendment to the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 seeks to mandate proof of U.S. citizenship for voter registration in federal elections. Currently referred to the House Committee on House Administration, this legislation could significantly impact voter registration processes. Stakeholders should monitor developments closely for potential implications on electoral participation.

event_name: Protecting American Energy Production Act
blurb: The Protecting American Energy Production Act, introduced by Mr. Pfluger, seeks to prohibit any federal moratorium on hydraulic fracturing unless authorized by Congress. The bill emphasizes state regulation of hydraulic fracturing on state and private lands. It is currently under review by the Committees on Natural Resources and Energy and Commerce. Key takeaway: This legislation aims to safeguard energy production and limit federal intervention.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 26 
To prohibit a moratorium on the use of hydraulic fracturing. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. P FLUGER introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Com-
mittee on Natural Resources, and in addition to the Committee on En-ergy and Commerce, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To prohibit a moratorium on the use of hydraulic fracturing. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Protecting American 4
Energy Production Act’’. 5
SEC. 2. PROTECTING AMERICAN ENERGY PRODUCTION. 6
(a) S ENSE OF CONGRESS .—It is the sense of Con- 7
gress that States should maintain primacy for the regula-8
tion of hydraulic fracturing for oil and natural gas produc-9
tion on State and private lands. 10

RIUM ON HYDRAULIC FRACTURING .—Notwithstanding 2
any other provision of law, the President may not declare 3
a moratorium on the use of hydraulic fracturing unless 4
such moratorium is authorized by an Act of Congress. 5

event_name: Agent Raul Gonzalez Officer Safety Act
blurb: The Agent Raul Gonzalez Officer Safety Act, introduced in the House on January 3, 2025, aims to impose strict criminal and immigration penalties for individuals who intentionally flee from pursuing federal officers in vehicles. Key penalties include imprisonment from 2 years to life, depending on injury outcomes. The bill is currently under review by the House Judiciary Committee.

A BILL

tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2

cer Safety Act’’. 5

event_name: HALT Fentanyl Act
blurb: The HALT Fentanyl Act (H.R. 27) aims to amend the Controlled Substances Act to enhance the scheduling of fentanyl-related substances. Introduced on January 3, 2025, it is currently under review by the Committees on Energy and Commerce and Judiciary. Key provisions include stricter controls on fentanyl analogs and revised research registration processes. Stakeholders should monitor its progress for implications on substance regulation and research protocols.

event_name: LASSO Act
blurb: The LASSO Act (H.R. 34), introduced by Mr. Gosar, proposes to allocate 10% of revenue from public lands to the Social Security Trust Fund annually. Currently referred to the Committees on Natural Resources and Agriculture, this legislation aims to enhance Social Security funding without increasing public land activity costs or reducing state revenue. Key implications for public land management and Social Security sustainability are expected.
body:
I 
119 THCONGRESS 
1STSESSION  H. R. 34 
To deposit portions of revenue generated from public lands into the Social 
Security Trust Fund. 
IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
JANUARY 3, 2025 
Mr. G OSAR introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee 
on Natural Resources, and in addition to the Committee on Agriculture, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned 
A BILL 
To deposit portions of revenue generated from public lands 
into the Social Security Trust Fund. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Land And Social Secu- 4
rity Optimization Act’’ or ‘‘LASSO Act’’. 5
SEC. 2. PUBLIC LAND REVENUE FOR SOCIAL SECURITY 6
TRUST FUND. 7
(a) I NGENERAL .—Notwithstanding any other law, 8
each fiscal year, 10 percent of amounts collected by the 9

(2) reducing amounts made available to States, 13

event_name: Veterans Health Care Freedom Act
blurb: The Veterans Health Care Freedom Act (H.R. 71) aims to enhance veterans' access to medical care by allowing them to choose their health care providers. The bill introduces a pilot program across at least four Veterans Integrated Service Networks, focusing on both rural and urban areas. Key provisions include streamlined access to care and coordination with primary care providers. The program is set to start one year post-enactment and will be evaluated quarterly.

to improve the ability of veterans to access medical care in medical facilities of the Department of Veterans Affairs and in the community by providing the veterans the ability to choose health care providers.

JANUARY 3, 2025

SALAZAR , Mr. G OSAR , Mrs. L UNA, and Mr. B RECHEEN ) introduced the 
following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Veterans’ Affairs 
A BILL 
To direct the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to carry out 
a pilot program to improve the ability of veterans to access medical care in medical facilities of the Depart-ment of Veterans Affairs and in the community by pro-viding the veterans the ability to choose health care providers. 
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa- 1
tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 2
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 3
This Act may be cited as the ‘‘Veterans Health Care 4
Freedom Act’’. 5
